When balancing combustion reactions, why is it helpful to balance carbon and hydrogen first, then oxygen last? Use C₂H₅OH + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O as an example
Balance the equation for the combustion of butane: C₄H₁₀ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O. If you initially get fractional coefficients, how do you convert them to whole numbers?

sub_topics.name: Types of Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying reactions into categories based on patterns of reactant and product arrangements, including synthesis, decomposition, single replacement, double replacement, and combustion.

sub_topics.name: Synthesis (Combination) Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions where two or more simple substances combine to form a more complex product (A + B → AB).
example_tasks: Identify which of the following are synthesis reactions: (a) 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO, (b) 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂, (c) N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃
Write and balance equations for the synthesis reactions: (a) sodium metal with chlorine gas, (b) magnesium oxide from its elements, (c) water from hydrogen and oxygen
Predict the product and write a balanced equation for the synthesis reaction between calcium and oxygen

sub_topics.name: Decomposition Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions where a complex substance breaks down into two or more simpler products (AB → A + B), often requiring energy input.
example_tasks: Classify each reaction as synthesis or decomposition: (a) 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂, (b) 2Na + Cl₂ → 2NaCl, (c) CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂
Write and balance the decomposition reactions for: (a) hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) breaking into water and oxygen, (b) sodium chloride breaking into its elements

Many decomposition reactions require heating (indicated by Δ over the arrow). Write a balanced equation for the thermal decomposition of potassium chlorate (KClO₃) into potassium chloride and oxygen gas

sub_topics.name: Single Replacement (Displacement) Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions where one element replaces another in a compound (A + BC → AC + B), dependent on the activity series.
example_tasks: Identify the single replacement reactions: (a) Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂, (b) 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂, (c) 2NaCl → 2Na + Cl₂
Predict whether a reaction will occur: (a) zinc metal in copper(II) sulfate solution, (b) copper metal in zinc sulfate solution. Use the activity series to explain
Write balanced equations for these single replacement reactions: (a) aluminum metal with copper(II) chloride solution, (b) chlorine gas with sodium bromide solution

sub_topics.name: Double Replacement (Metathesis) Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions where ions exchange partners (AB + CD → AD + CB), typically occurring in aqueous solution and often forming a precipitate, gas, or water.
example_tasks: Identify which are double replacement reactions: (a) AgNO₃ + NaCl → AgCl + NaNO₃, (b) Zn + CuSO₄ → ZnSO₄ + Cu, (c) HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O
Predict the products of these double replacement reactions and balance: (a) BaCl₂(aq) + Na₂SO₄(aq) →, (b) Pb(NO₃)₂(aq) + KI(aq) →
Write a balanced equation for the neutralization reaction between hydrochloric acid and calcium hydroxide. Identify this as a special type of double replacement reaction

sub_topics.name: Combustion Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions where a substance (usually organic) reacts rapidly with oxygen to produce oxides and energy, typically producing CO₂ and H₂O.
example_tasks: Write and balance the complete combustion reactions for: (a) methane (CH₄), (b) propane (C₃H₈), (c) ethanol (C₂H₅OH)
Explain the difference between complete combustion (sufficient oxygen) and incomplete combustion (insufficient oxygen) using methane as an example
Identify whether each reaction is combustion or another type: (a) C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O, (b) 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, (c) CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O

sub_topics.name: Predicting Reaction Products
sub_topics.short_description: Using patterns and rules to predict the products of chemical reactions based on reactants and reaction type, including solubility rules and activity series.

sub_topics.name: Activity Series for Predicting Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Using the activity series (ranking of metals by reactivity) to predict whether single replacement reactions will occur spontaneously.
example_tasks: Use an activity series to predict whether these reactions will occur: (a) Cu + ZnSO₄ →, (b) Mg + CuSO₄ →, (c) Ag + HCl →
Explain why magnesium can displace copper from copper(II) sulfate solution but copper cannot displace magnesium from magnesium sulfate solution
Rank the following metals in order of decreasing reactivity based on the activity series: zinc, copper, magnesium, and silver. Which metal can displace all the others from their compounds?

sub_topics.name: Solubility Rules for Predicting Precipitates
sub_topics.short_description: Using solubility rules to predict whether ionic compounds will dissolve in water or form precipitates in double replacement reactions.
example_tasks: Using solubility rules, predict whether a precipitate forms when solutions of the following are mixed: (a) NaCl and AgNO₃, (b) Na₂SO₄ and BaCl₂, (c) KNO₃ and NaCl
Write complete balanced equations for these double replacement reactions, including state symbols, and identify any precipitates: (a) Pb(NO₃)₂(aq) + 2KI(aq) →, (b) CaCl₂(aq) + Na₂CO₃(aq) →
Explain the general solubility rules for: (a) nitrates, (b) chlorides, (c) sulfates, (d) carbonates. Give examples of soluble and insoluble compounds for each

sub_topics.name: Predicting Products Based on Reaction Type
sub_topics.short_description: Using knowledge of reaction patterns to predict products when given reactants and reaction type, then balancing the resulting equation.
example_tasks: Predict the products and balance these equations: (a) synthesis: Li + O₂ →, (b) decomposition: H₂O₂ →, (c) single replacement: Al + CuCl₂ →
Complete and balance these combustion reactions: (a) C₄H₁₀ + O₂ →, (b) C₂H₅OH + O₂ →
Predict the products of these double replacement reactions and determine if a precipitate, gas, or water forms: (a) HCl + NaOH →, (b) Na₂CO₃ + HCl →, (c) NH₄Cl + NaOH →

sub_topics.name: Evidence of Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying observable signs that indicate a chemical reaction has occurred, distinguishing chemical changes from physical changes in laboratory and real-world contexts.

sub_topics.name: Observable Signs of Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing indicators such as color change, temperature change, gas production, precipitate formation, and light emission that signal chemical reactions.
example_tasks: List five observable signs that a chemical reaction has occurred and provide a specific example reaction for each sign
When baking soda (NaHCO₃) reacts with vinegar (acetic acid), bubbles form, the mixture feels cool, and the smell changes. Identify which of these are evidence of chemical change
Distinguish between physical and chemical changes in these scenarios: (a) ice melting, (b) iron rusting, (c) water boiling, (d) a match burning, (e) sugar dissolving in water

grade_9_10.name: Stoichiometry
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding quantitative relationships in chemistry, including the mole concept, molar mass calculations, percent composition, and using balanced equations to calculate amounts of reactants and products. Students learn to solve problems involving mass, moles, particles, and volume relationships.

sub_topics.name: The Mole Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the mole as the fundamental unit for counting particles in chemistry, equal to Avogadro's number (6.022 × 10²³) of particles.

sub_topics.name: Avogadro's Number and Counting Particles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that one mole of any substance contains 6.022 × 10²³ particles (atoms, molecules, or formula units), allowing chemists to count particles by weighing.
example_tasks: Explain what Avogadro's number represents and why it is useful in chemistry. How many atoms are in 1 mole of carbon?
Calculate the number of molecules in 2.5 moles of water (H₂O). Show your work using Avogadro's number
If a sample contains 1.204 × 10²⁴ atoms of copper, how many moles of copper are present? Explain your calculation

sub_topics.name: Converting Between Moles and Particles
sub_topics.short_description: Using Avogadro's number as a conversion factor to convert between number of moles and number of particles (atoms, molecules, or ions).
example_tasks: Convert 0.50 moles of sodium chloride (NaCl) to formula units. How many total ions (Na⁺ and Cl⁻) does this represent?
A sample contains 3.01 × 10²³ molecules of carbon dioxide. Convert this to moles of CO₂
Calculate how many atoms are in 0.25 moles of aluminum. Then calculate how many atoms are in 0.25 moles of aluminum oxide (Al₂O₃)

sub_topics.name: Molar Mass
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding molar mass as the mass of one mole of a substance, calculated by summing atomic masses from the periodic table, expressed in g/mol.
example_tasks: Calculate the molar mass of the following compounds: (a) H₂O, (b) NaCl, (c) Ca(OH)₂, (d) (NH₄)₂SO₄
The molar mass of glucose is 180.16 g/mol. If you have 360.32 g of glucose, how many moles do you have?
Explain why one mole of carbon dioxide (CO₂) has a greater mass than one mole of water (H₂O), even though both represent the same number of molecules

sub_topics.name: Converting Between Moles and Mass
sub_topics.short_description: Using molar mass as a conversion factor to convert between grams and moles of a substance.
example_tasks: Convert 50.0 g of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) to moles. (Molar mass of CaCO₃ = 100.09 g/mol)
How many grams are in 2.5 moles of sodium hydroxide (NaOH)? (Molar mass of NaOH = 40.00 g/mol)
A sample contains 0.75 moles of iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃). Calculate: (a) the mass of the sample, (b) the number of formula units, (c) the number of iron atoms

sub_topics.name: Percent Composition
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the percentage by mass of each element in a compound and using percent composition to determine or verify chemical formulas.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Percent Composition from Formula
sub_topics.short_description: Determining the mass percentage of each element in a compound by dividing the total mass of each element by the molar mass and multiplying by 100.
example_tasks: Calculate the percent composition by mass of each element in water (H₂O). Verify that the percentages add up to 100%
Determine the percent composition of sodium in sodium chloride (NaCl) and in sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃). Which compound has a higher percentage of sodium?
A compound has the formula C₆H₁₂O₆. Calculate the percent composition of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in this compound

sub_topics.name: Applications of Percent Composition
sub_topics.short_description: Using percent composition to compare compounds, verify purity, or identify unknown substances by comparing calculated and experimental values.
example_tasks: Two iron oxides exist: FeO (72.4% Fe) and Fe₂O₃ (69.9% Fe). Which oxide would be better as an iron ore for extracting iron? Explain your reasoning
A sample of a compound is analyzed and found to contain 40.0% carbon, 6.7% hydrogen, and 53.3% oxygen by mass. Could this be glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆)? Verify by calculation
Fertilizer labels show the percent nitrogen content. Calculate which compound provides more nitrogen per gram: urea (NH₂)₂CO or ammonium nitrate (NH₄NO₃)

sub_topics.name: Empirical and Molecular Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Determining empirical formulas (simplest whole number ratio) and molecular formulas (actual number of atoms) from percent composition or mass data.

sub_topics.name: Determining Empirical Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Converting percent composition or mass data to mole ratios, then simplifying to the smallest whole number ratio to find the empirical formula.
example_tasks: A compound contains 75.0% carbon and 25.0% hydrogen by mass. Determine the empirical formula of the compound
A sample is analyzed and found to contain 2.40 g of carbon and 0.80 g of hydrogen. Calculate the empirical formula
A compound is 52.2% carbon, 13.0% hydrogen, and 34.8% oxygen by mass. Determine its empirical formula through step-by-step calculation

sub_topics.name: Determining Molecular Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Using the empirical formula and molar mass to determine the actual molecular formula by finding the multiple of the empirical formula mass.
example_tasks: The empirical formula of a compound is CH₂ and its molar mass is 84 g/mol. Determine the molecular formula
A compound has an empirical formula of C₂H₅ and a molar mass of 58 g/mol. What is its molecular formula?
A compound's percent composition is 40.0% C, 6.7% H, and 53.3% O. If its molar mass is 180 g/mol, determine both the empirical formula and the molecular formula

sub_topics.name: Distinguishing Empirical and Molecular Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that empirical formulas show the simplest ratio while molecular formulas show actual numbers, and that some compounds have identical empirical and molecular formulas.
example_tasks: Identify whether each formula is empirical, molecular, or both: (a) CH, (b) C₂H₆, (c) H₂O, (d) C₆H₆, (e) CH₂O
Explain why glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆) and formaldehyde (CH₂O) have the same empirical formula but different molecular formulas
For the following molecular formulas, write the empirical formulas: (a) H₂O₂, (b) C₆H₁₂O₆, (c) N₂O₄, (d) C₈H₁₈

sub_topics.name: Stoichiometric Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using balanced chemical equations to calculate quantitative relationships between reactants and products, including mole-to-mole, mass-to-mass, and other conversions.

sub_topics.name: Mole Ratios from Balanced Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that coefficients in balanced equations represent mole ratios, which serve as conversion factors in stoichiometric calculations.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, write all possible mole ratios between the reactants and products
In the reaction N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃, how many moles of NH₃ can be produced from 6 moles of H₂? Show your calculation using the mole ratio
For the equation 4Fe + 3O₂ → 2Fe₂O₃, explain what the coefficients tell you about the relationship between iron and iron(III) oxide

sub_topics.name: Mole-to-Mole Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using mole ratios from balanced equations to convert between moles of one substance and moles of another substance in a reaction.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2Na + Cl₂ → 2NaCl, calculate how many moles of NaCl are produced from 0.50 moles of Na
In photosynthesis (6CO₂ + 6H₂O → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂), how many moles of oxygen are produced when 2.5 moles of glucose are formed?
For the combustion of propane (C₃H₈ + 5O₂ → 3CO₂ + 4H₂O), calculate: (a) moles of O₂ needed for 2 moles of C₃H₈, (b) moles of CO₂ produced from 10 moles of O₂

sub_topics.name: Mass-to-Mass Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Converting from mass of one substance to mass of another using the pathway: mass → moles → mole ratio → moles → mass.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO, calculate the mass of magnesium oxide produced from 24.0 g of magnesium (Mg). Show all conversion steps
How many grams of oxygen are needed to completely react with 50.0 g of hydrogen in the reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O?
In the reaction CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂, if 25.0 g of calcium carbonate decomposes, calculate: (a) mass of CaO produced, (b) mass of CO₂ released

sub_topics.name: Limiting Reactant
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying which reactant will be completely consumed first, thus limiting the amount of product that can form, while the other reactant is in excess.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, if you have 3 moles of H₂ and 3 moles of O₂, identify the limiting reactant and calculate how much product forms
In the reaction N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃, if you start with 2.0 moles of N₂ and 4.0 moles of H₂, determine: (a) the limiting reactant, (b) moles of NH₃ produced, (c) moles of excess reactant remaining
A reaction requires 2 moles of A for every 3 moles of B. If you have 10 moles of A and 12 moles of B, which is the limiting reactant? Show your reasoning

sub_topics.name: Percent Yield and Theoretical Yield
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding theoretical yield (maximum amount calculated from stoichiometry), actual yield (amount obtained in lab), and percent yield (efficiency of reaction).
example_tasks: Define theoretical yield, actual yield, and percent yield. If a reaction's theoretical yield is 50.0 g but only 42.0 g is obtained, calculate the percent yield
In a reaction, 25.0 g of product was predicted (theoretical yield) but only 18.5 g was obtained (actual yield). Calculate the percent yield and suggest two reasons why it might be less than 100%
A student performs a synthesis reaction and calculates that 15.0 g of product should form. If the percent yield is 85.0%, what mass of product did the student actually obtain?

sub_topics.name: Multi-Step Stoichiometry Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Combining limiting reactant, percent yield, and other concepts to solve complex stoichiometry problems requiring multiple conversion steps.
example_tasks: For the reaction 4Al + 3O₂ → 2Al₂O₃, if 54.0 g of Al reacts with 48.0 g of O₂ and the percent yield is 80.0%, calculate the actual mass of Al₂O₃ produced
Given 100.0 g of CaCO₃ that decomposes according to CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂, calculate: (a) theoretical yield of CaO, (b) if actual yield is 48.0 g, find percent yield, (c) mass of CO₂ actually produced
In the reaction 2C₈H₁₈ + 25O₂ → 16CO₂ + 18H₂O, if 50.0 g of octane (C₈H₁₈) burns with excess oxygen with 92% efficiency, calculate the actual mass of water produced

sub_topics.name: Gas Stoichiometry and Molar Volume
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of moles (Avogadro's Law), and using molar volume at STP for gas calculations.

sub_topics.name: Molar Volume at STP
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that one mole of any gas occupies 22.4 L at Standard Temperature and Pressure (STP: 0°C and 1 atm), allowing volume-to-mole conversions for gases.
example_tasks: Define STP (Standard Temperature and Pressure) and state the molar volume of a gas at STP. How many liters does 2.0 moles of oxygen gas occupy at STP?
Calculate the volume occupied by 16.0 g of methane gas (CH₄) at STP. Show your conversion from mass to moles to volume
A container holds 44.8 L of nitrogen gas at STP. Calculate: (a) the number of moles of N₂, (b) the mass of N₂, (c) the number of molecules

sub_topics.name: Volume-to-Volume Calculations for Gases
sub_topics.short_description: Using volume ratios (equal to mole ratios) for gases at the same temperature and pressure to perform stoichiometric calculations more simply.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(g), if 10.0 L of hydrogen reacts completely, what volume of oxygen is needed and what volume of water vapor is produced (all at the same T and P)?
In the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) → 2NH₃(g), calculate the volume of ammonia produced from 15.0 L of nitrogen gas (assuming all gases are at the same temperature and pressure)
Propane burns according to C₃H₈(g) + 5O₂(g) → 3CO₂(g) + 4H₂O(g). If 5.0 L of propane burns completely, calculate the volumes of oxygen consumed and carbon dioxide produced

sub_topics.name: Gas Stoichiometry with Mass Conversions
sub_topics.short_description: Combining gas volume calculations with mass and mole conversions to solve problems involving both gaseous and non-gaseous substances.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2KClO₃(s) → 2KCl(s) + 3O₂(g), calculate the volume of oxygen gas produced at STP from the decomposition of 49.0 g of potassium chlorate
How many grams of calcium carbonate must decompose to produce 5.60 L of carbon dioxide at STP? The equation is CaCO₃(s) → CaO(s) + CO₂(g)
Magnesium reacts with hydrochloric acid: Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) → MgCl₂(aq) + H₂(g). If 4.86 g of magnesium reacts completely, calculate the volume of hydrogen gas produced at STP

grade_9_10.name: States of Matter and Phase Changes
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding the three common states of matter (solid, liquid, gas) and their properties, the kinetic molecular theory, phase changes, and gas laws. Students learn how particles behave at the molecular level and how temperature and pressure affect matter.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Molecular Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the model that explains matter behavior based on particle motion, with assumptions about particle size, motion, energy, and collisions.

sub_topics.name: Postulates of Kinetic Molecular Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the key assumptions: particles are in constant random motion, particle collisions are elastic, average kinetic energy depends on temperature, and particle volumes are negligible.
example_tasks: List the five main postulates of the kinetic molecular theory and explain what each means in simple terms
Explain what 'elastic collisions' means in the context of KMT. What happens to the total kinetic energy of particles during collisions?
According to KMT, how does increasing temperature affect the motion of particles? How does this relate to the average kinetic energy?

sub_topics.name: Temperature and Average Kinetic Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles, with higher temperatures meaning faster average particle motion.
example_tasks: Explain the relationship between temperature and the average kinetic energy of particles. If temperature doubles, what happens to particle motion?
Two samples of gas are at different temperatures: 25°C and 100°C. Which sample has particles with higher average kinetic energy? Explain
Describe what happens to particle motion as a substance approaches absolute zero (0 K or -273°C). Why is absolute zero the lowest possible temperature?

sub_topics.name: KMT Explanation of States of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Using kinetic molecular theory to explain differences between solids, liquids, and gases in terms of particle arrangement, motion, and forces.
example_tasks: Use KMT to explain the differences between solids, liquids, and gases in terms of particle arrangement, particle motion, and intermolecular forces
Explain why gases are compressible but solids and liquids are not, using the kinetic molecular theory
Using KMT, explain why liquids have a definite volume but no definite shape, while gases have neither definite volume nor definite shape

sub_topics.name: Properties of Solids, Liquids, and Gases
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing and contrasting the macroscopic properties of the three states of matter including shape, volume, density, and compressibility.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Solids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that solids have definite shape and volume, with particles in fixed positions vibrating about their locations, forming crystalline or amorphous structures.
example_tasks: List four characteristic properties of solids and explain each property in terms of particle arrangement and motion
Compare crystalline solids (like table salt) with amorphous solids (like glass). How do their particle arrangements differ?
Explain why solids are generally more dense than liquids or gases (water being a notable exception). Use particle arrangement to support your answer

sub_topics.name: Properties of Liquids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that liquids have definite volume but take the shape of their container, with particles close together but able to move past each other.
example_tasks: Describe four properties of liquids, including shape, volume, density, and particle motion. How do these differ from solids and gases?
Explain why liquids can flow while solids cannot, using the kinetic molecular theory to describe particle behavior
Discuss three examples of liquid properties in everyday life: surface tension, viscosity, and capillary action. Relate each to intermolecular forces

sub_topics.name: Properties of Gases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that gases have no definite shape or volume, are highly compressible, and have particles in rapid random motion with large spaces between them.
example_tasks: List five characteristic properties of gases. For each property, explain how it relates to the particle nature of gases
Explain why gases are easily compressed while liquids and solids are not. Use a particle diagram to illustrate your answer
Describe the process of diffusion in gases. Why do different gases diffuse at different rates? Use ammonia (NH₃) and hydrogen chloride (HCl) as examples

sub_topics.name: Phase Changes and Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the six phase transitions between solid, liquid, and gas states, and the energy changes involved during these transitions (endothermic vs. exothermic).

sub_topics.name: Types of Phase Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the names and processes of the six phase changes: melting, freezing, vaporization, condensation, sublimation, and deposition.
example_tasks: Define and give an example of each phase change: melting, freezing, vaporization (evaporation and boiling), condensation, sublimation, and deposition
Draw a diagram showing the six phase changes between solid, liquid, and gas. Label each transition with its name and whether it requires or releases energy
Explain the difference between evaporation and boiling. Both are types of vaporization, but under what conditions does each occur?

sub_topics.name: Heating and Cooling Curves
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting graphs showing temperature changes as a substance is heated or cooled, including flat regions where phase changes occur at constant temperature.
example_tasks: Sketch a heating curve for water starting at -20°C (ice) and ending at 120°C (steam). Label the phase change plateaus (melting and boiling points) and explain why temperature remains constant during these phases
On a cooling curve, identify the regions where: (a) a gas is cooling, (b) condensation is occurring, (c) a liquid is cooling, (d) freezing is occurring, (e) a solid is cooling
Explain why the temperature remains constant during a phase change even though heat is being added or removed. Where is the energy going or coming from?

sub_topics.name: Endothermic and Exothermic Phase Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that phase changes requiring energy input (melting, vaporization, sublimation) are endothermic while those releasing energy (freezing, condensation, deposition) are exothermic.
example_tasks: Classify each phase change as endothermic or exothermic: melting, freezing, vaporization, condensation, sublimation, deposition. Explain your classifications
Explain why you feel cold when water evaporates from your skin. Is evaporation endothermic or exothermic from the perspective of your skin?
When steam condenses on your skin, it releases a large amount of energy and can cause burns. Explain this in terms of phase changes and energy transfer

sub_topics.name: Vapor Pressure and Boiling Point
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding vapor pressure as the pressure exerted by vapor in equilibrium with its liquid, and that boiling occurs when vapor pressure equals atmospheric pressure.
example_tasks: Define vapor pressure and explain how it relates to the volatility of a liquid. Which has higher vapor pressure at room temperature: water or alcohol?
Explain why water boils at 100°C at sea level (1 atm) but at lower temperatures on mountains. How does atmospheric pressure affect boiling point?
Using the concept of vapor pressure, explain why a liquid in a sealed container won't continue to evaporate indefinitely but reaches an equilibrium

sub_topics.name: Gas Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the mathematical relationships between pressure, volume, temperature, and amount of gas, including Boyle's Law, Charles's Law, Gay-Lussac's Law, Combined Gas Law, and Ideal Gas Law.

sub_topics.name: Boyle's Law (Pressure-Volume Relationship)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that pressure and volume are inversely proportional at constant temperature: P₁V₁ = P₂V₂.
example_tasks: State Boyle's Law and explain what it means in terms of the relationship between pressure and volume. What must be held constant?
A gas occupies 5.0 L at a pressure of 2.0 atm. If the pressure is increased to 4.0 atm at constant temperature, what is the new volume?
Using the kinetic molecular theory, explain why decreasing the volume of a gas container increases the pressure. What happens to particle collisions?

sub_topics.name: Charles's Law (Temperature-Volume Relationship)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that volume and absolute temperature are directly proportional at constant pressure: V₁/T₁ = V₂/T₂ (temperature must be in Kelvin).
example_tasks: State Charles's Law and explain the relationship between volume and temperature. Why must temperature be expressed in Kelvin for gas law calculations?
A balloon has a volume of 2.0 L at 27°C (300 K). If the temperature is increased to 127°C (400 K) at constant pressure, what is the new volume?
Convert the following temperatures to Kelvin: (a) 25°C, (b) 100°C, (c) -50°C, (d) 0°C. Explain why absolute zero (0 K) represents the lowest possible temperature

sub_topics.name: Gay-Lussac's Law (Pressure-Temperature Relationship)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that pressure and absolute temperature are directly proportional at constant volume: P₁/T₁ = P₂/T₂.
example_tasks: State Gay-Lussac's Law and describe the relationship between pressure and temperature. What is held constant in this relationship?
A sealed rigid container holds gas at 2.0 atm and 300 K. If the temperature is increased to 450 K, what is the new pressure?
Explain why aerosol cans warn against heating. Use Gay-Lussac's Law to explain what happens to pressure when temperature increases in a sealed container

sub_topics.name: Combined Gas Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the combination of Boyle's, Charles's, and Gay-Lussac's Laws: (P₁V₁)/T₁ = (P₂V₂)/T₂, used when all three variables change.
example_tasks: Write the combined gas law equation and identify which individual gas laws it combines. When would you use the combined gas law?
A gas has a volume of 3.0 L at 2.0 atm and 300 K. Calculate the volume when the pressure changes to 1.5 atm and temperature changes to 400 K
A balloon contains 5.0 L of helium at 25°C and 1.0 atm. If it rises to an altitude where the temperature is -20°C and pressure is 0.5 atm, what is the new volume?

sub_topics.name: Ideal Gas Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the equation PV = nRT that relates pressure, volume, temperature, and number of moles, where R is the ideal gas constant (0.0821 L·atm/mol·K).
example_tasks: State the ideal gas law equation and define each variable. What is the value and units of the gas constant R?
Calculate the volume occupied by 2.0 moles of nitrogen gas at 298 K and 1.5 atm using PV = nRT
A container holds 5.0 L of oxygen gas at 25°C and 2.0 atm. Calculate: (a) the number of moles of O₂, (b) the mass of O₂, (c) the number of molecules

sub_topics.name: Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the total pressure of a gas mixture equals the sum of the partial pressures of individual gases: Ptotal = P₁ + P₂ + P₃ + ...
example_tasks: State Dalton's Law of Partial Pressures. If a container holds nitrogen at 2.0 atm and oxygen at 1.5 atm, what is the total pressure?
A gas mixture contains 0.3 atm of helium, 0.5 atm of neon, and 0.7 atm of argon. Calculate the total pressure and the mole fraction of each gas
Explain how Dalton's Law applies to breathing. Air contains approximately 78% N₂ and 21% O₂ at 1.0 atm. Calculate the partial pressure of oxygen in air

sub_topics.name: Real Gases vs. Ideal Gases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the differences between ideal gas behavior (following PV = nRT perfectly) and real gas behavior, and conditions where deviations occur.

sub_topics.name: Ideal Gas Assumptions and Limitations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that ideal gases assume negligible particle volume and no intermolecular forces, which is only approximate for real gases under certain conditions.
example_tasks: List the assumptions made by the ideal gas law. Under what conditions (temperature and pressure) do real gases behave most like ideal gases?
Explain why real gases deviate from ideal behavior at high pressures and low temperatures. Which assumption of the ideal gas law breaks down?
Compare the behavior of helium and carbon dioxide at the same conditions. Which gas behaves more ideally? Explain in terms of intermolecular forces and molecular size

grade_9_10.name: Solutions and Mixtures
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding solutions as homogeneous mixtures, solubility principles, concentration units, and colligative properties. Students learn to prepare solutions, calculate concentrations, and understand factors affecting solubility.

sub_topics.name: Solutions Terminology and Types
sub_topics.short_description: Learning key terms including solute, solvent, solubility, saturated, unsaturated, and supersaturated solutions, and understanding different types of solutions.

sub_topics.name: Solute, Solvent, and Solution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a solution is a homogeneous mixture where the solute dissolves in the solvent, with the solvent typically being the component present in greater amount.
example_tasks: Define solute, solvent, and solution. In salt water, identify which is the solute and which is the solvent
Give three examples of solutions where: (a) a solid dissolves in a liquid, (b) a gas dissolves in a liquid, (c) a liquid dissolves in a liquid
Explain why air is considered a solution. What is the solvent and what are some solutes in air?

sub_topics.name: Aqueous Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding solutions where water is the solvent, represented by (aq) in chemical equations, and learning about hydration and dissociation.
example_tasks: Explain what the symbol (aq) means in a chemical equation. Write an equation showing sodium chloride dissolving in water
Describe what happens at the molecular level when an ionic compound like NaCl dissolves in water. What role do the polar water molecules play?
Compare what happens when sugar (C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁) and salt (NaCl) dissolve in water. Which substance dissociates into ions and which remains as molecules?

sub_topics.name: Saturated, Unsaturated, and Supersaturated Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding solution saturation: unsaturated (can dissolve more solute), saturated (maximum solute dissolved at equilibrium), and supersaturated (contains more solute than should dissolve).
example_tasks: Define and distinguish between unsaturated, saturated, and supersaturated solutions. Which type is in equilibrium?
At 25°C, the solubility of NaCl is 36 g per 100 mL of water. If 30 g of NaCl is dissolved in 100 mL of water at 25°C, is the solution saturated, unsaturated, or supersaturated?
Describe how to prepare a supersaturated solution of sodium acetate. What happens when a seed crystal is added to a supersaturated solution?

sub_topics.name: Solubility and Factors Affecting Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding solubility as the maximum amount of solute that can dissolve in a given amount of solvent, and how temperature, pressure, and molecular structure affect solubility.

sub_topics.name: Solubility and Solubility Curves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding solubility values (typically in g/100 mL) and interpreting solubility curves that show how solubility changes with temperature.
example_tasks: The solubility of KNO₃ is 32 g/100 mL at 20°C and 109 g/100 mL at 60°C. Calculate how much more KNO₃ can dissolve in 200 mL of water when temperature increases from 20°C to 60°C
Using a solubility curve, determine: (a) the solubility of KCl at 40°C, (b) whether 60 g of KCl in 100 mL of water at 40°C is saturated or unsaturated
Explain what happens when a saturated solution of NaNO₃ at 60°C is cooled to 20°C. What is this process called?

sub_topics.name: Effect of Temperature on Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for most solids, solubility increases with temperature, while for gases, solubility decreases with increasing temperature.
example_tasks: Explain why sugar dissolves faster in hot water than in cold water. Does the solubility of sugar increase or decrease with temperature?
Describe how the solubility of gases in liquids changes with temperature. Why do fish sometimes die in warm water during summer?
Contrast the effect of temperature on solid solubility versus gas solubility. Use the example of sugar (solid) and oxygen (gas) dissolving in water

sub_topics.name: Effect of Pressure on Gas Solubility (Henry's Law)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that gas solubility increases with pressure according to Henry's Law, while pressure has negligible effect on solid and liquid solubility.
example_tasks: State Henry's Law and explain why carbonated beverages are bottled under high pressure. What happens when you open the bottle?
Explain why deep-sea divers must ascend slowly to avoid 'the bends.' How does this relate to gas solubility and pressure?
Compare the effect of pressure on: (a) the solubility of oxygen gas in water, (b) the solubility of table salt in water. Which is affected by pressure changes?

sub_topics.name: Polarity and 'Like Dissolves Like'
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that polar solutes dissolve in polar solvents and nonpolar solutes dissolve in nonpolar solvents due to similar intermolecular forces.
example_tasks: Explain the principle 'like dissolves like.' Why does salt (ionic/polar) dissolve in water (polar) but not in oil (nonpolar)?
Predict which solvent (water or hexane) would better dissolve: (a) sugar (polar), (b) vegetable oil (nonpolar), (c) ethanol (polar). Explain each prediction
Iodine (I₂) is nonpolar. Predict whether it will dissolve better in water or in carbon tetrachloride (CCl₄, nonpolar). Explain your reasoning

sub_topics.name: Concentration Units
sub_topics.short_description: Learning various ways to express solution concentration including molarity, percent by mass, percent by volume, and parts per million, and converting between units.

sub_topics.name: Molarity (M)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding molarity as moles of solute per liter of solution (M = mol/L), the most common concentration unit in chemistry, and performing molarity calculations.
example_tasks: Define molarity and write its formula. Calculate the molarity of a solution made by dissolving 2.0 moles of NaCl in enough water to make 0.50 L of solution
How many grams of NaOH are needed to prepare 500 mL of a 0.20 M solution? (Molar mass of NaOH = 40.0 g/mol)
A solution contains 5.85 g of NaCl in 250 mL of solution. Calculate: (a) moles of NaCl, (b) molarity of the solution

sub_topics.name: Dilution Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using the dilution equation M₁V₁ = M₂V₂ to calculate concentrations and volumes when diluting solutions by adding solvent.
example_tasks: State the dilution equation M₁V₁ = M₂V₂ and explain what each variable represents. What stays constant during dilution?
Calculate the volume of 6.0 M HCl needed to prepare 500 mL of 0.50 M HCl solution
A chemist dilutes 25.0 mL of 3.0 M sulfuric acid to a final volume of 150.0 mL. Calculate the molarity of the diluted solution

sub_topics.name: Percent by Mass
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding percent composition as (mass of solute / mass of solution) × 100%, useful for solid-liquid and liquid-liquid mixtures.
example_tasks: Define percent by mass and write its formula. Calculate the percent by mass if 10.0 g of sugar is dissolved in 90.0 g of water
A solution is 15% sodium chloride by mass. How many grams of NaCl are in 200 g of this solution?
How many grams of water must be added to 20.0 g of salt to make a solution that is 5.0% salt by mass?

sub_topics.name: Percent by Volume
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding percent by volume as (volume of solute / volume of solution) × 100%, commonly used for liquid-liquid solutions like alcohol in water.
example_tasks: Define percent by volume. If 50 mL of ethanol is mixed with water to make 200 mL of solution, what is the percent by volume of ethanol?
A bottle of rubbing alcohol is labeled 70% isopropyl alcohol by volume. How many milliliters of isopropyl alcohol are in a 500 mL bottle?
Explain why percent by volume is more convenient than percent by mass for describing the concentration of alcohol in beverages

sub_topics.name: Parts Per Million (ppm)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding very dilute concentrations expressed as ppm (mg of solute per kg of solution), commonly used for pollutants or trace substances.
example_tasks: Define parts per million (ppm). Convert 5 ppm to percent by mass
A water sample contains 15 mg of lead in 1.0 kg of water. Express this concentration in parts per million (ppm)
The EPA maximum contaminant level for arsenic in drinking water is 10 ppb (parts per billion). Convert this to ppm. Which is more dilute: 10 ppm or 10 ppb?

sub_topics.name: Preparing Solutions in the Laboratory
sub_topics.short_description: Learning procedures for making solutions of specific concentrations by dissolving solids or diluting concentrated solutions, using proper laboratory techniques.

sub_topics.name: Preparing Solutions from Solid Solutes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the step-by-step process of weighing a solid, dissolving it, and diluting to final volume in a volumetric flask.
example_tasks: Describe the procedure for preparing 250 mL of 0.10 M NaCl solution starting with solid NaCl. Include the mass of NaCl needed and the equipment used
Explain why you should not fill a volumetric flask to the mark before adding the solute. What is the correct procedure?
Calculate the mass of CuSO₄·5H₂O (hydrate) needed to prepare 500 mL of 0.20 M CuSO₄ solution. Account for the water of hydration in the molar mass

sub_topics.name: Preparing Solutions by Dilution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how to prepare dilute solutions from concentrated stock solutions by calculating and measuring the required volume of stock solution.
example_tasks: Describe the procedure for preparing 100 mL of 0.50 M HCl from 6.0 M HCl stock solution. Include the volume of stock solution needed and safety considerations
Explain the proper order of operations when diluting concentrated acids: Should you add acid to water or water to acid? Why?
Calculate the volume of 12 M HCl needed to prepare 2.0 L of 0.50 M HCl solution. Describe the dilution procedure

sub_topics.name: Colligative Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding properties that depend on the number of solute particles rather than their identity, including vapor pressure lowering, boiling point elevation, freezing point depression, and osmotic pressure.

sub_topics.name: Vapor Pressure Lowering
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that adding a nonvolatile solute lowers the vapor pressure of the solvent because solute particles occupy surface area and reduce evaporation rate.
example_tasks: Explain why the vapor pressure of a solution is lower than the vapor pressure of the pure solvent. How do solute particles affect evaporation?
Predict which solution has lower vapor pressure: pure water or salt water. Explain your reasoning
If you add sugar to water, does the vapor pressure increase, decrease, or stay the same? Why doesn't it matter whether you add sugar or salt (assuming equal numbers of particles)?

sub_topics.name: Boiling Point Elevation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that dissolved solutes raise the boiling point of a solution, with the elevation proportional to the concentration of solute particles.
example_tasks: Explain why adding salt to water increases its boiling point. Why is this effect called a colligative property?
Predict which solution has the highest boiling point: pure water, 0.1 M glucose solution, or 0.1 M NaCl solution. Explain your reasoning considering ion dissociation
Describe a practical application of boiling point elevation, such as adding antifreeze to car radiators or salt to pasta water

sub_topics.name: Freezing Point Depression
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that dissolved solutes lower the freezing point of a solution, preventing crystal formation and making the solution freeze at lower temperatures.
example_tasks: Explain why ocean water freezes at a lower temperature than pure water. How does salt affect the freezing process?
Predict which solution has the lowest freezing point: pure water, 1.0 M glucose, or 1.0 M CaCl₂. Consider the number of particles each solute produces
Describe two practical applications of freezing point depression, such as road salt in winter or antifreeze in car engines

sub_topics.name: Applications of Colligative Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding real-world applications including road de-icing, antifreeze, food preservation, and determining molar mass.
example_tasks: Explain why salt is spread on icy roads in winter. Which colligative property is being applied?
Describe how osmosis (a colligative property) is used in dialysis for patients with kidney failure
Explain how colligative properties can be used to determine the molar mass of an unknown solute by measuring freezing point depression or boiling point elevation

grade_9_10.name: Acids, Bases, and pH
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding the properties and behavior of acids and bases, pH scale, neutralization reactions, and titrations. Students learn to identify acids and bases, calculate pH, and perform acid-base titrations in the laboratory.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Acids and Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the characteristic properties of acids and bases through observations and chemical tests, including their effects on indicators and reactivity patterns.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that acids taste sour, turn litmus red, conduct electricity in solution, react with metals to produce hydrogen gas, and neutralize bases.
example_tasks: List five characteristic properties of acids. For each property, provide a specific example using common acids like HCl or H₂SO₄
Explain why you should never taste chemicals in the laboratory, even though acids are described as having a sour taste. Name three common acids found in foods
Write a balanced equation showing zinc metal reacting with hydrochloric acid. What gas is produced and how can you test for it?

sub_topics.name: Properties of Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that bases taste bitter, feel slippery, turn litmus blue, conduct electricity in solution, and neutralize acids.
example_tasks: List five characteristic properties of bases. Explain why bases feel slippery on your skin (hint: they react with oils)
Compare and contrast the properties of acids and bases using a table or chart. Include effects on indicators, taste, and feel
Name three common bases found in household products, such as cleaning supplies or antacids, and explain their uses

sub_topics.name: Acid-Base Indicators
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that indicators are substances that change color depending on whether they are in acidic or basic solutions, with different indicators having different color changes.
example_tasks: Describe what an acid-base indicator is and how it works. What color is litmus paper in acidic solutions? In basic solutions?
Create a table showing the colors of three indicators (litmus, phenolphthalein, and bromothymol blue) in acidic, neutral, and basic solutions
Explain how red cabbage juice can be used as a natural pH indicator. What causes the different colors at different pH values?

sub_topics.name: Arrhenius Definition of Acids and Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Arrhenius theory that acids produce H⁺ ions (or H₃O⁺) in water and bases produce OH⁻ ions in water.

sub_topics.name: Arrhenius Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that Arrhenius acids are substances that increase the concentration of hydrogen ions (H⁺) or hydronium ions (H₃O⁺) when dissolved in water.
example_tasks: Define an Arrhenius acid. Write equations showing how HCl and HNO₃ produce H⁺ ions when dissolved in water
Explain the relationship between H⁺ and H₃O⁺ (hydronium ion). Why do chemists often use these interchangeably when discussing acids in water?
Write the equation showing sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) acting as an Arrhenius acid in water. How many H⁺ ions can one molecule of H₂SO₄ produce?

sub_topics.name: Arrhenius Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that Arrhenius bases are substances that increase the concentration of hydroxide ions (OH⁻) when dissolved in water.
example_tasks: Define an Arrhenius base. Write equations showing how NaOH and Ca(OH)₂ produce OH⁻ ions when dissolved in water
Explain why ammonia (NH₃) can act as a base even though it doesn't contain OH⁻ ions. Write the equation: NH₃ + H₂O ⇌ NH₄⁺ + OH⁻
Predict whether the following are Arrhenius acids, bases, or neither: HBr, KOH, NaCl, H₃PO₄, Mg(OH)₂

sub_topics.name: Strong vs. Weak Acids and Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between strong acids/bases that ionize completely and weak acids/bases that only partially ionize in solution.

sub_topics.name: Strong Acids and Strong Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that strong acids and bases ionize completely (nearly 100%) in water, including memorizing the common strong acids and bases.
example_tasks: Define what makes an acid or base 'strong.' List the six common strong acids: HCl, HBr, HI, HNO₃, H₂SO₄, and HClO₄
List the common strong bases: Group 1 hydroxides (LiOH, NaOH, KOH) and some Group 2 hydroxides (Ca(OH)₂, Sr(OH)₂, Ba(OH)₂)
Write the ionization equation for hydrochloric acid (HCl) in water. Why do we use a single arrow (→) instead of an equilibrium arrow (⇌) for strong acids?

sub_topics.name: Weak Acids and Weak Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that weak acids and bases only partially ionize in water, establishing an equilibrium between ionized and un-ionized forms.
example_tasks: Define what makes an acid or base 'weak.' Provide three examples of weak acids (such as acetic acid CH₃COOH, carbonic acid H₂CO₃, and hydrofluoric acid HF)
Write the equilibrium equation for acetic acid (CH₃COOH) ionizing in water. Why do we use an equilibrium arrow (⇌)?
Compare 0.1 M solutions of HCl (strong acid) and CH₃COOH (weak acid). Which solution has: (a) higher H⁺ concentration, (b) higher conductivity, (c) lower pH?

sub_topics.name: Degree of Ionization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the strength of an acid or base depends on the percentage of molecules that ionize, not the concentration of the solution.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between concentration and strength. Can you have a dilute solution of a strong acid? Can you have a concentrated solution of a weak acid?
A 0.1 M HCl solution is 100% ionized while a 0.1 M acetic acid solution is only about 1% ionized. Compare the pH of these two solutions and explain the difference
Sketch two beakers showing molecular representations of: (a) a strong acid in water (fully dissociated), (b) a weak acid in water (mostly un-dissociated). Show H⁺ ions and intact acid molecules

sub_topics.name: The pH Scale
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pH as a measure of hydrogen ion concentration on a logarithmic scale from 0-14, with pH < 7 being acidic, pH = 7 being neutral, and pH > 7 being basic.

sub_topics.name: Definition and Calculation of pH
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pH as the negative logarithm of hydrogen ion concentration: pH = -log[H⁺], allowing expression of very small concentrations as manageable numbers.
example_tasks: Define pH and explain what the pH scale measures. What does a pH of 3 tell you about the concentration of H⁺ ions compared to a pH of 5?
Calculate the pH of a solution with [H⁺] = 1 × 10⁻⁴ M. Is this solution acidic, basic, or neutral?
If a solution has [H⁺] = 1 × 10⁻⁹ M, calculate its pH. Classify the solution as acidic, basic, or neutral

sub_topics.name: Interpreting the pH Scale
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the pH scale is logarithmic, so each unit change represents a tenfold change in H⁺ concentration, and relating pH values to acid/base strength.
example_tasks: Explain what it means that the pH scale is logarithmic. How many times more acidic is a solution with pH 2 compared to pH 4?
Arrange the following in order of increasing acidity: pH 10, pH 3, pH 7, pH 1, pH 12. Which is the most basic?
The pH of stomach acid is approximately 2, while the pH of blood is approximately 7.4. Calculate how many times more acidic stomach acid is compared to blood

sub_topics.name: pH, pOH, and the Relationship pH + pOH = 14
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that pOH measures hydroxide ion concentration and that pH and pOH are related through the equation pH + pOH = 14 at 25°C.
example_tasks: Define pOH and write the equation relating pH and pOH. If a solution has pH = 9, what is its pOH?
Calculate the pOH of a solution with [OH⁻] = 1 × 10⁻³ M. Then determine the pH of this solution
A solution has a pOH of 11. Calculate: (a) the pH, (b) [OH⁻], (c) [H⁺]. Is this solution acidic or basic?

sub_topics.name: Measuring pH
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding methods for measuring pH including indicators (color changes), pH paper, and pH meters (electronic measurement).
example_tasks: Compare three methods for measuring pH: indicators, pH paper, and pH meters. What are the advantages and disadvantages of each method?
A student uses pH paper to test a solution and observes a red color, indicating pH ≈ 3. What can you conclude about the solution?
Explain why a pH meter provides more accurate pH measurements than pH paper or indicators. In what situations would you choose each method?

sub_topics.name: Neutralization Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that acids and bases react to form salt and water, with H⁺ ions combining with OH⁻ ions in a neutralization reaction.

sub_topics.name: Acid-Base Neutralization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the general pattern of neutralization: acid + base → salt + water, and writing complete and net ionic equations for neutralization.
example_tasks: Write the general equation for a neutralization reaction. What two products are always formed?
Write balanced equations for the neutralization of: (a) HCl with NaOH, (b) H₂SO₄ with KOH, (c) HNO₃ with Ca(OH)₂
Write the net ionic equation for the neutralization of any strong acid with any strong base. Why is this equation the same regardless of which specific acid and base are used?

sub_topics.name: Salts from Neutralization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that salts are ionic compounds formed from the cation of a base and the anion of an acid during neutralization reactions.
example_tasks: Define a salt in the context of acid-base chemistry. Give three examples of salts and identify which acid and base would react to form each
Predict the salt formed when the following acids and bases react: (a) HCl + NaOH, (b) H₂SO₄ + Ca(OH)₂, (c) HNO₃ + KOH
Explain why not all salts are neutral. Research one example of an acidic salt and one example of a basic salt

sub_topics.name: Applications of Neutralization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding practical uses of neutralization including antacids for stomach acid, treating acidic soil, and neutralizing chemical spills.
example_tasks: Explain how antacids work to relieve heartburn. What neutralization reaction occurs when calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) reacts with stomach acid (HCl)?
Describe how farmers use lime (CaO or Ca(OH)₂) to neutralize acidic soil. Write a neutralization equation showing this process
When a base spill occurs in a laboratory, a weak acid like vinegar can be used to neutralize it. Explain why this is safer than using a strong acid

sub_topics.name: Acid-Base Titrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the laboratory technique of titration to determine the concentration of an acid or base by reacting it with a solution of known concentration.

sub_topics.name: Titration Procedure and Equipment
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the step-by-step process of titration using a burette to add titrant to analyte until reaching the equivalence point, indicated by color change.
example_tasks: Describe the procedure for performing an acid-base titration. What equipment is needed and what is the role of each piece?
Define the following terms: titrant, analyte, equivalence point, endpoint, and indicator. How does the endpoint differ from the equivalence point?
Explain why a burette is used to add the titrant rather than a graduated cylinder. What advantage does a burette provide?

sub_topics.name: Titration Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using the relationship MₐVₐ = MᵦVᵦ (for monoprotic acids and bases) or considering mole ratios to calculate unknown concentrations from titration data.
example_tasks: In a titration, 25.0 mL of HCl solution requires 32.5 mL of 0.10 M NaOH to reach the equivalence point. Calculate the molarity of the HCl solution
A student titrates 20.0 mL of H₂SO₄ with 0.15 M NaOH and finds that 40.0 mL of NaOH is required. Calculate the molarity of the H₂SO₄. (Note: H₂SO₄ is diprotic)
Explain why you must consider the mole ratio from the balanced equation when performing titration calculations. Give an example where the acid-to-base ratio is not 1:1

sub_topics.name: Choosing Indicators for Titrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that different indicators have different pH ranges for color changes, and selecting appropriate indicators based on the expected pH at equivalence point.
example_tasks: Explain why phenolphthalein (pH range 8.3-10) is suitable for titrating a strong acid with a strong base, but not for titrating a weak acid with a strong base
Describe what happens to the pH during the titration of a strong acid with a strong base. Sketch a titration curve showing pH vs. volume of base added
List three common indicators used in titrations along with their pH ranges and color changes: phenolphthalein, methyl orange, and bromothymol blue

grade_9_10.name: Introduction to Thermochemistry
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding energy changes in chemical reactions, including exothermic and endothermic processes, enthalpy, calorimetry, and Hess's Law. Students learn to measure and calculate heat changes associated with chemical and physical processes.

sub_topics.name: Energy in Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chemical reactions involve breaking bonds (requiring energy) and forming bonds (releasing energy), with net energy change determining if reaction is exothermic or endothermic.

sub_topics.name: Bond Energy and Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that energy is required to break bonds and energy is released when bonds form, with the difference determining the overall energy change of a reaction.
example_tasks: Explain why breaking chemical bonds requires energy while forming chemical bonds releases energy. Use the example of H₂ + Cl₂ → 2HCl

In a reaction, 500 kJ is required to break bonds in the reactants and 600 kJ is released when forming bonds in the products. Is this reaction exothermic or endothermic? Calculate the net energy change
Describe what happens to chemical potential energy during an exothermic reaction. Do the products have more or less potential energy than the reactants?

sub_topics.name: Exothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions that release energy to the surroundings, usually as heat, with products having lower energy than reactants (ΔH negative).
example_tasks: Define exothermic reaction and provide three examples, such as combustion, neutralization, and freezing of water
Draw an energy diagram for an exothermic reaction, labeling reactants, products, activation energy, and the energy released (ΔH). Why is ΔH negative?
Explain why exothermic reactions often feel hot to the touch. Where does the heat energy come from?

sub_topics.name: Endothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions that absorb energy from the surroundings, with products having higher energy than reactants (ΔH positive).
example_tasks: Define endothermic reaction and provide three examples, such as photosynthesis, melting of ice, and dissolving ammonium nitrate in water
Draw an energy diagram for an endothermic reaction, labeling reactants, products, activation energy, and the energy absorbed (ΔH). Why is ΔH positive?
Explain why endothermic reactions often feel cold to the touch, such as when instant cold packs are activated. Where does the absorbed energy come from?

sub_topics.name: Activation Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that all reactions require a minimum amount of energy to get started, called activation energy, representing the energy barrier between reactants and products.
example_tasks: Define activation energy and explain why even exothermic reactions need activation energy to begin. Use the example of burning wood
Compare the activation energies of a fast reaction and a slow reaction. Which has the higher activation energy barrier?
On an energy diagram, label the activation energy for both the forward and reverse reactions. How do these activation energies compare for exothermic vs. endothermic reactions?

sub_topics.name: Enthalpy (H) and Enthalpy Change (ΔH)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding enthalpy as the heat content of a system at constant pressure, with enthalpy change (ΔH) representing the heat absorbed or released during a reaction.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Enthalpy and ΔH
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that enthalpy (H) represents the total heat content and ΔH = Hproducts - Hreactants indicates whether energy is released (negative) or absorbed (positive).
example_tasks: Define enthalpy (H) and enthalpy change (ΔH). What are the units typically used for enthalpy change?
If ΔH for a reaction is -250 kJ, is the reaction exothermic or endothermic? What does the negative sign indicate?
Calculate ΔH for a reaction where the products have an enthalpy of 150 kJ and the reactants have an enthalpy of 200 kJ. Is the reaction exothermic or endothermic?

sub_topics.name: Standard Enthalpy of Formation (ΔH°f)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding standard enthalpy of formation as the heat change when one mole of a compound forms from its elements in their standard states at 25°C and 1 atm.
example_tasks: Define standard enthalpy of formation (ΔH°f). What is the standard enthalpy of formation for any element in its standard state?
Explain what the ° symbol means in ΔH°f. What are the standard conditions for thermochemical measurements?
Given that ΔH°f of H₂O(l) is -286 kJ/mol, write the formation equation for water and explain what this value represents

sub_topics.name: Thermochemical Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding chemical equations that include enthalpy changes, showing the amount of heat released or absorbed with specific amounts of reactants and products.
example_tasks: Write the thermochemical equation for the combustion of methane: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l), ΔH = -890 kJ. What does the -890 kJ represent?
If the thermochemical equation for the formation of ammonia is N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) → 2NH₃(g), ΔH = -92 kJ, calculate ΔH for the formation of 4 moles of NH₃
Explain how to reverse a thermochemical equation. If a forward reaction has ΔH = -200 kJ, what is ΔH for the reverse reaction?

sub_topics.name: Calorimetry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the experimental technique of measuring heat changes in chemical reactions or physical processes using a calorimeter and the equation q = mcΔT.

sub_topics.name: Specific Heat Capacity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding specific heat as the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 gram of a substance by 1°C, with different substances having different specific heats.
example_tasks: Define specific heat capacity and state its units (J/g·°C). What is the specific heat capacity of water (4.18 J/g·°C)?
Calculate the heat required to raise the temperature of 100 g of water from 20°C to 50°C using q = mcΔT
Explain why water has a high specific heat capacity and why this property is important for regulating Earth's climate and in living organisms

sub_topics.name: Heat Calculations Using q = mcΔT
sub_topics.short_description: Using the equation q = mcΔT to calculate heat absorbed or released, where q is heat, m is mass, c is specific heat capacity, and ΔT is temperature change.
example_tasks: A 50.0 g sample of copper (specific heat = 0.385 J/g·°C) is heated from 25°C to 75°C. Calculate the heat absorbed using q = mcΔT
When 200 g of water cools from 80°C to 20°C, calculate the heat released. (c for water = 4.18 J/g·°C)
A metal sample with mass 25.0 g releases 1500 J of heat as it cools from 150°C to 50°C. Calculate the specific heat capacity of the metal

sub_topics.name: Calorimeter Experiments
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how calorimeters measure heat changes by assuming heat lost by one substance equals heat gained by another (assuming no heat loss to surroundings).
example_tasks: Describe the structure and function of a simple coffee cup calorimeter. Why is it insulated and covered?
In a calorimetry experiment, 50.0 g of hot metal at 100°C is placed in 100 g of water at 20°C. The final temperature is 25°C. Use q(metal) = -q(water) to find the specific heat of the metal
A student burns a sample of food and uses the heat released to warm 500 g of water from 20°C to 35°C. Calculate the energy content of the food sample in kJ

sub_topics.name: Hess's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the total enthalpy change for a reaction is independent of the pathway taken, allowing calculation of ΔH by combining multiple reactions.

sub_topics.name: Principle of Hess's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that enthalpy is a state function, meaning ΔH depends only on initial and final states, not on the pathway or intermediate steps taken.
example_tasks: State Hess's Law in your own words. Why is it useful for calculating enthalpy changes that are difficult to measure directly?
Explain what it means that enthalpy is a 'state function.' Give an analogy using elevation change when climbing a mountain
If a reaction can proceed by two different pathways with different numbers of steps, what does Hess's Law tell you about the total ΔH for each pathway?

sub_topics.name: Applying Hess's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Using Hess's Law to calculate unknown enthalpy changes by manipulating and combining equations with known ΔH values, including reversing and multiplying equations.
example_tasks: Given: (1) C(s) + O₂(g) → CO₂(g), ΔH = -394 kJ and (2) CO(g) + ½O₂(g) → CO₂(g), ΔH = -283 kJ. Calculate ΔH for: C(s) + ½O₂(g) → CO(g)
Explain the rules for manipulating thermochemical equations when using Hess's Law: What happens to ΔH when you reverse an equation? When you multiply an equation by a coefficient?
Use the following equations to calculate ΔH for the target reaction: Given: (1) 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(l), ΔH = -572 kJ and (2) H₂O(l) → H₂O(g), ΔH = +44 kJ. Find ΔH for: 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(g)

grade_9_10.name: Nuclear Chemistry
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding radioactivity, nuclear reactions, half-life, and applications of nuclear chemistry in medicine, energy, and dating. Students learn about nuclear stability, types of radiation, and the differences between nuclear and chemical reactions.

sub_topics.name: Nuclear vs. Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding fundamental differences between reactions involving electron rearrangement (chemical) and reactions involving changes in the nucleus (nuclear).

sub_topics.name: Key Differences
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing nuclear and chemical reactions in terms of what changes, energy involved, rates, and effects of temperature and pressure.
example_tasks: Create a comparison table showing the differences between chemical and nuclear reactions, including: what particles are involved, magnitude of energy changes, and what factors affect reaction rates
Explain why nuclear reactions release millions of times more energy than chemical reactions. Which involves changes in the nucleus?
Describe why temperature and pressure affect chemical reaction rates but not nuclear decay rates. What does this tell you about the location of the changes?

sub_topics.name: Radioactivity and Types of Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding radioactivity as the spontaneous emission of particles and energy from unstable nuclei, including alpha, beta, and gamma radiation.

sub_topics.name: Alpha (α) Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alpha particles as helium nuclei (₂⁴He) with low penetrating power but high ionizing ability, stopped by paper or skin.
example_tasks: Describe alpha radiation in terms of: (a) composition (what is an alpha particle?), (b) symbol (₂⁴He or ₂⁴α), (c) penetrating power, (d) charge
Write the nuclear equation for uranium-238 undergoing alpha decay: ²³⁸₉₂U → ? + ₂⁴He. What element is formed?
Explain why alpha radiation is dangerous if ingested or inhaled but can be stopped by a sheet of paper. What does this tell you about its ionizing power?

sub_topics.name: Beta (β) Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding beta particles as high-speed electrons (₋₁⁰e) emitted when a neutron converts to a proton, with moderate penetrating power, stopped by aluminum.
example_tasks: Describe beta radiation in terms of: (a) composition, (b) symbol (₋₁⁰e or ₋₁⁰β), (c) penetrating power, (d) charge
Write the nuclear equation for carbon-14 undergoing beta decay: ¹⁴₆C → ? + ₋₁⁰e. What element is formed? What happens to the atomic number?
Explain what happens inside the nucleus during beta decay. How does a neutron transform, and why does this change the element?

sub_topics.name: Gamma (γ) Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding gamma rays as high-energy electromagnetic radiation with no mass or charge, highest penetrating power, requiring lead or thick concrete shielding.
example_tasks: Describe gamma radiation in terms of: (a) composition (electromagnetic radiation), (b) symbol (₀⁰γ), (c) penetrating power, (d) charge
Explain why gamma radiation often accompanies alpha or beta decay. Does gamma emission change the atomic number or mass number?
Compare the penetrating power of alpha, beta, and gamma radiation. What materials are needed to shield against each type?

sub_topics.name: Positron Emission and Electron Capture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding other types of nuclear decay including positron emission (₁⁰e) and electron capture, both decreasing atomic number by one.
example_tasks: Describe positron emission. How does it differ from beta decay? Write the equation for carbon-11 undergoing positron emission: ¹¹₆C → ? + ₁⁰e
Explain what happens during electron capture. How does the atomic number change?
Compare the four types of decay (alpha, beta, positron, electron capture) in terms of how they change atomic number and mass number

sub_topics.name: Writing and Balancing Nuclear Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to write balanced nuclear equations where both mass number (top) and atomic number (bottom) are conserved on both sides of the equation.

sub_topics.name: Balancing Nuclear Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that in nuclear equations, the sum of mass numbers and the sum of atomic numbers must be equal on both sides.
example_tasks: Balance the following nuclear equation by identifying the missing particle: ²³⁸₉₂U → ²³⁴₉₀Th + ?
Complete and balance these nuclear equations: (a) ¹⁴₆C → ? + ₋₁⁰e, (b) ²²⁶₈₈Ra → ? + ₂⁴He, (c) ¹³₇N → ¹³₆C + ?
Write the nuclear equation for polonium-210 (²¹⁰₈₄Po) undergoing alpha decay. Show all mass numbers and atomic numbers

sub_topics.name: Half-Life and Radioactive Decay
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding half-life as the time required for half of a radioactive sample to decay, and using half-life to calculate remaining amounts over time.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Half-Life
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that half-life is constant for each isotope and independent of initial amount, temperature, or pressure, representing exponential decay.
example_tasks: Define half-life. If a sample contains 100 g of a radioactive isotope with a half-life of 10 years, how much remains after: (a) 10 years, (b) 20 years, (c) 30 years?
Explain why after one half-life, 50% of the original sample remains, but after two half-lives, 25% remains, not 0%. Draw a decay curve showing this pattern
A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 5 days. If you start with 80 g, calculate the mass remaining after: (a) 5 days, (b) 15 days, (c) 25 days

sub_topics.name: Half-Life Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using the equation N = N₀(½)ⁿ where n is the number of half-lives elapsed, to calculate remaining amount or elapsed time.
example_tasks: The half-life of iodine-131 is 8 days. If you start with 40 mg, how much remains after 24 days? Show your calculation including the number of half-lives
A 200 g sample of a radioactive isotope decays to 25 g. If the half-life is 6 hours, how much time has elapsed?
After 30 years, 12.5% of an original sample of a radioactive isotope remains. Calculate the half-life of the isotope

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Stability
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors that determine nuclear stability, including neutron-to-proton ratio, magic numbers, and the belt of stability.

sub_topics.name: Stable vs. Unstable Nuclei
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that stable nuclei have appropriate neutron-to-proton ratios, while unstable nuclei undergo radioactive decay to achieve stability.
example_tasks: Explain why small atoms (Z < 20) tend to be stable when they have approximately equal numbers of protons and neutrons, while larger atoms need more neutrons than protons
Predict whether an isotope is likely to be stable or unstable: (a) carbon-12 (6p, 6n), (b) carbon-14 (6p, 8n), (c) uranium-238 (92p, 146n)
Describe the 'belt of stability' on a graph of neutrons vs. protons. What happens to nuclei above the belt? Below the belt?

sub_topics.name: Applications of Nuclear Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding practical applications including medical treatments and diagnosis, radiocarbon dating, nuclear energy, and industrial uses.

sub_topics.name: Medical Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding uses of radioactive isotopes in medicine including diagnostic imaging (PET scans, X-rays) and cancer treatment (radiation therapy).
example_tasks: Explain how radioactive tracers like technetium-99m are used in medical imaging. Why are short half-lives preferred for diagnostic applications?
Describe how radiation therapy uses gamma rays or other radiation to treat cancer. Why does it affect cancer cells more than healthy cells?
Research PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans. What type of radioactive decay is used, and what information do PET scans provide?

sub_topics.name: Radiocarbon Dating
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how carbon-14 dating uses the known half-life of C-14 (5,730 years) to determine the age of organic materials up to about 50,000 years old.
example_tasks: Explain the principle behind radiocarbon dating. Why does the ratio of C-14 to C-12 in living organisms remain constant, but change after death?
A sample of wood from an ancient tomb contains 25% of the C-14 it had when the tree was alive. If the half-life of C-14 is 5,730 years, estimate the age of the sample
Explain why radiocarbon dating is only useful for organic materials and for samples less than about 50,000 years old

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Fission and Fusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding nuclear fission (splitting heavy nuclei) used in nuclear power plants and weapons, and nuclear fusion (combining light nuclei) occurring in stars.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion. Which process releases energy in nuclear power plants? In the sun?
Describe the process of nuclear fission of uranium-235. What products are formed and why does this reaction release enormous amounts of energy?
Explain why nuclear fusion requires extremely high temperatures and pressures. Why is fusion considered a cleaner energy source than fission?

grade_9_10.name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
grade_9_10.short_description: Understanding the chemistry of carbon compounds, including hydrocarbons, functional groups, isomers, and basic nomenclature. Students learn why carbon forms so many compounds and recognize common organic molecules in everyday life.

sub_topics.name: Carbon and Organic Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the unique properties of carbon that allow it to form millions of compounds, including its ability to form four bonds and chain/ring structures.

sub_topics.name: Why Carbon is Unique
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that carbon can form four covalent bonds, bond to other carbon atoms in chains and rings, and form single, double, or triple bonds.
example_tasks: Explain why carbon can form so many different compounds. How does carbon's position in the periodic table (Group 14) relate to its bonding capacity?
Describe three unique properties of carbon that make it the basis of organic chemistry: (a) four valence electrons, (b) ability to catenate (form chains), (c) ability to form multiple bonds
Draw the Lewis structure of methane (CH₄) showing all four C-H bonds. Explain why carbon forms four bonds rather than two or three

sub_topics.name: Organic vs. Inorganic Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that organic compounds contain carbon-hydrogen bonds (with few exceptions like CO₂), while inorganic compounds generally don't.
example_tasks: Define organic chemistry and give five examples of organic compounds found in everyday life (food, fuels, medicines, plastics)
Classify each compound as organic or inorganic: CH₄, NaCl, C₆H₁₂O₆, CO₂, H₂O, C₂H₅OH, CaCO₃
Explain why carbon dioxide (CO₂) and carbonates (like CaCO₃) are considered inorganic even though they contain carbon

sub_topics.name: Hydrocarbons
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding organic compounds containing only carbon and hydrogen, classified as alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes based on bond types.

sub_topics.name: Alkanes (Saturated Hydrocarbons)
