sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alkanes as hydrocarbons with only single bonds (CₙH₂ₙ₊₂), also called saturated hydrocarbons, including straight-chain and branched isomers.
example_tasks: Define alkanes and explain why they are called 'saturated' hydrocarbons. What is the general formula for alkanes?
Draw the structural formulas for the first four alkanes: methane (CH₄), ethane (C₂H₆), propane (C₃H₈), and butane (C₄H₁₀)
Name the following alkanes and identify each as straight-chain or branched: (a) CH₃CH₂CH₂CH₃, (b) CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₃

sub_topics.name: Alkenes (Unsaturated Hydrocarbons with Double Bonds)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alkenes as hydrocarbons containing at least one carbon-carbon double bond (C=C) with general formula CₙH₂ₙ.
example_tasks: Define alkenes and explain why they are called 'unsaturated' hydrocarbons. What is the general formula for alkenes?
Draw the structural formulas for ethene (C₂H₄) and propene (C₃H₆), showing the double bond clearly
Explain why alkenes are more reactive than alkanes. What role does the double bond play in their reactivity?

sub_topics.name: Alkynes (Unsaturated Hydrocarbons with Triple Bonds)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alkynes as hydrocarbons containing at least one carbon-carbon triple bond (C≡C) with general formula CₙH₂ₙ₋₂.
example_tasks: Define alkynes and give their general formula. How do alkynes differ from alkenes?
Draw the structural formula for ethyne (acetylene, C₂H₂), the simplest alkyne, showing the triple bond
Compare the formulas and structures of ethane (C₂H₆), ethene (C₂H₄), and ethyne (C₂H₂). Explain the relationship between the number of hydrogen atoms and bond type

sub_topics.name: Physical and Chemical Properties of Hydrocarbons
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding trends in boiling point, solubility, and reactivity of hydrocarbons, and their uses as fuels.
example_tasks: Explain how boiling point changes as the carbon chain length increases in alkanes. Why does octane (C₈H₁₈) have a higher boiling point than methane (CH₄)?
Describe the solubility of hydrocarbons in water and in nonpolar solvents. Explain using the concept of 'like dissolves like'
Write the balanced equation for the complete combustion of propane (C₃H₈). Why are hydrocarbons commonly used as fuels?

sub_topics.name: Functional Groups
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding functional groups as specific atom arrangements that determine the properties and reactions of organic compounds, including alcohols, carboxylic acids, and others.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Functional Groups
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that functional groups are reactive sites that give organic molecules their characteristic properties and reactions.
example_tasks: Define functional group and explain why they are important in organic chemistry. How do functional groups affect the properties of molecules?
Identify the functional group in each molecule: (a) ethanol (CH₃CH₂OH), (b) acetic acid (CH₃COOH), (c) acetone (CH₃COCH₃)
Explain why compounds with the same functional group tend to have similar chemical properties, even if their carbon chains differ in length

sub_topics.name: Alcohols (-OH)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alcohols as organic compounds containing the hydroxyl (-OH) functional group, with properties like hydrogen bonding and use as solvents.
example_tasks: Define alcohols and identify the functional group. Draw the structures of methanol (CH₃OH) and ethanol (C₂H₅OH)
Explain why alcohols have higher boiling points than alkanes of similar molecular mass. What role does the -OH group play?
Name three uses of alcohols in everyday life, such as hand sanitizer (ethanol), antifreeze (ethylene glycol), or rubbing alcohol (isopropanol)

sub_topics.name: Carboxylic Acids (-COOH)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding carboxylic acids as organic acids containing the carboxyl group (-COOH), including examples like acetic acid and citric acid.
example_tasks: Define carboxylic acids and identify the functional group. Draw the structure of acetic acid (CH₃COOH) found in vinegar
Explain why carboxylic acids are acidic. What ion is released when a carboxylic acid dissolves in water?
Give three examples of carboxylic acids and their sources: acetic acid (vinegar), citric acid (citrus fruits), and formic acid (ant stings)

sub_topics.name: Other Common Functional Groups
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing other important functional groups including aldehydes, ketones, esters, ethers, and amines, with simple examples.
example_tasks: Create a table showing five functional groups (alcohol, aldehyde, ketone, carboxylic acid, ester) with their structures and general formulas
Identify the functional group in each compound: (a) formaldehyde (methanal, HCHO), (b) acetone (propanone, CH₃COCH₃), (c) methyl acetate (CH₃COOCH₃)
Research and describe one important organic compound for each functional group, including its name, structure, and use in everyday life or industry

sub_topics.name: Isomers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that isomers are compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural arrangements, resulting in different properties.

sub_topics.name: Structural (Constitutional) Isomers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding isomers that have different connectivity of atoms, such as straight-chain vs. branched alkanes with the same molecular formula.
example_tasks: Define structural isomers. Draw the two structural isomers of C₄H₁₀ (butane and isobutane/methylpropane)
Explain how butane and isobutane can have the same molecular formula but different properties, such as boiling points
Draw all the structural isomers of C₅H₁₂ (there are three). Name each isomer

sub_topics.name: Simple Organic Nomenclature
sub_topics.short_description: Learning basic IUPAC naming rules for simple organic compounds including alkanes, alkenes, and compounds with common functional groups.

sub_topics.name: Naming Alkanes
sub_topics.short_description: Learning prefixes (meth-, eth-, prop-, but-, pent-, hex-) and rules for naming straight-chain and branched alkanes.
example_tasks: Name the following alkanes: CH₄, C₂H₆, C₃H₈, C₄H₁₀, C₅H₁₂, C₆H₁₄. What prefixes indicate the number of carbons?
Draw the structure of hexane (C₆H₁₄) and explain how the name is derived from the number of carbon atoms
Name the branched alkane: CH₃CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃ (2-methylbutane). Identify the main chain and the branch

sub_topics.name: Naming Compounds with Functional Groups
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to name simple alcohols, carboxylic acids, and other compounds by combining the alkane name with the functional group suffix.
example_tasks: Name the following alcohols by changing the -ane ending to -anol: CH₃OH (methanol), C₂H₅OH (ethanol), C₃H₇OH (propanol)
Name the following carboxylic acids using the -anoic acid ending: HCOOH (methanoic acid/formic acid), CH₃COOH (ethanoic acid/acetic acid)
Draw the structure for propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol. Explain how the number indicates the position of the -OH group

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Atomic Structure
grade_11_12.short_description: Deepening understanding of quantum mechanics, atomic spectra, electron configuration exceptions, and modern atomic theory. Students explore wave-particle duality, quantum numbers, and the mathematical basis of electron behavior.

sub_topics.name: Foundations of Quantum Mechanics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the wave-particle duality of matter and light, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, and the probabilistic nature of electron location.

sub_topics.name: Wave-Particle Duality
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that electrons and other particles exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties, as demonstrated by de Broglie's equation and electron diffraction.
example_tasks: Explain what wave-particle duality means. Provide evidence for both the wave nature and particle nature of electrons
Describe the double-slit experiment with electrons. How does this experiment demonstrate wave-particle duality?
Use de Broglie's relationship (λ = h/mv) to explain why wave properties are observable for electrons but not for macroscopic objects like baseballs

sub_topics.name: Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that it is impossible to simultaneously know both the exact position and exact momentum of an electron, leading to probability-based descriptions.
example_tasks: State the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle and explain what it means for our ability to describe electron behavior in atoms
Explain why we describe electron positions using orbitals (probability regions) rather than fixed orbits. How does the uncertainty principle relate to this?
Compare Bohr's model (electrons in fixed orbits) with the quantum mechanical model (electrons in probability clouds) in light of the uncertainty principle

sub_topics.name: Schrödinger Equation and Wave Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the Schrödinger equation describes electron behavior using wave functions (ψ), with ψ² representing the probability density of finding an electron.
example_tasks: Explain what a wave function (ψ) represents in quantum mechanics. What does ψ² tell us about an electron?
Describe how the Schrödinger equation revolutionized atomic theory. What information can be obtained by solving this equation?
Explain why the quantum mechanical model is probabilistic rather than deterministic. What can we know about electron location?

sub_topics.name: Quantum Numbers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the four quantum numbers (n, l, mₗ, mₛ) that completely describe each electron in an atom, including allowed values and physical meaning.

sub_topics.name: Principal Quantum Number (n)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding n as the quantum number that determines the energy level and average distance from the nucleus, with values n = 1, 2, 3, etc.
example_tasks: Define the principal quantum number (n) and describe what it tells us about an electron. What are the allowed values?
Explain how the energy of an electron relates to its n value. Which electrons have higher energy: those with n = 1 or n = 3?
Calculate the maximum number of electrons that can occupy the shell with n = 3. Use the formula 2n² to verify your answer

sub_topics.name: Angular Momentum Quantum Number (l)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding l as the quantum number that determines the shape of the orbital (s, p, d, f), with values from 0 to n-1 for each value of n.
example_tasks: Define the angular momentum quantum number (l) and explain what it determines. What are the allowed values for l when n = 3?
Match each l value with its sublevel designation: l = 0 (s), l = 1 (p), l = 2 (d), l = 3 (f). What do these letters represent?
For the n = 4 shell, list all possible values of l and name the corresponding sublevels. How many types of orbitals are possible in this shell?

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Quantum Number (mₗ)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding mₗ as the quantum number that specifies the orbital's orientation in space, with values from -l to +l including zero.
example_tasks: Define the magnetic quantum number (mₗ) and explain what it determines. For l = 2 (d sublevel), what are the possible values of mₗ?
Explain why the p sublevel (l = 1) has three orbitals (px, py, pz). How does mₗ relate to the number of orbitals in a sublevel?
For the d sublevel (l = 2), list all possible mₗ values and explain what this tells us about the number of d orbitals

sub_topics.name: Spin Quantum Number (mₛ)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding mₛ as the quantum number describing electron spin (intrinsic angular momentum), with values of +½ or -½ for spin-up and spin-down.
example_tasks: Define the spin quantum number (mₛ) and state its possible values. What physical property of electrons does spin represent?
Explain why each orbital can hold a maximum of two electrons. How does the Pauli Exclusion Principle relate to the spin quantum number?
Write a complete set of four quantum numbers for each electron in a helium atom (1s²). How do the quantum numbers differ?

sub_topics.name: Applying Quantum Numbers
sub_topics.short_description: Using all four quantum numbers together to describe electrons uniquely and determining valid vs. invalid quantum number combinations.
example_tasks: Write a valid set of four quantum numbers (n, l, mₗ, mₛ) for: (a) an electron in a 2p orbital, (b) an electron in a 3d orbital, (c) an electron in a 4s orbital
Identify which sets of quantum numbers are invalid and explain why: (a) n=2, l=2, mₗ=0, mₛ=+½, (b) n=3, l=1, mₗ=-2, mₛ=-½, (c) n=4, l=2, mₗ=1, mₛ=+½
For an electron with n = 3 and l = 2, list all possible combinations of mₗ and mₛ. How many electrons can have these n and l values?

sub_topics.name: Atomic Spectra and Energy Transitions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how electron transitions between energy levels produce or absorb specific wavelengths of light, explaining line spectra and the Rydberg equation.

sub_topics.name: Emission Spectra
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atoms emit specific wavelengths of light when excited electrons return to lower energy levels, producing characteristic line spectra.
example_tasks: Explain how an emission spectrum is produced. What happens to electrons when an atom is excited by heat or electricity?
Describe the hydrogen emission spectrum. Why does it consist of discrete lines rather than a continuous spectrum?
Explain how emission spectra can be used to identify elements. Why is each element's emission spectrum unique?

sub_topics.name: Absorption Spectra
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atoms absorb specific wavelengths when electrons jump to higher energy levels, producing dark lines in an otherwise continuous spectrum.
example_tasks: Explain how an absorption spectrum is produced. How does it differ from an emission spectrum?
Describe the relationship between absorption and emission spectra for the same element. Why do the dark lines in absorption match the bright lines in emission?
Explain how astronomers use absorption spectra to determine the composition of stars. What do the dark lines tell us about the star's atmosphere?

sub_topics.name: Energy Transitions and Photon Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the energy of photons emitted or absorbed during electron transitions using E = hν and the relationship between energy and wavelength.
example_tasks: Use the equation E = hν to calculate the energy of a photon with frequency 6.0 × 10¹⁴ Hz. (Planck's constant h = 6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s)
Calculate the wavelength of light emitted when an electron transitions from n = 3 to n = 2 in a hydrogen atom. Use the fact that higher energy corresponds to shorter wavelength
An electron in hydrogen drops from n = 4 to n = 2, emitting a photon with wavelength 486 nm (blue-green light). Calculate the energy change for this transition using E = hc/λ

sub_topics.name: Rydberg Equation for Hydrogen
sub_topics.short_description: Using the Rydberg equation to calculate wavelengths of light in hydrogen's spectrum based on electron transitions between energy levels.
example_tasks: State the Rydberg equation: 1/λ = R(1/n₁² - 1/n₂²), where R is the Rydberg constant. What do n₁ and n₂ represent?
Calculate the wavelength of light emitted when an electron in hydrogen transitions from n = 3 to n = 2. (Rydberg constant R = 1.097 × 10⁷ m⁻¹)
The Balmer series corresponds to transitions ending at n = 2 in hydrogen. Calculate the wavelengths for transitions from n = 3, 4, and 5 to n = 2. Which transition produces visible light?

sub_topics.name: Spectral Series in Hydrogen
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Lyman, Balmer, and Paschen series as groups of spectral lines corresponding to transitions ending at n = 1, 2, and 3 respectively.
example_tasks: Describe the Lyman series (transitions to n = 1). Are these photons in the UV, visible, or infrared region? Explain
The Balmer series (transitions to n = 2) produces visible light. Which transition in the Balmer series produces the highest energy photon?
Compare the energies of photons in the Lyman, Balmer, and Paschen series. Which series produces the highest energy photons? Why?

sub_topics.name: Advanced Electron Configuration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding exceptions to standard electron configuration patterns, particularly for transition metals and heavier elements, and predicting properties from configurations.

sub_topics.name: Transition Metal Electron Configurations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that d orbitals fill after the s orbital of the next shell, leading to the (n-1)d filling pattern characteristic of transition metals.
example_tasks: Write the electron configuration for scandium (Z = 21) through zinc (Z = 30), showing the filling of the 3d sublevel
Explain why the 4s orbital fills before the 3d orbital, but electrons are removed from 4s first when forming cations. Use iron (Fe) as an example
Write the electron configuration for Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺. Explain why electrons are removed from 4s before 3d when forming ions

sub_topics.name: Exceptions to Electron Configuration Rules
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chromium and copper (and others) have unexpected configurations due to the special stability of half-filled and filled d sublevels.
example_tasks: Explain why chromium has the electron configuration [Ar] 4s¹ 3d⁵ rather than [Ar] 4s² 3d⁴. What makes the half-filled d sublevel more stable?
Write the electron configuration for copper (Z = 29) and explain why it is [Ar] 4s¹ 3d¹⁰ rather than [Ar] 4s² 3d⁹
Identify other elements that have similar exceptions to standard filling order due to d-orbital stability (such as molybdenum and silver). What pattern do you notice?

sub_topics.name: Lanthanides and Actinides (f-block)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the electron configurations of lanthanides and actinides, where f orbitals are being filled, and their placement below the main periodic table.
example_tasks: Explain why lanthanides and actinides are placed separately at the bottom of the periodic table. What orbitals are being filled in these elements?
Write the electron configuration for cerium (Ce, Z = 58), the first lanthanide. Which orbital (4f) begins filling?
Describe the general properties of lanthanides and actinides. Why do they have similar chemical properties within each series?

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Properties from Electron Configuration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that unpaired electrons make atoms paramagnetic (attracted to magnetic fields) while paired electrons make atoms diamagnetic (weakly repelled).
example_tasks: Define paramagnetic and diamagnetic. Which type of substance is attracted to a magnetic field?
Determine whether the following atoms/ions are paramagnetic or diamagnetic based on their electron configurations: O, O²⁻, F, Fe²⁺, Zn²⁺
Explain why transition metals are often paramagnetic while main group elements in their compounds are usually diamagnetic. What role do d electrons play?

sub_topics.name: Advanced Periodic Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Deepening understanding of periodic trends with explanations based on electron configuration, effective nuclear charge, and shielding effects.

sub_topics.name: Effective Nuclear Charge (Zeff)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that outer electrons experience less than the full nuclear charge due to shielding by inner electrons, affecting atomic properties.
example_tasks: Define effective nuclear charge (Zeff) and explain how it differs from the actual nuclear charge. What causes the difference?
Explain why Zeff increases across a period. Use Period 3 (Na to Ar) as an example, considering added protons and constant shielding
Compare the Zeff experienced by a 3s electron in sodium versus chlorine. Which atom has the higher Zeff and why?

sub_topics.name: Shielding and Penetration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that inner electrons shield outer electrons from the nucleus, and that different orbitals have different penetrating abilities.
example_tasks: Explain the shielding effect using the example of sodium (1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s¹). How do the inner 10 electrons affect the 3s electron?
Describe orbital penetration. Rank s, p, d, and f orbitals in order of increasing penetration toward the nucleus for the same n value
Explain why a 3s electron is lower in energy than a 3p electron in the same atom, even though they have the same n value. Use penetration and shielding concepts

sub_topics.name: Exceptions to Periodic Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and explaining anomalies in periodic trends, such as the dip in ionization energy from N to O or from Mg to Al.
example_tasks: Explain why oxygen has a lower first ionization energy than nitrogen, even though ionization energy generally increases across a period. Consider electron configuration and repulsion
Explain the decrease in first ionization energy from Mg (Group 2) to Al (Group 13). Why does this occur despite the general trend of increasing IE across a period?
Analyze why noble gases have very high ionization energies despite being at the end of their periods. What makes their electron configurations so stable?

sub_topics.name: Successive Ionization Energies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that removing each subsequent electron requires more energy, with large jumps occurring when removing electrons from inner shells.
example_tasks: Explain why the second ionization energy is always greater than the first ionization energy for any element. Use magnesium as an example
Analyze the successive ionization energies of aluminum: IE₁ = 578 kJ/mol, IE₂ = 1817 kJ/mol, IE₃ = 2745 kJ/mol, IE₄ = 11,578 kJ/mol. Explain the large jump after IE₃
Use successive ionization energy data to determine how many valence electrons an unknown element has. If there's a large jump after the third ionization, what does this indicate?

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Chemical Bonding
grade_11_12.short_description: Deepening understanding of chemical bonding through hybridization, molecular orbital theory, resonance, and formal charge. Students explore the quantum mechanical basis of bonding and advanced models for predicting molecular properties.

sub_topics.name: Hybridization of Atomic Orbitals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how atomic orbitals mix to form hybrid orbitals that better explain molecular geometry and bonding, including sp, sp², sp³, and sp³d hybridizations.

sub_topics.name: sp³ Hybridization (Tetrahedral)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that mixing one s and three p orbitals creates four equivalent sp³ hybrid orbitals arranged tetrahedrally, as in methane.
example_tasks: Describe sp³ hybridization. How many atomic orbitals combine, and how many hybrid orbitals are formed? What geometry results?
Draw the orbital diagram showing how sp³ hybridization occurs in carbon. Show the unhybridized and hybridized states
Explain how sp³ hybridization accounts for the tetrahedral geometry and four equivalent C-H bonds in methane (CH₄)

sub_topics.name: sp² Hybridization (Trigonal Planar)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that mixing one s and two p orbitals creates three sp² hybrid orbitals in a plane, with one unhybridized p orbital remaining for π bonding.
example_tasks: Describe sp² hybridization. How many hybrid orbitals are formed, and what geometry do they have? What happens to the remaining p orbital?
Explain the bonding in ethene (C₂H₄) using sp² hybridization. Which orbitals form the C=C σ bond and which form the π bond?
Draw the orbital overlap diagram for ethene showing the σ bonds from sp² orbitals and the π bond from unhybridized p orbitals

sub_topics.name: sp Hybridization (Linear)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that mixing one s and one p orbital creates two sp hybrid orbitals arranged linearly, with two unhybridized p orbitals for π bonding.
example_tasks: Describe sp hybridization. How many hybrid orbitals are formed, and what is their geometry? How many unhybridized p orbitals remain?
Explain the bonding in ethyne (C₂H₂) using sp hybridization. How many σ bonds and how many π bonds are in the C≡C triple bond?
Draw orbital diagrams showing how sp hybridization leads to the linear geometry and triple bond in ethyne

sub_topics.name: Hybridization with Expanded Octets (sp³d, sp³d²)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that elements in Period 3 and beyond can use d orbitals for hybridization, allowing more than eight electrons around the central atom.
example_tasks: Describe sp³d hybridization. Which orbitals mix, how many hybrid orbitals form, and what geometry results? Give an example (such as PCl₅)
Explain sp³d² hybridization in SF₆. How does sulfur accommodate six bonding pairs around it?
Explain why carbon cannot form sp³d hybrid orbitals while phosphorus can. What is required for d orbital participation in bonding?

sub_topics.name: Determining Hybridization from Molecular Geometry
sub_topics.short_description: Using electron pair geometry and the number of electron groups to determine the type of hybridization at the central atom.
example_tasks: Determine the hybridization of the central atom in: NH₃, H₂O, BF₃, CO₂, and PCl₅. Explain your reasoning for each
A molecule has four electron groups around the central atom (3 bonds and 1 lone pair). What is the hybridization and molecular geometry?
For the molecule CH₂=CH-CH₃ (propene), determine the hybridization of each carbon atom. Explain any differences

sub_topics.name: Sigma (σ) and Pi (π) Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the difference between sigma bonds (head-on overlap) and pi bonds (side-by-side overlap), and how multiple bonds contain both types.

sub_topics.name: Sigma (σ) Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sigma bonds as the strongest type of covalent bond, formed by head-on overlap of orbitals along the bonding axis, allowing free rotation.
example_tasks: Define a sigma (σ) bond and describe how orbitals overlap to form it. Why can atoms rotate freely around single bonds?
Identify which orbitals overlap to form σ bonds in: H₂ (s-s), HCl (s-p), Cl₂ (p-p), and CH₄ (sp³-s)
Explain why all single bonds are σ bonds. Can a molecule have π bonds without σ bonds? Why or why not?

sub_topics.name: Pi (π) Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pi bonds as weaker bonds formed by side-by-side overlap of parallel p orbitals, restricting rotation and found in double and triple bonds.
example_tasks: Define a pi (π) bond and describe how p orbitals overlap to form it. Why does a π bond prevent free rotation?
Draw the orbital overlap for the double bond in C₂H₄, showing the σ bond (sp²-sp²) and the π bond (p-p)
Explain the composition of double and triple bonds in terms of σ and π bonds. How many of each type are in C=C? In C≡C?

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Multiple Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Counting and identifying σ and π bonds in molecules with single, double, and triple bonds, and understanding bond strength relationships.
example_tasks: For the molecule CO₂ (O=C=O), count the total number of σ bonds and π bonds. Show your reasoning
In the molecule CH₃-CH=CH₂ (propene), identify all σ and π bonds. How many of each type are present?
Rank the following bonds in order of increasing strength: C-C (single), C=C (double), C≡C (triple). Explain your ranking using σ and π bond concepts

sub_topics.name: Resonance Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that some molecules cannot be accurately represented by a single Lewis structure and are better described as resonance hybrids of multiple contributing structures.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Resonance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that resonance structures are different ways to draw the same molecule, with the true structure being an average (hybrid) of all valid structures.
example_tasks: Define resonance and explain what resonance structures represent. Does the molecule actually flip between structures? Explain
Draw the two resonance structures for ozone (O₃). Use a double-headed arrow (↔) to indicate they are resonance structures
Explain why the actual O₃ molecule has two equivalent O-O bonds that are intermediate between single and double bonds

sub_topics.name: Drawing Valid Resonance Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Learning rules for drawing resonance structures: moving only electrons (not atoms), maintaining the same number of electrons, and keeping atoms in the same positions.
example_tasks: Draw all resonance structures for the nitrate ion (NO₃⁻). How many equivalent resonance structures are there?
Draw resonance structures for the carbonate ion (CO₃²⁻). What is the bond order of each C-O bond in the resonance hybrid?
For benzene (C₆H₆), draw the two main resonance structures showing alternating double bonds. Explain why all C-C bonds are equivalent in the actual molecule

sub_topics.name: Resonance and Molecular Stability
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that molecules with resonance are more stable than any single contributing structure would predict, due to delocalization of electrons.
example_tasks: Explain how resonance stabilizes molecules. Why is benzene more stable than expected for a structure with alternating single and double bonds?
Compare the stability of the acetate ion (CH₃COO⁻) which has resonance, with ethanol (C₂H₅OH) which does not. Why is acetate more stable as a base?
Rank the following in order of increasing stability and explain using resonance: an isolated double bond, a conjugated diene (alternating double bonds), benzene

sub_topics.name: Formal Charge and Best Resonance Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Using formal charge calculations to determine which resonance structure contributes most to the resonance hybrid, favoring structures with minimal formal charges.
example_tasks: Define formal charge and write the formula: FC = V - (L + ½B), where V = valence electrons, L = lone pair electrons, B = bonding electrons
Calculate the formal charge on each atom in CO₂. Verify that the sum of formal charges equals the overall charge (zero)
Draw two resonance structures for HCN and calculate formal charges for each atom in both structures. Which resonance structure is preferred based on formal charge?

sub_topics.name: Molecular Orbital Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding molecular orbital (MO) theory as an alternative to valence bond theory, explaining bonding through constructive and destructive interference of atomic orbitals.

sub_topics.name: Basics of Molecular Orbital Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atomic orbitals combine to form molecular orbitals, with bonding orbitals (lower energy) and antibonding orbitals (higher energy).
example_tasks: Explain the fundamental principle of molecular orbital theory. How do atomic orbitals combine to form molecular orbitals?
Define bonding and antibonding molecular orbitals. Which is lower in energy and why?
Describe what σ and σ* (sigma and sigma-star) orbitals represent. Which is bonding and which is antibonding?

sub_topics.name: Molecular Orbital Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing and interpreting MO diagrams to show electron distribution in bonding and antibonding orbitals for simple diatomic molecules.
example_tasks: Draw the molecular orbital diagram for H₂. Show the 1s atomic orbitals combining to form σ and σ* molecular orbitals, then fill in the electrons
Draw the MO diagram for He₂ and explain why this molecule doesn't exist. What is the bond order?
Construct the MO diagram for O₂. Use the diagram to explain why O₂ is paramagnetic (has unpaired electrons)

sub_topics.name: Bond Order in MO Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating bond order using the formula: Bond Order = ½(bonding electrons - antibonding electrons), with higher bond order indicating stronger, shorter bonds.
example_tasks: Define bond order in molecular orbital theory. Calculate the bond order for H₂, He₂, and Li₂
Calculate the bond order for O₂ (with 10 bonding and 6 antibonding electrons). How does this compare to the double bond shown in the Lewis structure?
Predict the relative bond strengths and bond lengths for O₂, O₂⁺, and O₂⁻ using bond order calculations. Which has the strongest bond?

sub_topics.name: Explaining Paramagnetism with MO Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Using MO theory to explain the paramagnetic behavior of molecules like O₂ that have unpaired electrons in molecular orbitals.
example_tasks: Explain how MO theory successfully predicts that O₂ is paramagnetic, while Lewis structures incorrectly suggest all electrons are paired
Draw the MO diagram for B₂ and determine if it is paramagnetic or diamagnetic. How many unpaired electrons does it have?
Compare the magnetic properties of O₂ and F₂ using MO theory. Which is paramagnetic and which is diamagnetic?

sub_topics.name: Advanced Bond Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Deepening understanding of bond length, bond energy, bond order, and how molecular structure affects these properties.

sub_topics.name: Bond Energy and Bond Strength
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that bond energy (enthalpy) represents the energy required to break a bond, with higher values indicating stronger bonds.
example_tasks: Define bond energy (bond dissociation energy). Rank the following bonds in order of increasing bond energy: C-C (347 kJ/mol), C=C (614 kJ/mol), C≡C (839 kJ/mol)
Explain the relationship between bond order and bond energy. Why does a triple bond have higher bond energy than a double bond?
Use bond energies to estimate ΔH for the reaction: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O. Bond energies: C-H (413 kJ/mol), O=O (498 kJ/mol), C=O (799 kJ/mol), O-H (463 kJ/mol)

sub_topics.name: Bond Length Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that bond length decreases with increasing bond order and varies predictably with atomic size and electronegativity.
example_tasks: Explain the relationship between bond order and bond length. Rank C-C, C=C, and C≡C bonds in order of increasing bond length
Compare the C-H bond length in CH₄ with the C-C bond length. Which is shorter and why?
Predict the relative bond lengths in HF, HCl, HBr, and HI. Explain your reasoning based on atomic size

sub_topics.name: Bond Polarity and Dipole Moments
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding dipole moments as quantitative measures of bond polarity, with magnitude depending on charge difference and bond length.
example_tasks: Define dipole moment and explain how it relates to bond polarity. What factors determine the magnitude of a dipole moment?
Rank the following bonds in order of increasing dipole moment: C-H, C-Cl, C-F, C-O. Explain your ranking
Explain why CO₂ has no net dipole moment despite having two polar C=O bonds, while H₂O has a significant dipole moment

grade_11_12.name: Chemical Kinetics
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding the rates of chemical reactions, factors affecting rates, rate laws, reaction mechanisms, and catalysis. Students learn to measure reaction rates, determine rate laws experimentally, and understand how reactions proceed at the molecular level.

sub_topics.name: Reaction Rates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reaction rate as the change in concentration of reactants or products per unit time, and methods for measuring and expressing rates.

sub_topics.name: Defining and Measuring Reaction Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding rate as Δconcentration/Δtime, typically expressed in mol/(L·s), and that rates can be measured by following reactant decrease or product increase.
example_tasks: Define reaction rate and state its common units. If the concentration of a reactant decreases from 1.0 M to 0.6 M in 20 seconds, calculate the average rate
Explain why reaction rates are usually fastest at the beginning of a reaction and slow down as time progresses. What is happening to reactant concentrations?
For the reaction A → B, if [A] changes from 0.80 M to 0.50 M in 15 seconds, calculate the average rate of disappearance of A and the average rate of appearance of B

sub_topics.name: Average vs. Instantaneous Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that average rate is measured over a time interval while instantaneous rate is the slope of the tangent to a concentration vs. time curve at a specific moment.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between average rate and instantaneous rate. Which one changes as the reaction progresses?
Given a graph of [reactant] vs. time, describe how to determine: (a) the average rate between two points, (b) the instantaneous rate at a specific time
Sketch a graph showing [reactant] vs. time for a reaction. Mark two different times and compare the instantaneous rates (tangent slopes) at these times

sub_topics.name: Relating Rates Using Stoichiometry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for a reaction aA + bB → cC + dD, rates of different species are related by stoichiometric coefficients: rate = -1/a(Δ[A]/Δt) = -1/b(Δ[B]/Δt) = 1/c(Δ[C]/Δt) = 1/d(Δ[D]/Δt).
example_tasks: For the reaction 2N₂O₅ → 4NO₂ + O₂, if O₂ is produced at 0.10 M/s, calculate the rate of: (a) NO₂ production, (b) N₂O₅ consumption
Explain why the rate of consumption of reactants is expressed as a negative value while the rate of production of products is positive
For the reaction N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃, if N₂ is consumed at 0.30 M/s, at what rate is: (a) H₂ consumed, (b) NH₃ produced?

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Reaction Rates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how concentration, temperature, surface area, and catalysts affect the rate of chemical reactions through collision theory and activation energy.

sub_topics.name: Effect of Concentration on Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that increasing reactant concentration generally increases reaction rate because of more frequent collisions between particles.
example_tasks: Explain using collision theory why increasing the concentration of reactants typically increases the reaction rate
Design an experiment to demonstrate the effect of concentration on reaction rate using hydrochloric acid and magnesium ribbon
Predict and explain the effect on reaction rate when: (a) [reactant] is doubled, (b) [reactant] is halved. (Assume first-order dependence)

sub_topics.name: Effect of Temperature on Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that increasing temperature increases reaction rate by increasing collision frequency and, more importantly, the fraction of collisions with sufficient energy (activation energy).
example_tasks: Explain two reasons why increasing temperature increases reaction rate. Which factor is more significant?
A rule of thumb states that reaction rate roughly doubles for every 10°C increase in temperature. Explain this observation using the concept of activation energy
Sketch and compare Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curves for molecular speeds at two different temperatures. Show how the fraction of molecules with E ≥ Ea changes

sub_topics.name: Effect of Surface Area on Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that increasing surface area of solid reactants increases reaction rate by providing more sites for collisions to occur.
example_tasks: Explain why powdered zinc reacts faster with acid than a zinc strip of the same mass. Use collision theory
Describe an experiment demonstrating the effect of surface area on reaction rate using calcium carbonate (marble chips) and hydrochloric acid
Predict what would happen to the reaction rate if a solid reactant is ground into a fine powder. Explain your reasoning

sub_topics.name: Effect of Catalysts on Rate
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that catalysts increase reaction rate by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation energy, without being consumed in the reaction.
example_tasks: Define a catalyst and explain how it increases reaction rate. Why isn't the catalyst consumed during the reaction?
Draw two energy diagrams comparing: (a) uncatalyzed reaction, (b) catalyzed reaction. Label activation energies and show that ΔH remains the same
Give three examples of catalysts: one from industry (e.g., platinum in catalytic converters), one from biology (e.g., enzymes), and one from everyday life

sub_topics.name: Collision Theory and Activation Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy (activation energy) and proper orientation, explaining rate variations.

sub_topics.name: Collision Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that particles must collide for reactions to occur, but only effective collisions (with sufficient energy and correct orientation) lead to products.
example_tasks: State the two requirements for an effective collision according to collision theory. Why don't all collisions lead to a reaction?
Explain using collision theory why increasing temperature has such a dramatic effect on reaction rate (often doubling rate for each 10°C increase)
Describe what 'proper orientation' means in collision theory. Use the reaction between NO and O₃ as an example to illustrate why orientation matters

sub_topics.name: Activation Energy (Ea)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding activation energy as the minimum energy required for a reaction to occur, representing the energy barrier that must be overcome.
example_tasks: Define activation energy (Ea) and explain its significance. Why do reactions with high Ea tend to be slower?
Draw a potential energy diagram for an exothermic reaction, labeling: reactants, products, activation energy (Ea), and ΔH. Explain what each represents
Compare the activation energies for forward and reverse reactions on a potential energy diagram. For an exothermic reaction, which direction has the higher Ea?

sub_topics.name: Transition State (Activated Complex)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the transition state as the highest energy point along the reaction pathway, where bonds are partially broken and formed.
example_tasks: Define the transition state (activated complex). How does it differ from both reactants and products?
On a potential energy diagram, locate and label the transition state. Explain why it represents the highest energy point
For the reaction H₂ + I₂ → 2HI, describe what bonds are being broken and formed in the transition state

sub_topics.name: Arrhenius Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Using the Arrhenius equation k = Ae^(-Ea/RT) to relate rate constant, activation energy, and temperature quantitatively.
example_tasks: State the Arrhenius equation and define each term: k (rate constant), A (frequency factor), Ea (activation energy), R (gas constant), T (temperature)
Explain qualitatively how the Arrhenius equation shows that: (a) higher Ea leads to slower reactions, (b) higher T leads to faster reactions
Using the Arrhenius equation, explain why a small increase in temperature can cause a large increase in the rate constant k

sub_topics.name: Rate Laws and Reaction Order
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding rate laws as mathematical relationships between reaction rate and reactant concentrations, including determining reaction orders experimentally.

sub_topics.name: Rate Law Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that rate laws have the form: rate = k[A]^m[B]^n, where k is the rate constant and m, n are reaction orders determined experimentally.
example_tasks: Write the general form of a rate law for the reaction A + B → products. Define each term: rate, k, [A], [B], m, and n
Given the rate law: rate = k[NO]²[O₂], identify: (a) the rate constant, (b) the order with respect to NO, (c) the order with respect to O₂, (d) the overall order
Explain why reaction orders cannot be determined from the balanced equation alone. How must they be determined?

sub_topics.name: Reaction Orders (Zero, First, Second)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding zero-order (rate independent of concentration), first-order (rate proportional to concentration), and second-order (rate proportional to [A]²) reactions.
example_tasks: Define zero-order, first-order, and second-order reactions. For each, describe how rate depends on concentration
For a first-order reaction in A, if [A] is doubled, what happens to the rate? What if [A] is tripled?
For a second-order reaction in A, if [A] is doubled, what happens to the rate? Compare this with first-order behavior

sub_topics.name: Determining Rate Laws from Experimental Data
sub_topics.short_description: Using the method of initial rates (comparing how rate changes when concentration changes) to determine reaction orders experimentally.
example_tasks: Given initial rate data for the reaction A + B → products at different concentrations, determine the rate law and calculate k: Exp 1: [A]=0.1, [B]=0.1, rate=0.02; Exp 2: [A]=0.2, [B]=0.1, rate=0.04; Exp 3: [A]=0.1, [B]=0.2, rate=0.08
Explain the method of initial rates. Why is it useful to measure rate right at the beginning of the reaction?

From the following data, determine m and n in rate = k[A]^m[B]^n: Exp 1: [A]=0.10 M, [B]=0.10 M, rate=0.50 M/s; Exp 2: [A]=0.20 M, [B]=0.10 M, rate=2.00 M/s; Exp 3: [A]=0.10 M, [B]=0.30 M, rate=0.50 M/s

sub_topics.name: Rate Constant (k)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the rate constant k is temperature-dependent and has units that depend on overall reaction order.
example_tasks: Explain what the rate constant k represents. What factors affect its value?
Determine the units of k for: (a) a first-order reaction, (b) a second-order reaction, (c) a zero-order reaction
Two reactions have rate constants k₁ = 0.1 s⁻¹ and k₂ = 0.001 s⁻¹ at the same temperature. Which reaction is faster? Explain

sub_topics.name: Integrated Rate Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding integrated rate laws that relate concentration to time for zero, first, and second-order reactions, including half-life calculations.

sub_topics.name: First-Order Integrated Rate Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for first-order reactions, ln[A]t = ln[A]₀ - kt, with a constant half-life of t₁/₂ = 0.693/k.
example_tasks: Write the integrated rate law for a first-order reaction. What is the relationship between ln[A] and time?
For a first-order reaction with k = 0.050 s⁻¹, calculate the half-life. How long does it take for [A] to decrease from 1.0 M to 0.25 M?
A first-order reaction has a half-life of 20 minutes. If you start with 100 g of reactant, how much remains after: (a) 20 min, (b) 40 min, (c) 60 min?

sub_topics.name: Zero-Order Integrated Rate Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for zero-order reactions, [A]t = [A]₀ - kt, with half-life t₁/₂ = [A]₀/(2k) that depends on initial concentration.
example_tasks: Write the integrated rate law for a zero-order reaction. How does [A] change with time?
For a zero-order reaction, if initial concentration is 1.0 M and k = 0.10 M/s, calculate: (a) concentration after 5.0 seconds, (b) time to reach [A] = 0.50 M
Explain why the half-life of a zero-order reaction depends on initial concentration, unlike first-order reactions where half-life is constant

sub_topics.name: Second-Order Integrated Rate Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for second-order reactions, 1/[A]t = 1/[A]₀ + kt, with half-life t₁/₂ = 1/(k[A]₀) that depends on initial concentration.
example_tasks: Write the integrated rate law for a second-order reaction. What is plotted vs. time to get a straight line?
For a second-order reaction with k = 0.50 M⁻¹s⁻¹ and [A]₀ = 0.80 M, calculate [A] after 10 seconds
Calculate the half-life for a second-order reaction with k = 0.20 M⁻¹s⁻¹ and [A]₀ = 2.0 M. What is the half-life if [A]₀ = 1.0 M?

sub_topics.name: Graphical Determination of Reaction Order
sub_topics.short_description: Using linear plots ([A] vs. t for zero-order, ln[A] vs. t for first-order, 1/[A] vs. t for second-order) to determine reaction order from experimental data.
example_tasks: Describe how to determine reaction order graphically. What plot gives a straight line for: (a) zero-order, (b) first-order, (c) second-order?
Given concentration vs. time data, explain how you would plot the data three different ways to determine which order fits best
If a plot of ln[A] vs. time gives a straight line with slope = -0.025 s⁻¹, what is: (a) the reaction order, (b) the rate constant, (c) the half-life?

sub_topics.name: Reaction Mechanisms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reactions occur through a series of elementary steps, with the slowest step (rate-determining) controlling the overall rate.

sub_topics.name: Elementary Steps
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding elementary steps as single-step processes (unimolecular, bimolecular, or rarely termolecular) whose molecularity equals reaction order.
example_tasks: Define elementary step and molecularity. Classify each as unimolecular, bimolecular, or termolecular: (a) A → products, (b) 2A → products, (c) A + B → products
Explain why the molecularity of an elementary step equals its reaction order. Why is this NOT true for overall reactions?
Write the rate law for each elementary step: (a) O₃ → O₂ + O (unimolecular), (b) NO + O₃ → NO₂ + O₂ (bimolecular)

sub_topics.name: Rate-Determining Step
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the slowest step in a mechanism controls the overall reaction rate, analogous to the narrowest point in a bottleneck.
example_tasks: Define the rate-determining step. Explain the bottleneck analogy for why the slowest step controls the overall rate
For a two-step mechanism where step 1 is slow and step 2 is fast, which step determines the rate law for the overall reaction?
Given the mechanism: Step 1 (slow): A → B + C; Step 2 (fast): B + D → E. Write the rate law for the overall reaction

sub_topics.name: Reaction Intermediates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that intermediates are species produced in one step and consumed in a later step, not appearing in the overall equation.
example_tasks: Define a reaction intermediate. How does it differ from a catalyst?
For the mechanism: Step 1: NO₂ + NO₂ → NO₃ + NO; Step 2: NO₃ + CO → NO₂ + CO₂. Identify: (a) the intermediate, (b) the overall reaction
Explain why intermediates don't appear in the overall balanced equation but do appear in the mechanism

sub_topics.name: Relating Mechanisms to Rate Laws
sub_topics.short_description: Using proposed mechanisms to derive rate laws and comparing with experimental rate laws to validate or reject mechanisms.
example_tasks: For the mechanism: Step 1 (slow): 2NO₂ → NO₃ + NO; Step 2 (fast): NO₃ + CO → NO₂ + CO₂. Overall: NO₂ + CO → NO + CO₂. Derive the rate law and verify it matches the experimental rate law
Explain how a proposed mechanism can be rejected if its predicted rate law doesn't match the experimental rate law
A mechanism is proposed: Step 1 (fast equilibrium): A + B ⇌ C; Step 2 (slow): C → D. Show that this mechanism gives rate = k[A][B]

sub_topics.name: Catalysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, enzyme catalysis, and how catalysts lower activation energy without being consumed.

sub_topics.name: Homogeneous Catalysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding catalysis where the catalyst is in the same phase as the reactants, often involving formation of intermediate complexes.
example_tasks: Define homogeneous catalysis and provide two examples, such as acid catalysis in esterification or enzyme catalysis
Explain how a homogeneous catalyst works by providing an alternative mechanism with lower activation energy. Use an energy diagram to illustrate
Describe the role of I⁻ as a homogeneous catalyst in the decomposition of H₂O₂. Write the mechanism showing how I⁻ is regenerated

sub_topics.name: Heterogeneous Catalysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding catalysis where the catalyst is in a different phase from reactants, typically solid catalysts with gas or liquid reactants.
example_tasks: Define heterogeneous catalysis and provide examples such as platinum in catalytic converters or iron in the Haber process
Describe the steps in heterogeneous catalysis: (1) adsorption, (2) reaction on surface, (3) desorption of products
Explain why finely divided catalysts (high surface area) are more effective than bulk catalysts in heterogeneous catalysis

sub_topics.name: Enzyme Catalysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding biological catalysts (enzymes) that are highly specific, forming enzyme-substrate complexes with active sites.
example_tasks: Describe how enzymes catalyze biological reactions. What is the active site and why are enzymes highly specific?
Explain the lock-and-key model of enzyme-substrate interaction. How does the induced-fit model improve upon this?
Discuss factors that affect enzyme activity: temperature, pH, substrate concentration, and inhibitors

grade_11_12.name: Chemical Equilibrium
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding reversible reactions, equilibrium constants, Le Chatelier's Principle, and equilibrium calculations. Students learn that many reactions reach a dynamic equilibrium where forward and reverse rates are equal, and how to predict and calculate equilibrium positions.

sub_topics.name: Reversible Reactions and Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reversible reactions can proceed in both forward and reverse directions, eventually reaching a dynamic equilibrium state.

sub_topics.name: Reversible Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that some reactions can proceed in both directions, indicated by a double arrow (⇌), with products converting back to reactants.
example_tasks: Define a reversible reaction and explain how it differs from an irreversible reaction. What symbol is used to represent reversibility?
Give three examples of reversible reactions: (a) N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, (b) H₂O(l) ⇌ H₂O(g), (c) CoCl₄²⁻(aq) + 6H₂O ⇌ Co(H₂O)₆²⁺(aq) + 4Cl⁻(aq)
Explain why some reactions reach equilibrium while others go essentially to completion. What factors determine this?

sub_topics.name: Dynamic Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding equilibrium as a dynamic state where forward and reverse reaction rates are equal, so concentrations remain constant despite ongoing reactions.
example_tasks: Define dynamic equilibrium. Explain why it is 'dynamic' rather than static—what is still happening at the molecular level?
Describe what happens to the rates of forward and reverse reactions as a system approaches equilibrium. Draw a graph showing how rates change over time
For the reaction N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g), explain what happens at equilibrium: Are reactions still occurring? Do concentrations change?

sub_topics.name: Conditions for Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that equilibrium is achieved in a closed system and that the equilibrium position depends on initial conditions and temperature.
example_tasks: Explain why equilibrium can only be achieved in a closed system. What happens in an open system?
Describe the difference between the equilibrium state and the equilibrium position. Can different initial conditions lead to the same equilibrium state?
For the reaction A + B ⇌ C + D, if you start with only reactants versus starting with only products, will the equilibrium concentrations be the same? Explain

sub_topics.name: The Equilibrium Constant
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the equilibrium constant (K) as a ratio of product to reactant concentrations at equilibrium, and its significance in predicting reaction extent.

sub_topics.name: Writing Equilibrium Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Writing the equilibrium constant expression K = [products]^coefficients / [reactants]^coefficients, using molar concentrations for aqueous and gaseous species.
example_tasks: Write the equilibrium constant expression (Kc) for: (a) N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), (b) 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), (c) H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g)
Explain why pure solids and pure liquids are not included in the equilibrium expression. What about solvents like water in dilute aqueous solutions?
For the reaction CaCO₃(s) ⇌ CaO(s) + CO₂(g), write the equilibrium expression. Why don't the solid concentrations appear?

sub_topics.name: Kc and Kp for Gas-Phase Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Kc (using concentrations) and Kp (using partial pressures) for gas-phase equilibria, related by Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn.
example_tasks: Define Kc and Kp. For gas-phase reactions, which uses molar concentrations and which uses partial pressures?
Write both Kc and Kp expressions for: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g). How are they related?
For the reaction PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g), if Kc = 0.042 at 500 K, calculate Kp using Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn where Δn = change in moles of gas and R = 0.0821 L·atm/(mol·K)

sub_topics.name: Magnitude of K and Reaction Extent
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that K >> 1 means products favored (equilibrium lies to the right), K << 1 means reactants favored (equilibrium lies to the left), and K ≈ 1 means significant amounts of both.
example_tasks: Explain what the magnitude of K tells you about the equilibrium position. What does K = 10⁶ indicate? What about K = 10⁻⁶?
For the following equilibrium constants, predict whether reactants or products are favored: (a) K = 1.5 × 10⁸, (b) K = 3.2 × 10⁻⁵, (c) K = 0.85
Two reactions have K₁ = 100 and K₂ = 0.01. Which reaction has more products at equilibrium? Which reaction proceeds further toward completion?

sub_topics.name: Calculating K from Equilibrium Concentrations
sub_topics.short_description: Using measured equilibrium concentrations to calculate the value of the equilibrium constant.
example_tasks: For the reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), equilibrium concentrations are [H₂] = 0.50 M, [I₂] = 0.50 M, [HI] = 3.0 M. Calculate Kc
At equilibrium, [N₂] = 0.10 M, [H₂] = 0.20 M, and [NH₃] = 0.60 M for N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g). Calculate Kc
Explain why the value of K depends only on temperature, not on initial concentrations or the presence of a catalyst

sub_topics.name: Manipulating Equilibrium Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how K changes when equations are reversed (Kreverse = 1/Kforward), multiplied by a coefficient (K' = K^n), or added together (Koverall = K₁ × K₂).
example_tasks: If K = 25 for the forward reaction A ⇌ B, what is K for the reverse reaction B ⇌ A? Explain
For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g) with K₁ = 0.50, calculate K₂ for: ½N₂(g) + 3/2H₂(g) ⇌ NH₃(g)
If reaction (1) has K₁ = 2.0 and reaction (2) has K₂ = 3.0, what is K for the reaction obtained by adding (1) + (2)? Show that Koverall = K₁ × K₂

sub_topics.name: Equilibrium Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Using ICE tables (Initial, Change, Equilibrium) to calculate unknown equilibrium concentrations from known K values and initial conditions.

sub_topics.name: ICE Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Using ICE (Initial, Change, Equilibrium) tables to organize information and solve for equilibrium concentrations systematically.
example_tasks: Explain what an ICE table is and how it helps organize equilibrium calculations. What do I, C, and E represent?
For the reaction A + B ⇌ 2C with initial [A] = 1.0 M, [B] = 1.0 M, [C] = 0 M, set up an ICE table. If 'x' M of A reacts, express all equilibrium concentrations in terms of x
Set up an ICE table for H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g) starting with [H₂] = 0.50 M, [I₂] = 0.50 M, and [HI] = 0 M. Let 'x' be the change in [H₂]

sub_topics.name: Calculating Equilibrium Concentrations
sub_topics.short_description: Using K and ICE tables to solve for unknown equilibrium concentrations, including small K approximation when appropriate.
example_tasks: For H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g) with K = 50, if you start with [H₂] = [I₂] = 1.0 M and [HI] = 0, calculate the equilibrium concentrations using an ICE table
For the reaction A ⇌ 2B with K = 4.0, starting with [A] = 0.80 M and [B] = 0, set up the ICE table and solve for equilibrium concentrations
When is the 'small x' approximation valid? For the reaction A ⇌ B with K = 1 × 10⁻⁵ and [A]₀ = 0.50 M, show that x is negligible compared to 0.50 and solve

sub_topics.name: Solving Equilibrium Problems Using Quadratic Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Solving equilibrium problems that result in quadratic equations when the small x approximation is not valid.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2A ⇌ B with K = 0.25, starting with [A] = 1.0 M, set up the equilibrium expression and show that it leads to a quadratic equation in x
Solve the quadratic equation 4x² + x - 0.25 = 0 using the quadratic formula. Use the physically meaningful root to determine equilibrium concentrations
Explain when you must use the quadratic formula versus when the small x approximation is acceptable. What is a general rule of thumb?

sub_topics.name: Reaction Quotient (Q)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Q as a ratio calculated like K but using non-equilibrium concentrations, and comparing Q to K to predict reaction direction.

sub_topics.name: Calculating the Reaction Quotient
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating Q using the same expression as K but with current (non-equilibrium) concentrations to determine the reaction's status.
example_tasks: Define the reaction quotient Q. How does it differ from the equilibrium constant K?
For the reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), calculate Q when [H₂] = 0.20 M, [I₂] = 0.30 M, and [HI] = 1.0 M. Is this an equilibrium mixture if K = 50?
Write the expression for Q for the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g) and explain when Q equals K

sub_topics.name: Predicting Reaction Direction Using Q
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing Q to K to predict whether a reaction will proceed forward (Q < K), reverse (Q > K), or is at equilibrium (Q = K).
example_tasks: Explain how to use Q and K to predict reaction direction. What happens when: (a) Q < K, (b) Q > K, (c) Q = K?
For a reaction with K = 100, calculate Q for the following mixtures and predict the direction of reaction: (a) Q = 10, (b) Q = 100, (c) Q = 1000
For N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g) with K = 0.50 at a certain temperature, a mixture has [N₂] = 0.10 M, [H₂] = 0.20 M, [NH₃] = 0.30 M. Calculate Q and predict which direction the reaction will proceed

sub_topics.name: Le Chatelier's Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that when a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to counteract the disturbance and establish a new equilibrium position.

sub_topics.name: Statement of Le Chatelier's Principle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that an equilibrium system responds to stress by shifting in the direction that relieves the stress, establishing a new equilibrium.
example_tasks: State Le Chatelier's Principle in your own words. What types of stresses can disturb an equilibrium system?
For the equilibrium N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), predict the shift when: (a) N₂ is added, (b) NH₃ is removed, (c) H₂ is added
Explain why Le Chatelier's Principle doesn't change the value of K—it only changes the equilibrium position (concentrations)

sub_topics.name: Effect of Concentration Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that adding reactants or removing products shifts equilibrium toward products (right), while adding products or removing reactants shifts toward reactants (left).
example_tasks: For the equilibrium A + B ⇌ C + D, predict the effect on equilibrium position when: (a) more A is added, (b) some C is removed, (c) more D is added
For the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), how would you shift the equilibrium to produce more SO₃? List three changes you could make
Explain why removing a product causes the equilibrium to shift toward products. Use Q vs K reasoning to support your answer

sub_topics.name: Effect of Pressure and Volume Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for gas-phase equilibria, increasing pressure (or decreasing volume) shifts toward the side with fewer moles of gas, while decreasing pressure shifts toward more moles.
example_tasks: For N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), predict the effect on equilibrium when pressure is increased. Which side has fewer moles of gas?
Explain why pressure changes only affect equilibria involving gases and only when there's a difference in the number of moles on each side
For the reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), what happens to the equilibrium position when: (a) volume is decreased, (b) pressure is increased? Explain

sub_topics.name: Effect of Temperature Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that temperature changes affect K: increasing T favors the endothermic direction, decreasing T favors the exothermic direction.
example_tasks: For the exothermic reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), ΔH = -92 kJ, predict the effect of: (a) increasing temperature, (b) decreasing temperature
Explain why temperature is the only factor that changes the value of K. How do other factors (concentration, pressure) differ?
For an endothermic reaction: A + B ⇌ C + D, ΔH = +50 kJ, how would you maximize the production of products? Should you heat or cool the system?

sub_topics.name: Effect of Catalysts on Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that catalysts speed up both forward and reverse reactions equally, allowing equilibrium to be reached faster but not changing the equilibrium position or K.
example_tasks: Explain how a catalyst affects an equilibrium system. Does it change the value of K or the equilibrium concentrations? What does it change?
Why do industrial processes often use catalysts even though they don't change the equilibrium position? What advantage do they provide?
For the Haber process (N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃), iron is used as a catalyst. Explain how this increases ammonia production even though K remains unchanged

sub_topics.name: Multiple Stresses and Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing systems with multiple simultaneous stresses and understanding how industrial processes optimize conditions to maximize desired products.
example_tasks: For N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), ΔH = -92 kJ, what conditions (temperature, pressure, concentrations) would maximize NH₃ production? Explain the trade-offs
Explain why the Haber process uses high pressure (favors products) but only moderate temperature (even though low T favors products). What's the practical consideration?
For the exothermic reaction A(g) + B(g) ⇌ 2C(g), design conditions to maximize production of C, considering: (a) temperature, (b) pressure, (c) use of catalyst, (d) removal of product

sub_topics.name: Applications of Equilibrium Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding industrial and biological applications of chemical equilibrium, including the Haber process, Contact process, and hemoglobin-oxygen binding.

sub_topics.name: Haber Process for Ammonia Production
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how Le Chatelier's Principle and equilibrium optimization are applied in the industrial synthesis of ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen.
example_tasks: Describe the Haber process: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), ΔH = -92 kJ. What conditions are used and why?
Explain why high pressure and moderate temperature with an iron catalyst represent the optimum compromise for ammonia production
Calculate the effect on equilibrium yield if pressure is doubled for the Haber process. Use Le Chatelier's Principle to explain

sub_topics.name: Contact Process for Sulfuric Acid
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the equilibrium 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g) in sulfuric acid production and how conditions are optimized.
example_tasks: Describe the key equilibrium step in the Contact process: 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), ΔH = -198 kJ. What conditions favor SO₃ production?
Explain why a V₂O₅ catalyst is essential in the Contact process even though it doesn't affect the equilibrium position
Discuss the trade-offs in the Contact process between equilibrium yield (favored by low T, high P) and reaction rate (favored by high T)

sub_topics.name: Equilibrium in Biological Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how equilibrium principles apply to biological processes such as oxygen transport by hemoglobin and acid-base balance in blood.
example_tasks: Describe the equilibrium: Hb + 4O₂ ⇌ Hb(O₂)₄. Explain how this equilibrium shifts in lungs (high [O₂]) versus tissues (low [O₂])
Explain how carbon monoxide poisoning disrupts oxygen transport: CO binds more strongly to hemoglobin than O₂, shifting the equilibrium
Describe the carbonic acid equilibrium in blood: CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻. How does this relate to blood pH regulation?

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Thermodynamics
grade_11_12.short_description: Deepening understanding of thermodynamics through entropy, Gibbs free energy, spontaneity, and the relationship between thermodynamics and equilibrium. Students learn to predict whether reactions are spontaneous and calculate equilibrium constants from thermodynamic data.

sub_topics.name: Enthalpy Review and Standard Enthalpies
sub_topics.short_description: Reviewing enthalpy concepts and using standard enthalpies of formation to calculate reaction enthalpies.

sub_topics.name: Applying Hess's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Using Hess's Law and standard enthalpies of formation to calculate ΔH°rxn for reactions: ΔH°rxn = ΣΔH°f(products) - ΣΔH°f(reactants).
example_tasks: Calculate ΔH°rxn for: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) using ΔH°f values: CH₄ = -74.8 kJ/mol, CO₂ = -393.5 kJ/mol, H₂O(l) = -285.8 kJ/mol, O₂ = 0 kJ/mol
Explain why the standard enthalpy of formation for any element in its standard state is zero. Give three examples
Use standard enthalpies of formation to calculate ΔH° for: 2NO(g) + O₂(g) → 2NO₂(g). ΔH°f: NO = 90.3 kJ/mol, NO₂ = 33.2 kJ/mol

sub_topics.name: Bond Enthalpies and Reaction Enthalpy
sub_topics.short_description: Using average bond enthalpies to estimate ΔH°rxn: ΔH°rxn = Σ(bonds broken) - Σ(bonds formed).
example_tasks: Estimate ΔH° for: H₂(g) + Cl₂(g) → 2HCl(g) using bond energies: H-H = 436 kJ/mol, Cl-Cl = 242 kJ/mol, H-Cl = 431 kJ/mol
Explain why bond breaking requires energy (endothermic) while bond formation releases energy (exothermic). How does this relate to overall reaction enthalpy?
Calculate the average C-H bond energy if the combustion of CH₄ releases 890 kJ/mol and you're given other relevant bond energies

sub_topics.name: Entropy (S) and the Second Law
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding entropy as a measure of disorder or dispersal of energy, and the Second Law stating that the total entropy of the universe always increases in spontaneous processes.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Entropy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding entropy (S) as a measure of the number of microstates (disorder) of a system, with higher entropy meaning more disorder or more ways to arrange energy.
example_tasks: Define entropy in your own words. Why is entropy sometimes described as a measure of 'disorder' or 'randomness'?
Compare the entropy of: (a) ice vs. liquid water, (b) liquid water vs. steam, (c) a tidy room vs. a messy room. Explain your rankings
Explain at the molecular level why entropy increases when ice melts. What changes about the water molecules?

sub_topics.name: Predicting Entropy Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors that increase entropy: phase changes (solid→liquid→gas), temperature increases, dissolving, and increasing number of particles.
example_tasks: Predict the sign of ΔS° for each process: (a) H₂O(l) → H₂O(g), (b) 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(l), (c) NaCl(s) → Na⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq)
Explain why entropy generally increases when: (a) a substance is heated, (b) a gas expands, (c) a solid dissolves in a liquid
For the reaction CaCO₃(s) → CaO(s) + CO₂(g), predict whether ΔS° is positive or negative. Explain your reasoning

sub_topics.name: Third Law and Standard Entropies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Third Law: a perfect crystal at 0 K has zero entropy, allowing absolute entropy values to be determined for substances.
example_tasks: State the Third Law of Thermodynamics. Why can we assign absolute entropy values (unlike enthalpy where we use ΔH°f)?
Explain why S° values are always positive, while ΔH°f values can be positive or negative
Compare standard entropy values: S°[H₂O(s)] = 45 J/(mol·K), S°[H₂O(l)] = 70 J/(mol·K), S°[H₂O(g)] = 189 J/(mol·K). Explain the trend

sub_topics.name: Calculating ΔS° for Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating standard entropy change using: ΔS°rxn = ΣS°(products) - ΣS°(reactants).
example_tasks: Calculate ΔS°rxn for: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) → 2NH₃(g) using S° values: N₂ = 192 J/(mol·K), H₂ = 131 J/(mol·K), NH₃ = 193 J/(mol·K)
For the reaction 2H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2H₂O(l), calculate ΔS°rxn. Given: S°[H₂(g)] = 131, S°[O₂(g)] = 205, S°[H₂O(l)] = 70 J/(mol·K). Why is ΔS° negative?
Explain why reactions that produce more gas molecules generally have positive ΔS° values. Give an example

sub_topics.name: Second Law of Thermodynamics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the total entropy of the universe (system + surroundings) always increases in spontaneous processes: ΔSuniverse = ΔSsystem + ΔSsurroundings > 0.
example_tasks: State the Second Law of Thermodynamics. What does it say about spontaneous processes?
Explain how it's possible for ΔSsystem to be negative (decrease in disorder) yet the process still be spontaneous. Give an example like freezing water
For an exothermic reaction where ΔSsystem < 0, explain how ΔSuniverse can still be positive (making the reaction spontaneous)

sub_topics.name: Gibbs Free Energy (G)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Gibbs free energy as the combination of enthalpy and entropy that determines spontaneity at constant temperature and pressure: ΔG = ΔH - TΔS.

sub_topics.name: Defining Gibbs Free Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Gibbs free energy as the energy available to do work, with ΔG < 0 indicating spontaneous processes, ΔG > 0 non-spontaneous, and ΔG = 0 equilibrium.
example_tasks: Define Gibbs free energy (G). What does the sign of ΔG tell you about a process?
Explain the relationship: ΔG = ΔH - TΔS. How do enthalpy and entropy contribute to spontaneity?
Classify processes as spontaneous, non-spontaneous, or at equilibrium: (a) ΔG = -50 kJ, (b) ΔG = +25 kJ, (c) ΔG = 0

sub_topics.name: Predicting Spontaneity from ΔH and ΔS
sub_topics.short_description: Using the signs of ΔH and ΔS to predict spontaneity at different temperatures based on ΔG = ΔH - TΔS.
example_tasks: Complete a table showing how ΔH and ΔS determine spontaneity: For each combination (ΔH<0, ΔS>0; ΔH<0, ΔS<0; ΔH>0, ΔS>0; ΔH>0, ΔS<0), state whether ΔG is negative (spontaneous), positive (non-spontaneous), or temperature-dependent
A reaction has ΔH° = -50 kJ and ΔS° = -100 J/K. At what temperature does it become non-spontaneous? Use ΔG = ΔH - TΔS
Explain why reactions with ΔH < 0 and ΔS > 0 are spontaneous at all temperatures, while reactions with ΔH > 0 and ΔS < 0 are never spontaneous

sub_topics.name: Standard Free Energy of Formation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ΔG°f and calculating ΔG°rxn using: ΔG°rxn = ΣΔG°f(products) - ΣΔG°f(reactants).
example_tasks: Define standard free energy of formation (ΔG°f). What is the ΔG°f for any element in its standard state?
Calculate ΔG°rxn for: CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(l) using: ΔG°f[CH₄] = -50.8, ΔG°f[CO₂] = -394.4, ΔG°f[H₂O(l)] = -237.2 kJ/mol
Calculate ΔG°rxn using ΔG°rxn = ΔH°rxn - TΔS°rxn for: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) → 2NH₃(g) at 298 K. Given: ΔH°rxn = -92 kJ, ΔS°rxn = -199 J/K

sub_topics.name: Temperature Dependence of ΔG
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how temperature affects spontaneity through the equation ΔG = ΔH - TΔS, with entropy term becoming more important at high temperatures.
example_tasks: For a reaction with ΔH° = +50 kJ and ΔS° = +200 J/K, calculate ΔG° at: (a) 298 K, (b) 500 K. At what temperature does the reaction become spontaneous?
Explain why endothermic reactions (ΔH > 0) can be spontaneous at high temperatures if they have positive ΔS
For CaCO₃(s) → CaO(s) + CO₂(g), ΔH° = +178 kJ, ΔS° = +160 J/K. Calculate the minimum temperature at which decomposition becomes spontaneous

sub_topics.name: Free Energy and Equilibrium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the relationship between Gibbs free energy and equilibrium constant through ΔG° = -RT ln K, connecting thermodynamics to equilibrium.

sub_topics.name: ΔG vs. ΔG° (Standard Free Energy)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that ΔG° is for standard conditions (1 M, 1 atm, 298 K) while ΔG depends on actual conditions, related by ΔG = ΔG° + RT ln Q.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between ΔG and ΔG°. Under what conditions does ΔG = ΔG°?
State the equation: ΔG = ΔG° + RT ln Q. Define each term and explain what Q represents
If ΔG° = -10 kJ for a reaction, what is ΔG when Q = 1? What about when Q = 100 at 298 K? (R = 8.314 J/(mol·K))

sub_topics.name: Relationship Between ΔG° and K
sub_topics.short_description: Using the equation ΔG° = -RT ln K to calculate equilibrium constants from thermodynamic data, connecting spontaneity to equilibrium position.
example_tasks: State the equation relating ΔG° and K: ΔG° = -RT ln K. What does this equation tell you about the relationship between spontaneity and equilibrium?
If ΔG° = -10 kJ at 298 K, calculate the equilibrium constant K using ΔG° = -RT ln K where R = 8.314 J/(mol·K)
Explain what ΔG° < 0 implies about K. If ΔG° is very negative, is K large or small? What does this mean about the equilibrium position?

sub_topics.name: ΔG and Reaction Progress
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that ΔG indicates the direction a reaction will proceed: ΔG < 0 (forward), ΔG > 0 (reverse), ΔG = 0 (equilibrium).
example_tasks: At equilibrium, what is the value of ΔG? Why? What is the relationship between Q and K at equilibrium?
If ΔG < 0, in which direction will the reaction proceed? What happens to Q as the reaction progresses?
Show that when Q = K, ΔG = 0 using the equation ΔG = ΔG° + RT ln Q and ΔG° = -RT ln K

sub_topics.name: Using Thermodynamics to Calculate K
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating equilibrium constants from ΔH° and ΔS° values using ΔG° = ΔH° - TΔS° = -RT ln K.
example_tasks: For N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), ΔH° = -92 kJ and ΔS° = -199 J/K at 298 K. Calculate: (a) ΔG°, (b) K
If a reaction has K = 1.0 × 10⁶ at 298 K, calculate ΔG°. Is the reaction spontaneous under standard conditions?
Explain the relationship: Large K (>>1) ⇔ ΔG° << 0 ⇔ Products strongly favored. Give an example

sub_topics.name: Coupled Reactions and Thermodynamic Favorability
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how non-spontaneous reactions can be driven by coupling them with spontaneous reactions, important in biological systems.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Coupled Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a non-spontaneous reaction (ΔG > 0) can be made to occur by coupling it with a highly spontaneous reaction (ΔG << 0) where ΔGtotal < 0.
example_tasks: Explain what is meant by 'coupled reactions.' How can a non-spontaneous process be driven forward?
