If reaction A has ΔG₁ = +20 kJ and reaction B has ΔG₂ = -50 kJ, what is ΔGtotal when they are coupled? Is the coupled process spontaneous?
Give an example of coupled reactions in biology: ATP hydrolysis (ΔG° = -31 kJ/mol) coupled with an endergonic biosynthesis reaction

sub_topics.name: ATP Hydrolysis in Biological Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ATP → ADP + Pi as the universal energy currency in cells, with ΔG° = -31 kJ/mol used to drive unfavorable reactions.
example_tasks: Write the equation for ATP hydrolysis and state its ΔG° value. Why is ATP called the 'energy currency' of the cell?
Explain how ATP hydrolysis can drive the synthesis of proteins or other molecules that would not occur spontaneously
Calculate whether ATP hydrolysis can drive a reaction with ΔG° = +25 kJ/mol. What is ΔGtotal for the coupled process?

grade_11_12.name: Electrochemistry
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding oxidation-reduction reactions, electrochemical cells, cell potentials, and the relationship between electricity and chemical reactions. Students learn to balance redox reactions, calculate cell potentials, and understand batteries, electrolysis, and corrosion.

sub_topics.name: Oxidation-Reduction (Redox) Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electron transfer in redox reactions, oxidation states, and identifying oxidizing and reducing agents.

sub_topics.name: Defining Oxidation and Reduction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding oxidation as loss of electrons (increase in oxidation state) and reduction as gain of electrons (decrease in oxidation state): OIL RIG or LEO says GER.
example_tasks: Define oxidation and reduction in terms of electron transfer. Which process involves loss of electrons?
Use the mnemonic 'OIL RIG' (Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain) to identify the oxidized and reduced species in: Zn + Cu²⁺ → Zn²⁺ + Cu
Explain why oxidation and reduction must occur simultaneously in redox reactions. Can you have one without the other?

sub_topics.name: Assigning Oxidation States
sub_topics.short_description: Learning rules for assigning oxidation numbers to atoms in compounds and using oxidation states to identify redox reactions.
example_tasks: State the rules for assigning oxidation states. What is the oxidation state of: (a) any element in its standard state, (b) oxygen in most compounds, (c) hydrogen in most compounds?
Assign oxidation states to all atoms in: H₂SO₄, NO₃⁻, Cr₂O₇²⁻, and MnO₄⁻
For the reaction: 2Fe²⁺ + Cl₂ → 2Fe³⁺ + 2Cl⁻, identify: (a) which species is oxidized, (b) which is reduced, (c) the change in oxidation state for each

sub_topics.name: Oxidizing and Reducing Agents
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the oxidizing agent is reduced (gains electrons) and the reducing agent is oxidized (loses electrons).
example_tasks: Define oxidizing agent and reducing agent. In the reaction Zn + Cu²⁺ → Zn²⁺ + Cu, identify each
Explain the statement: 'The oxidizing agent gets reduced and the reducing agent gets oxidized.' Why is this true?
For the reaction: 2Al + 3Cl₂ → 2AlCl₃, identify: (a) the oxidizing agent, (b) the reducing agent, (c) what is oxidized, (d) what is reduced

sub_topics.name: Identifying Redox Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Using changes in oxidation states to determine whether a reaction is a redox reaction or not.
example_tasks: Determine which of the following are redox reactions by checking for changes in oxidation states: (a) 2Na + Cl₂ → 2NaCl, (b) HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O, (c) 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂
Explain why acid-base neutralization reactions are not redox reactions. Do oxidation states change?
For the reaction: MnO₄⁻ + 5Fe²⁺ + 8H⁺ → Mn²⁺ + 5Fe³⁺ + 4H₂O, show that this is a redox reaction by identifying oxidation state changes

sub_topics.name: Balancing Redox Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Learning systematic methods for balancing redox equations in acidic and basic solutions using the half-reaction method.

sub_topics.name: Half-Reaction Method
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that redox reactions can be split into oxidation and reduction half-reactions, balanced separately, then recombined.
example_tasks: Define a half-reaction. For the reaction Fe²⁺ + MnO₄⁻ → Fe³⁺ + Mn²⁺ (in acid), write separate half-reactions for: (a) oxidation, (b) reduction
Explain why electrons must balance when combining half-reactions. What mathematical operation ensures this?
For the half-reaction Cl₂ → 2Cl⁻, add electrons to balance the charge. Is this oxidation or reduction?

sub_topics.name: Balancing Redox Equations in Acidic Solution
sub_topics.short_description: Using the half-reaction method in acidic solution: balance atoms (except O and H), add H₂O for O, add H⁺ for H, add electrons, equalize electrons, combine.
example_tasks: Balance the following redox equation in acidic solution using the half-reaction method: MnO₄⁻ + Fe²⁺ → Mn²⁺ + Fe³⁺
Balance in acidic solution: Cr₂O₇²⁻ + Cl⁻ → Cr³⁺ + Cl₂. Show all steps including electron balance
List the steps for balancing redox equations in acidic solution. Why do we add H₂O and H⁺?

sub_topics.name: Balancing Redox Equations in Basic Solution
sub_topics.short_description: Balancing in basic solution by first balancing as if in acid, then adding OH⁻ to both sides to neutralize H⁺, simplifying H₂O.
example_tasks: Balance the following in basic solution: MnO₄⁻ + I⁻ → MnO₂ + I₂. First balance in acid, then convert to base
Explain why we add OH⁻ to neutralize H⁺ when balancing redox equations in basic solution. What forms when H⁺ + OH⁻ combine?
Balance in basic solution: Cr(OH)₃ + ClO⁻ → CrO₄²⁻ + Cl⁻. Show all steps

sub_topics.name: Electrochemical Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding galvanic (voltaic) cells that convert chemical energy to electrical energy through spontaneous redox reactions, including cell notation and components.

sub_topics.name: Galvanic (Voltaic) Cells
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cells where spontaneous redox reactions generate electrical current, with oxidation at the anode and reduction at the cathode.
example_tasks: Define a galvanic (voltaic) cell. What type of redox reaction occurs in these cells—spontaneous or non-spontaneous?
Draw and label a diagram of a galvanic cell with zinc and copper electrodes. Include: anode, cathode, salt bridge, direction of electron flow, and ion migration
For a Zn/Cu galvanic cell, write the half-reactions at each electrode: (a) anode (oxidation), (b) cathode (reduction), (c) overall cell reaction

sub_topics.name: Anode and Cathode
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that oxidation occurs at the anode (negative electrode in galvanic cells) and reduction occurs at the cathode (positive electrode), remembered as 'An Ox, Red Cat'.
example_tasks: Use the mnemonic 'An Ox, Red Cat' to remember: oxidation at anode, reduction at cathode. Why is the anode negative in a galvanic cell?
In a galvanic cell, which electrode loses mass and which gains mass? Explain using a Zn/Cu cell as an example
Explain the direction of electron flow in a galvanic cell. Do electrons flow from anode to cathode or cathode to anode?

sub_topics.name: Function of Salt Bridge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that a salt bridge maintains electrical neutrality by allowing ion migration between half-cells, preventing charge buildup.
example_tasks: Explain the purpose of a salt bridge in a galvanic cell. What would happen without it?
Describe how ions migrate through the salt bridge. Do anions move toward the anode or cathode?
In a Zn/Cu cell, if the salt bridge contains KNO₃, describe which ions migrate to each half-cell and why

sub_topics.name: Cell Notation (Line Notation)
sub_topics.short_description: Using standard cell notation to represent galvanic cells: anode | anode solution || cathode solution | cathode, with single lines for phase boundaries and double lines for salt bridge.
example_tasks: Write the cell notation for a Zn/Cu galvanic cell where Zn²⁺ and Cu²⁺ concentrations are both 1.0 M
Interpret the cell notation: Pt(s) | Fe²⁺(aq), Fe³⁺(aq) || Ag⁺(aq) | Ag(s). Identify the anode, cathode, and write the overall cell reaction
Explain what the single vertical line (|) and double vertical line (||) represent in cell notation

sub_topics.name: Cell Potential and Standard Reduction Potentials
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding cell potential (voltage) as a measure of the driving force for electron transfer, calculated from standard reduction potentials.

sub_topics.name: Standard Reduction Potentials (E°)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that each half-reaction has a standard reduction potential measured relative to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE, defined as 0.00 V).
example_tasks: Define standard reduction potential (E°). What are the standard conditions (concentrations, temperature, pressure)?
Explain what the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) is and why it's assigned E° = 0.00 V. What half-reaction does it represent?
Given E° values: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu, E° = +0.34 V; Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Zn, E° = -0.76 V. Which species is more easily reduced? Which is a stronger oxidizing agent?

sub_topics.name: Calculating Standard Cell Potential (E°cell)
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating E°cell using E°cell = E°cathode - E°anode, where cathode undergoes reduction and anode undergoes oxidation (reverse of its reduction potential).
example_tasks: State the equation for calculating E°cell. For a Zn/Cu cell, calculate E°cell using: E°(Cu²⁺/Cu) = +0.34 V, E°(Zn²⁺/Zn) = -0.76 V
Explain why we subtract the anode potential from the cathode potential. What does a positive E°cell indicate?
Calculate E°cell for a cell where Ag⁺/Ag (E° = +0.80 V) is the cathode and Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = -0.44 V) is the anode

sub_topics.name: Relationship Between E°cell and Spontaneity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that E°cell > 0 indicates a spontaneous reaction (galvanic cell), E°cell < 0 indicates non-spontaneous (requires external voltage), related to ΔG° by ΔG° = -nFE°.
example_tasks: Explain the relationship between E°cell and spontaneity. What does E°cell > 0 tell you about the reaction?
State the equation relating ΔG° and E°cell: ΔG° = -nFE°, where n = moles of electrons and F = Faraday's constant (96,485 C/mol). Calculate ΔG° for a cell with E°cell = +1.10 V and n = 2
If E°cell is negative, can the reaction proceed spontaneously? What would be required to make it occur?

sub_topics.name: Predicting Redox Reactions Using E° Values
sub_topics.short_description: Using standard reduction potentials to predict which direction a redox reaction will proceed spontaneously and to compare oxidizing/reducing agent strengths.
example_tasks: Given E° values for: Ag⁺/Ag (+0.80 V), Cu²⁺/Cu (+0.34 V), Zn²⁺/Zn (-0.76 V). Predict whether Ag⁺ will oxidize Cu metal. Calculate E°cell
Rank the following as oxidizing agents from strongest to weakest using E° values: F₂/F⁻ (+2.87 V), Cl₂/Cl⁻ (+1.36 V), Br₂/Br⁻ (+1.07 V)
Use E° values to predict whether the reaction: 2Al + 3Cu²⁺ → 2Al³⁺ + 3Cu will occur spontaneously. E°(Cu²⁺/Cu) = +0.34 V, E°(Al³⁺/Al) = -1.66 V

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Acid-Base Chemistry
grade_11_12.short_description: Deepening understanding of acid-base equilibria, buffer systems, polyprotic acids, titration curves, and acid-base indicators. Students learn to calculate pH in complex systems and understand biological and industrial buffer applications.

sub_topics.name: Brønsted-Lowry Acid-Base Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding acids as proton (H⁺) donors and bases as proton acceptors, expanding beyond Arrhenius theory to include non-aqueous systems and amphiprotic species.

sub_topics.name: Brønsted-Lowry Definitions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that Brønsted-Lowry acids donate protons (H⁺) and bases accept protons, applicable to any solvent, not just water.
example_tasks: Define Brønsted-Lowry acids and bases. How does this definition expand upon the Arrhenius definition?
For the reaction HCl + NH₃ → NH₄⁺ + Cl⁻, identify the Brønsted-Lowry acid and base. Show the proton transfer
Explain why NH₃ is a Brønsted-Lowry base even though it doesn't contain OH⁻. What happens when NH₃ accepts a proton?

sub_topics.name: Conjugate Acid-Base Pairs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that acids and bases exist in conjugate pairs, differing by one proton: acid ⇌ conjugate base + H⁺; base + H⁺ ⇌ conjugate acid.
example_tasks: Define conjugate acid-base pair. For the reaction: HF + H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + F⁻, identify both conjugate acid-base pairs
Write the formula for the conjugate base of: (a) HNO₃, (b) H₂SO₄, (c) H₂PO₄⁻. Write the formula for the conjugate acid of: (d) NH₃, (e) OH⁻, (f) HCO₃⁻
Explain the relationship: strong acids have weak conjugate bases, weak acids have strong conjugate bases. Use HCl/Cl⁻ and CH₃COOH/CH₃COO⁻ as examples

sub_topics.name: Amphiprotic Species
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that amphiprotic species can act as either acids or bases depending on what they react with, such as water, HCO₃⁻, and HSO₄⁻.
example_tasks: Define amphiprotic (or amphoteric). Give three examples of amphiprotic species
Show that HCO₃⁻ is amphiprotic by writing two reactions: (a) HCO₃⁻ acting as an acid with OH⁻, (b) HCO₃⁻ acting as a base with H₃O⁺
Explain why water is amphiprotic. Write equations showing H₂O acting as: (a) an acid with NH₃, (b) a base with HCl

sub_topics.name: Water Ionization and pH Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the autoionization of water, the ion-product constant (Kw), and advanced pH, pOH, pKa, and pKb calculations.

sub_topics.name: Autoionization of Water
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that water undergoes autoionization: 2H₂O ⇌ H₃O⁺ + OH⁻, with Kw = [H₃O⁺][OH⁻] = 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25°C.
example_tasks: Write the equation for autoionization of water and the expression for Kw. What is the value of Kw at 25°C?
Calculate [OH⁻] in pure water at 25°C. Why are [H₃O⁺] and [OH⁻] both equal to 1.0 × 10⁻⁷ M?
If [H₃O⁺] = 1.0 × 10⁻³ M in a solution, calculate [OH⁻] using Kw. Is this solution acidic, basic, or neutral?

sub_topics.name: pH Calculations for Strong Acids and Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating pH for strong acids and bases that ionize completely, directly converting concentration to [H₃O⁺] or [OH⁻].
example_tasks: Calculate the pH of 0.010 M HCl solution. Explain why [H₃O⁺] equals the initial HCl concentration
Calculate the pH of 0.050 M NaOH solution. First find pOH, then use pH + pOH = 14
Calculate the pH of a solution made by diluting 25.0 mL of 0.10 M HNO₃ to 250.0 mL

sub_topics.name: Acid Dissociation Constant (Ka) and Base Dissociation Constant (Kb)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Ka as the equilibrium constant for acid ionization and Kb for base ionization, with larger values indicating stronger acids/bases.
example_tasks: Write the Ka expression for acetic acid: CH₃COOH ⇌ H⁺ + CH₃COO⁻. What does a large Ka value indicate?
Write the Kb expression for ammonia: NH₃ + H₂O ⇌ NH₄⁺ + OH⁻. Explain what Kb measures
Compare two weak acids: Ka₁ = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵ and Ka₂ = 6.3 × 10⁻⁸. Which is the stronger acid? Which ionizes to a greater extent?

sub_topics.name: pH Calculations for Weak Acids and Bases
sub_topics.short_description: Using Ka or Kb with ICE tables to calculate pH for weak acids and bases that only partially ionize.
example_tasks: Calculate the pH of 0.10 M acetic acid (Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵). Use an ICE table and the small x approximation if valid
Calculate the pH of 0.25 M ammonia solution (Kb = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵). First calculate [OH⁻], then pOH, then pH
A weak acid has Ka = 5.0 × 10⁻⁶. If a 0.50 M solution has pH = 2.85, verify that the Ka value is correct

sub_topics.name: Percent Ionization
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the percent of acid molecules that ionize: % ionization = ([H⁺]/[HA]initial) × 100%, which decreases as concentration increases.
example_tasks: Define percent ionization. For 0.10 M acetic acid with [H⁺] = 1.3 × 10⁻³ M at equilibrium, calculate the percent ionization
Explain why percent ionization decreases as the concentration of a weak acid increases (Le Chatelier's Principle)
Calculate the percent ionization of 0.50 M HF (Ka = 6.8 × 10⁻⁴). Compare with percent ionization if the solution were diluted to 0.050 M

sub_topics.name: Relationship Between Ka and Kb for Conjugate Pairs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for a conjugate acid-base pair: Ka × Kb = Kw = 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25°C.
example_tasks: State the relationship between Ka and Kb for a conjugate acid-base pair. Derive it from the equilibrium expressions
If Ka for CH₃COOH is 1.8 × 10⁻⁵, calculate Kb for CH₃COO⁻ using Ka × Kb = Kw
Ammonia has Kb = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵. Calculate Ka for the ammonium ion (NH₄⁺)

sub_topics.name: pKa and pKb
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pKa = -log Ka and pKb = -log Kb as convenient ways to express acid/base strength, with pKa + pKb = 14 for conjugate pairs.
example_tasks: Define pKa and pKb. If Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵, calculate pKa
Explain the relationship: pKa + pKb = 14 for conjugate acid-base pairs. Verify this using acetic acid (pKa = 4.74) and acetate (pKb = 9.26)
Rank the following acids from strongest to weakest based on their pKa values: Acid A (pKa = 3.2), Acid B (pKa = 7.5), Acid C (pKa = 4.8)

sub_topics.name: Buffer Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding buffer systems that resist pH changes through equilibria between weak acids/bases and their conjugate pairs, including buffer capacity and the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

sub_topics.name: Buffer Concept and Composition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that buffers consist of a weak acid and its conjugate base (or weak base and conjugate acid) that resist pH changes when small amounts of acid or base are added.
example_tasks: Define a buffer solution. What two components are required for an acidic buffer? For a basic buffer?
Explain how a buffer resists pH change when: (a) a small amount of strong acid is added, (b) a small amount of strong base is added. Use CH₃COOH/CH₃COO⁻ as an example
Give three examples of buffer systems: one acidic buffer, one basic buffer, and one biological buffer

sub_topics.name: Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Using the equation pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]) to calculate buffer pH from concentrations or to design buffers with specific pH values.
example_tasks: State the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation and define each term. When is this equation most useful?
Calculate the pH of a buffer containing 0.50 M CH₃COOH and 0.25 M CH₃COO⁻. (pKa of CH₃COOH = 4.74)
Design a buffer with pH = 5.00 using acetic acid (pKa = 4.74). What ratio of [CH₃COO⁻]/[CH₃COOH] is needed?

sub_topics.name: Buffer Capacity and Range
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that buffer capacity (amount of acid/base that can be neutralized) depends on concentrations, and buffers work best when pH ≈ pKa (within pH = pKa ± 1).
example_tasks: Define buffer capacity. Compare the buffer capacity of: (a) 0.10 M CH₃COOH/0.10 M CH₃COO⁻ vs. (b) 1.0 M CH₃COOH/1.0 M CH₃COO⁻
Explain the buffer range rule: buffers are effective when pH = pKa ± 1. Why does this range exist?
A buffer has pKa = 7.2. Over what pH range will this buffer be most effective? Would it be a good choice for maintaining pH 5.0?

sub_topics.name: Buffer Calculations with Added Acid or Base
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating pH changes when strong acid or base is added to a buffer, treating the neutralization reaction first, then using Henderson-Hasselbalch.
example_tasks: A buffer contains 0.50 M CH₃COOH and 0.50 M CH₃COO⁻ (pKa = 4.74). Calculate the pH after adding 0.10 mol HCl to 1.0 L of this buffer
For the same buffer as above, calculate the pH after adding 0.10 mol NaOH to 1.0 L of buffer
Compare the pH change in the buffer (previous problem) with the pH change if the same amount of acid were added to 1.0 L of pure water. Demonstrate the buffer's effectiveness

sub_topics.name: Preparing Buffer Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding methods to prepare buffers: mixing weak acid with its salt, or partially neutralizing a weak acid with strong base.
example_tasks: Describe two methods to prepare an acetic acid/acetate buffer: (a) mixing CH₃COOH with NaCH₃COO, (b) adding NaOH to CH₃COOH
Calculate how many grams of sodium acetate (NaCH₃COO, MW = 82.0 g/mol) must be added to 500 mL of 0.20 M acetic acid to prepare a buffer with pH = 5.00 (pKa = 4.74)
You have 100 mL of 0.50 M NH₃ (Kb = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵). How many mL of 0.50 M HCl should be added to create a buffer with pH = 9.00?

sub_topics.name: Biological Buffer Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding important biological buffers including the carbonic acid-bicarbonate system in blood and phosphate buffers in cells.
example_tasks: Describe the carbonic acid-bicarbonate buffer system in blood: H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻. How does it maintain blood pH at 7.4?
Explain how hyperventilation (increased breathing rate) affects blood pH through the carbonic acid equilibrium: CO₂ + H₂O ⇌ H₂CO₃ ⇌ H⁺ + HCO₃⁻
Describe the phosphate buffer system: H₂PO₄⁻ ⇌ H⁺ + HPO₄²⁻ (pKa = 7.2). Why is this an effective intracellular buffer?

sub_topics.name: Polyprotic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding acids that can donate more than one proton, with multiple Ka values and stepwise ionization, such as H₂SO₄, H₃PO₄, and H₂CO₃.

sub_topics.name: Stepwise Ionization of Polyprotic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that polyprotic acids ionize in steps, with each step having its own Ka value, and Ka1 >> Ka2 >> Ka3.
example_tasks: Define polyprotic acid. Write the three ionization steps for phosphoric acid (H₃PO₄) with their corresponding Ka expressions
Explain why Ka1 > Ka2 > Ka3 for polyprotic acids. Why does it become progressively harder to remove each successive proton?
For sulfuric acid, H₂SO₄, the first ionization is complete (strong acid) but the second is not: HSO₄⁻ ⇌ H⁺ + SO₄²⁻ (Ka2 = 1.2 × 10⁻²). Explain this difference

sub_topics.name: pH Calculations for Polyprotic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating pH of polyprotic acid solutions by considering primarily the first ionization when Ka1 >> Ka2.
example_tasks: Calculate the pH of 0.10 M H₂CO₃ solution. Ka1 = 4.3 × 10⁻⁷, Ka2 = 5.6 × 10⁻¹¹. Why can you ignore the second ionization for pH calculation?
For 0.10 M H₃PO₄ (Ka1 = 7.5 × 10⁻³), calculate: (a) pH, (b) [H₂PO₄⁻], (c) [HPO₄²⁻]. Explain why [HPO₄²⁻] is much smaller than [H₂PO₄⁻]
Explain the general approximation for polyprotic acids: if Ka1 >> Ka2, then [H⁺] from the first ionization dominates the pH

sub_topics.name: Amphiprotic Ions from Polyprotic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that intermediate ions (like HCO₃⁻ or H₂PO₄⁻) are amphiprotic, with pH calculated from pH = ½(pKa1 + pKa2).
example_tasks: Show that HCO₃⁻ is amphiprotic by writing equations where it acts as: (a) an acid, (b) a base
Calculate the pH of 0.10 M NaHCO₃ solution using pH = ½(pKa1 + pKa2). For H₂CO₃: pKa1 = 6.37, pKa2 = 10.25
Explain why a solution of NaH₂PO₄ is acidic while a solution of Na₂HPO₄ is basic. Consider their Ka and Kb values

sub_topics.name: Advanced Acid-Base Titrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding titration curves, equivalence points, buffer regions, and selecting appropriate indicators for strong-strong, strong-weak, and weak-weak titrations.

sub_topics.name: Titration Curves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding pH vs. volume graphs for titrations, identifying initial pH, buffer region, equivalence point, and endpoint features.
example_tasks: Sketch and label a titration curve for strong acid-strong base titration (e.g., HCl with NaOH). Label: initial pH, equivalence point, steep rise region
Describe the four regions of a weak acid-strong base titration curve: (a) before titration begins, (b) buffer region, (c) equivalence point, (d) after equivalence point
Explain why the equivalence point for a strong acid-strong base titration occurs at pH = 7, while for a weak acid-strong base titration it occurs at pH > 7

sub_topics.name: Strong Acid-Strong Base Titrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that equivalence point is at pH = 7 since conjugate acid and base are neutral, with steep vertical region around equivalence point.
example_tasks: Calculate the pH at the equivalence point when 25.0 mL of 0.10 M HCl is titrated with 0.10 M NaOH. Explain why pH = 7
For the titration of 50.0 mL of 0.10 M HNO₃ with 0.10 M KOH, calculate the pH after adding: (a) 0 mL, (b) 25.0 mL, (c) 50.0 mL (equivalence point), (d) 75.0 mL
Explain why almost any indicator with a transition range near pH 7 is suitable for strong acid-strong base titrations

sub_topics.name: Weak Acid-Strong Base Titrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that equivalence point is at pH > 7 due to hydrolysis of conjugate base, with buffer region before equivalence point and pH = pKa at half-equivalence point.
example_tasks: Explain why the equivalence point for a weak acid-strong base titration occurs at pH > 7. What species is present at equivalence point?
For titrating 25.0 mL of 0.10 M CH₃COOH (Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵) with 0.10 M NaOH, calculate the pH at: (a) 0 mL added, (b) 12.5 mL added (half-equivalence point), (c) 25.0 mL (equivalence point)
Explain why pH = pKa at the half-equivalence point of a weak acid titration. Use the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation to justify

sub_topics.name: Weak Base-Strong Acid Titrations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that equivalence point is at pH < 7 due to hydrolysis of conjugate acid, with buffer region before equivalence point.
example_tasks: Explain why the equivalence point for a weak base-strong acid titration occurs at pH < 7. What species predominates at equivalence point?
For titrating 30.0 mL of 0.15 M NH₃ (Kb = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵) with 0.15 M HCl, predict whether the pH at equivalence point will be acidic, basic, or neutral. Explain
Calculate the pH at the half-equivalence point when titrating ammonia with HCl. How does this relate to pKb?

sub_topics.name: Titration of Polyprotic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that polyprotic acid titrations show multiple equivalence points corresponding to each ionizable proton, if Ka values differ sufficiently.
example_tasks: Sketch the titration curve for H₃PO₄ with NaOH. How many equivalence points are there? Label each
For the titration of H₂CO₃ with NaOH, explain why there are two distinct equivalence points. What species predominates at each?
Calculate the volume of 0.10 M NaOH needed to reach: (a) the first equivalence point, (b) the second equivalence point, when titrating 25.0 mL of 0.10 M H₂SO₄

sub_topics.name: Selecting Appropriate Indicators
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing indicators whose transition range (pKa ± 1) matches the pH at the equivalence point of the titration.
example_tasks: Explain how to select an appropriate indicator for a titration. What should match between the indicator and the titration?
For a weak acid-strong base titration with equivalence point at pH 8.7, which indicator would be best: bromothymol blue (pH 6.0-7.6), phenolphthalein (pH 8.3-10.0), or methyl red (pH 4.2-6.3)?
Create a table of three indicators (methyl orange, bromothymol blue, phenolphthalein) showing their pH transition ranges and the type of titration each is best suited for

sub_topics.name: Acid-Base Properties of Salts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that salts can produce acidic, basic, or neutral solutions depending on the relative strengths of their parent acids and bases.

sub_topics.name: Hydrolysis and pH of Salt Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that cations from weak bases (like NH₄⁺) make solutions acidic, anions from weak acids (like CH₃COO⁻) make solutions basic, and salts from strong acids/bases are neutral.
example_tasks: Predict whether each salt solution is acidic, basic, or neutral: (a) NaCl, (b) NH₄Cl, (c) NaCH₃COO, (d) KNO₃, (e) Na₂CO₃
Explain why a solution of NaCH₃COO is basic. Write the hydrolysis equation for the acetate ion
Calculate the pH of 0.10 M NH₄Cl solution. Ka for NH₄⁺ = 5.6 × 10⁻¹⁰. Use an ICE table

sub_topics.name: Classifying Salts by pH
sub_topics.short_description: Using rules to predict salt solution pH: strong acid + strong base → neutral; weak acid + strong base → basic; strong acid + weak base → acidic; weak acid + weak base → compare Ka and Kb.
example_tasks: Create a chart showing how to predict whether a salt solution is acidic, basic, or neutral based on the strengths of the parent acid and base
For the salt NH₄CH₃COO (from weak acid and weak base), predict the pH by comparing Ka of NH₄⁺ (5.6 × 10⁻¹⁰) with Kb of CH₃COO⁻ (5.6 × 10⁻¹⁰)
Explain why FeCl₃ produces an acidic solution. Consider the hydrolysis of Fe³⁺: Fe(H₂O)₆³⁺ ⇌ Fe(H₂O)₅OH²⁺ + H⁺

sub_topics.name: Lewis Acid-Base Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the broadest acid-base definition where Lewis acids are electron-pair acceptors and Lewis bases are electron-pair donors, applicable to non-proton-transfer reactions.

sub_topics.name: Lewis Acid-Base Definitions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that Lewis acids accept electron pairs (often have empty orbitals) and Lewis bases donate electron pairs (have lone pairs).
example_tasks: Define Lewis acid and Lewis base. How is this definition broader than Brønsted-Lowry?
For the reaction BF₃ + NH₃ → F₃B-NH₃, identify the Lewis acid and Lewis base. Show the electron pair donation
Explain why all Brønsted-Lowry bases are Lewis bases, but not all Lewis bases are Brønsted-Lowry bases. Give an example of a Lewis base that isn't a Brønsted-Lowry base

sub_topics.name: Lewis Acid-Base Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying Lewis acid-base reactions including complex ion formation, reactions of metal ions, and reactions not involving proton transfer.
example_tasks: For the reaction Ag⁺ + 2NH₃ → Ag(NH₃)₂⁺, identify the Lewis acid and Lewis base. Explain the coordinate covalent bond formation
Identify the Lewis acid and base in: Cu²⁺ + 4H₂O → Cu(H₂O)₄²⁺. Why is Cu²⁺ a Lewis acid?
Give three examples of Lewis acids that are not Brønsted-Lowry acids: metal cations, molecules with incomplete octets, and molecules with available empty d orbitals

grade_11_12.name: Solubility Equilibria
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding the equilibrium between ionic solids and their dissolved ions, solubility product constant (Ksp), predicting precipitation, common ion effect, and selective precipitation. Students learn quantitative aspects of ionic compound dissolution.

sub_topics.name: Solubility Product Constant (Ksp)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Ksp as the equilibrium constant for the dissolution of sparingly soluble ionic compounds, with larger Ksp indicating greater solubility.

sub_topics.name: Writing Ksp Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Writing Ksp expressions for dissolution equilibria of ionic compounds, with products raised to powers equal to their stoichiometric coefficients.
example_tasks: Write the dissolution equation and Ksp expression for: (a) AgCl, (b) CaF₂, (c) Ag₂CrO₄
For the equilibrium PbI₂(s) ⇌ Pb²⁺(aq) + 2I⁻(aq), write the Ksp expression. Explain why the solid PbI₂ doesn't appear in the expression
Write Ksp expressions for: (a) Ca₃(PO₄)₂, (b) Fe(OH)₃, (c) Ag₂S. What are the powers on each ion concentration?

sub_topics.name: Interpreting Ksp Magnitude
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that larger Ksp values generally indicate higher solubility, though direct comparison requires considering stoichiometry.
example_tasks: Compare the Ksp values: AgCl (1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) and AgBr (5.0 × 10⁻¹³). Which compound is more soluble?
Explain why you cannot directly compare Ksp values for AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) and CaF₂ (Ksp = 3.9 × 10⁻¹¹) to determine which is more soluble
Rank the following in order of increasing solubility based on Ksp values: BaSO₄ (Ksp = 1.1 × 10⁻¹⁰), PbSO₄ (Ksp = 1.6 × 10⁻⁸), Ag₂SO₄ (Ksp = 1.4 × 10⁻⁵)

sub_topics.name: Calculating Solubility from Ksp
sub_topics.short_description: Using Ksp values and ICE tables to calculate molar solubility (mol/L) or solubility in g/L for sparingly soluble compounds.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Molar Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Using Ksp to calculate molar solubility (moles of compound that dissolve per liter), setting up ICE tables based on dissolution stoichiometry.
example_tasks: Calculate the molar solubility of AgCl in pure water given Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰. Set up an ICE table for AgCl(s) ⇌ Ag⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq)
Calculate the molar solubility of CaF₂ (Ksp = 3.9 × 10⁻¹¹). Note that if solubility = s, then [Ca²⁺] = s and [F⁻] = 2s
For Ag₂CrO₄ with Ksp = 1.2 × 10⁻¹², calculate the molar solubility. Express [Ag⁺] and [CrO₄²⁻] in terms of s

sub_topics.name: Converting Between Molar Solubility and Solubility in g/L
sub_topics.short_description: Converting molar solubility to grams per liter using molar mass, and vice versa.
example_tasks: If the molar solubility of PbI₂ is 1.5 × 10⁻³ M, calculate the solubility in g/L. (Molar mass of PbI₂ = 461 g/mol)
The solubility of BaSO₄ is 2.3 × 10⁻³ g/L. Calculate: (a) the molar solubility, (b) Ksp. (Molar mass = 233 g/mol)
Calculate the mass of AgCl that will dissolve in 500 mL of water given Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰

sub_topics.name: Calculating Ksp from Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Using measured solubility data to calculate Ksp values by determining ion concentrations at equilibrium.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Ksp from Molar Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Converting molar solubility to ion concentrations, then substituting into the Ksp expression.
example_tasks: The molar solubility of PbCl₂ is 1.6 × 10⁻² M. Calculate Ksp for PbCl₂(s) ⇌ Pb²⁺(aq) + 2Cl⁻(aq)
If 6.5 × 10⁻⁴ mol of Ag₂CO₃ dissolves in 1.0 L of water, calculate Ksp. What are [Ag⁺] and [CO₃²⁻] at equilibrium?
The solubility of CaF₂ is 0.017 g/L. Calculate: (a) molar solubility, (b) [Ca²⁺] and [F⁻] at equilibrium, (c) Ksp

sub_topics.name: Predicting Precipitation
sub_topics.short_description: Using the reaction quotient (Q) and comparing it to Ksp to predict whether a precipitate will form when solutions are mixed.

sub_topics.name: Using Q to Predict Precipitation
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating Q using initial ion concentrations and comparing to Ksp: if Q > Ksp, precipitation occurs; if Q < Ksp, no precipitate; if Q = Ksp, at equilibrium.
example_tasks: Explain how to predict precipitation by comparing Q and Ksp. What happens when: (a) Q > Ksp, (b) Q < Ksp, (c) Q = Ksp?
Will a precipitate form when 50 mL of 0.002 M AgNO₃ is mixed with 50 mL of 0.002 M NaCl? Ksp(AgCl) = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰. Calculate Q and compare
Calculate whether BaSO₄ precipitates when 100 mL of 0.001 M Ba(NO₃)₂ is mixed with 100 mL of 0.001 M Na₂SO₄. Ksp(BaSO₄) = 1.1 × 10⁻¹⁰

sub_topics.name: Calculating Minimum Concentration for Precipitation
sub_topics.short_description: Determining the minimum ion concentration needed to initiate precipitation using Ksp.
example_tasks: Calculate the minimum [Cl⁻] needed to precipitate AgCl from a solution where [Ag⁺] = 0.010 M. Ksp(AgCl) = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰
What minimum [OH⁻] is required to precipitate Mg(OH)₂ from a solution with [Mg²⁺] = 0.050 M? Ksp(Mg(OH)₂) = 1.8 × 10⁻¹¹
Calculate the maximum [Pb²⁺] that can exist in solution with [I⁻] = 0.020 M without precipitating PbI₂. Ksp = 7.1 × 10⁻⁹

sub_topics.name: Common Ion Effect
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the solubility of an ionic compound decreases when a common ion is added, due to Le Chatelier's Principle shifting equilibrium.

sub_topics.name: Effect on Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that adding a common ion (from another source) decreases the solubility of a sparingly soluble salt by shifting equilibrium toward the solid.
example_tasks: Explain the common ion effect using Le Chatelier's Principle. For AgCl(s) ⇌ Ag⁺ + Cl⁻, what happens to solubility if NaCl is added?
Calculate the molar solubility of AgCl in 0.10 M NaCl solution. Compare with solubility in pure water. Ksp(AgCl) = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰
The molar solubility of PbCl₂ in pure water is 1.6 × 10⁻² M. Calculate its molar solubility in 0.10 M NaCl solution. Ksp(PbCl₂) = 1.7 × 10⁻⁵

sub_topics.name: Quantitative Common Ion Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Performing calculations where the common ion concentration is much larger than the solubility, simplifying the ICE table.
example_tasks: Calculate the solubility of CaF₂ in 0.025 M NaF solution. Ksp(CaF₂) = 3.9 × 10⁻¹¹. Can you assume [F⁻] ≈ 0.025 M?
Compare the molar solubility of Ag₂CrO₄ in: (a) pure water, (b) 0.10 M AgNO₃. Ksp = 1.2 × 10⁻¹²
Explain why the common ion effect is used in qualitative analysis to selectively precipitate certain ions

sub_topics.name: Complex Ion Formation and Solubility
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that formation of complex ions can increase the solubility of sparingly soluble salts by removing free metal ions from solution.

sub_topics.name: Complex Ion Equilibria
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that metal ions can form complex ions with ligands (Lewis bases), characterized by formation constants (Kf), increasing overall solubility.
example_tasks: Define a complex ion and give three examples: Ag(NH₃)₂⁺, Cu(NH₃)₄²⁺, Fe(CN)₆³⁻. What is a ligand?
Write the formation equation and Kf expression for: Ag⁺ + 2NH₃ ⇌ Ag(NH₃)₂⁺
Explain how adding NH₃ to a saturated AgCl solution increases the solubility of AgCl by forming Ag(NH₃)₂⁺

sub_topics.name: Amphoteric Hydroxides
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that amphoteric hydroxides like Al(OH)₃ and Zn(OH)₃ dissolve in both acid (acting as base) and excess base (forming complex ions).
example_tasks: Explain what an amphoteric hydroxide is. Write equations showing Al(OH)₃ dissolving in: (a) HCl (acting as base), (b) excess NaOH (forming Al(OH)₄⁻)
Describe the behavior of Zn(OH)₂ when: (a) acid is added, (b) excess base is added. Why does it dissolve in both cases?
List three amphoteric hydroxides and explain their behavior in acidic and basic solutions

sub_topics.name: Selective Precipitation
sub_topics.short_description: Using differences in Ksp values to selectively precipitate one ion while keeping another in solution, important in qualitative analysis.

sub_topics.name: Separating Ions by Selective Precipitation
sub_topics.short_description: Adding a precipitating agent gradually to precipitate the ion with smaller Ksp first, calculating the concentration range for selective precipitation.
example_tasks: A solution contains 0.010 M Cl⁻ and 0.010 M CrO₄²⁻. When AgNO₃ is added slowly, which precipitates first: AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) or Ag₂CrO₄ (Ksp = 1.2 × 10⁻¹²)? Calculate [Ag⁺] needed for each
Can you effectively separate Ba²⁺ from Ca²⁺ by adding sulfate? Ksp(BaSO₄) = 1.1 × 10⁻¹⁰, Ksp(CaSO₄) = 2.4 × 10⁻⁵. Show calculations
Describe the qualitative analysis scheme for separating Group I cations (Ag⁺, Pb²⁺, Hg₂²⁺) using HCl. What is the basis for this separation?

grade_11_12.name: Organic Chemistry
grade_11_12.short_description: Comprehensive study of organic compounds including nomenclature, isomerism, functional group reactions, reaction mechanisms, and synthesis. Students explore the structure, properties, and transformations of carbon-based molecules.

sub_topics.name: Advanced Organic Nomenclature
sub_topics.short_description: Learning IUPAC naming rules for complex organic molecules including branched alkanes, alkenes with multiple bonds, and molecules with multiple functional groups.

sub_topics.name: Naming Branched Alkanes
sub_topics.short_description: Using IUPAC rules to name branched alkanes: finding the longest chain, numbering to give lowest numbers, naming branches as alkyl groups.
example_tasks: Name the following branched alkane: CH₃CH₂CH(CH₃)CH₂CH₃ (2-methylpentane). Identify the main chain and branches
Draw the structure of 3-ethyl-2,4-dimethylhexane. Show all carbon atoms and hydrogen atoms
Explain the priority rules for numbering carbons in the main chain. When do you number from left vs. right?

sub_topics.name: Naming Alkenes and Alkynes
sub_topics.short_description: Naming unsaturated hydrocarbons using -ene and -yne suffixes, indicating position of double or triple bonds with numbers.
example_tasks: Name: CH₂=CHCH₂CH₃ (1-butene or but-1-ene). Why is the number necessary?
Draw the structure of 2-methylbut-2-ene. Where is the double bond located?
Name: HC≡CCH₂CH₃ (but-1-yne or 1-butyne). Explain the difference between but-1-yne and but-2-yne

sub_topics.name: Naming Compounds with Functional Groups
sub_topics.short_description: Systematic naming of alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, ethers, amines, and amides following priority rules.
example_tasks: Name the following alcohol: CH₃CH₂CH₂OH (propan-1-ol or 1-propanol). Compare with CH₃CH(OH)CH₃ (propan-2-ol)
Name: CH₃CHO (ethanal or acetaldehyde) and CH₃COCH₃ (propanone or acetone). What is the difference in functional group position?
Write the structure of ethanoic acid (acetic acid), ethyl ethanoate (ethyl acetate), and ethanamide (acetamide)

sub_topics.name: Advanced Isomerism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding structural isomers, geometric (cis-trans) isomers, and optical isomers (enantiomers), including their properties and identification.

sub_topics.name: Types of Structural Isomers
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying chain isomers (different carbon skeletons), position isomers (functional group in different positions), and functional group isomers (different functional groups).
example_tasks: Draw all structural isomers of C₅H₁₂ (there are three). Name each isomer
Draw position isomers of C₃H₈O (propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol). How do their physical properties differ?
Draw functional group isomers with molecular formula C₂H₆O: ethanol (an alcohol) and dimethyl ether (an ether). Explain the difference in functional groups

sub_topics.name: Geometric (Cis-Trans) Isomers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that restricted rotation around double bonds creates cis (same side) and trans (opposite sides) isomers with different physical properties.
example_tasks: Draw cis-but-2-ene and trans-but-2-ene. Explain why rotation around the C=C bond is restricted
Explain why CH₂=CHCH₃ (propene) does not show cis-trans isomerism, but but-2-ene does
Compare the physical properties of cis and trans isomers. Which typically has a higher melting point and why?

sub_topics.name: Optical Isomers (Enantiomers)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding chiral molecules with asymmetric carbon atoms (four different groups) that exist as non-superimposable mirror images, rotating plane-polarized light.
example_tasks: Define chiral carbon (asymmetric carbon). Identify the chiral carbon in 2-butanol: CH₃CH(OH)CH₂CH₃
Explain what enantiomers are and why they are called 'optical isomers.' What physical property differs between enantiomers?
Draw the two enantiomers of lactic acid (2-hydroxypropanoic acid). Are they superimposable mirror images?

sub_topics.name: Reactions of Hydrocarbons
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding characteristic reactions including combustion, substitution in alkanes, addition in alkenes/alkynes, and polymerization.

sub_topics.name: Combustion of Hydrocarbons
sub_topics.short_description: Complete combustion producing CO₂ and H₂O, incomplete combustion producing CO or C (soot), and their applications as fuels.
example_tasks: Write balanced equations for: (a) complete combustion of ethane (C₂H₆), (b) incomplete combustion producing CO
Calculate the volume of O₂ (at STP) needed for complete combustion of 1.0 mole of octane (C₈H₁₈)
Explain why incomplete combustion is dangerous (produces toxic CO). Under what conditions does it occur?

sub_topics.name: Substitution Reactions of Alkanes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding halogenation of alkanes (substitution of H with halogen) in presence of UV light or heat, proceeding through free radical mechanism.
example_tasks: Write the equation for chlorination of methane: CH₄ + Cl₂ → CH₃Cl + HCl (under UV light or heat)
Explain why alkanes are relatively unreactive and require harsh conditions (UV light) for substitution reactions
Write all possible products when propane reacts with Cl₂ under UV light. Which carbons can be substituted?

sub_topics.name: Addition Reactions of Alkenes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding addition of H₂ (hydrogenation), X₂ (halogenation), HX (hydrohalogenation), and H₂O (hydration) across C=C double bonds.
example_tasks: Write equations for ethene reacting with: (a) H₂ (Pt catalyst), (b) Br₂, (c) HCl, (d) H₂O (H⁺ catalyst)
Explain Markovnikov's rule for addition of HX to unsymmetrical alkenes. For CH₃CH=CH₂ + HBr, predict the major product
Describe the test for unsaturation: adding bromine water to an alkene causes the brown color to disappear. Write the equation for ethene with Br₂

sub_topics.name: Polymerization Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding addition polymerization of alkenes to form plastics and polymers, including polyethylene, polypropylene, and PVC.
example_tasks: Write the equation for polymerization of ethene (C₂H₄) to form polyethylene (polythene). Show at least three monomer units
Draw the polymer formed from propene (CH₂=CHCH₃). What is this polymer called?
Explain the difference between addition polymerization and condensation polymerization. Give an example of each

sub_topics.name: Reactions of Functional Groups
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding characteristic reactions of alcohols, carboxylic acids, esters, and other functional groups including oxidation, esterification, and hydrolysis.

sub_topics.name: Reactions of Alcohols
sub_topics.short_description: Oxidation of primary alcohols to aldehydes then carboxylic acids, secondary alcohols to ketones, combustion, and esterification.
example_tasks: Write equations for oxidation of ethanol: (1) to ethanal (using mild oxidizing agent), (2) to ethanoic acid (using strong oxidizing agent like KMnO₄)
Explain why tertiary alcohols (like 2-methylpropan-2-ol) cannot be easily oxidized. What structural feature prevents this?
Write the equation for dehydration of ethanol to form ethene: CH₃CH₂OH → CH₂=CH₂ + H₂O (using conc. H₂SO₄ and heat)

sub_topics.name: Reactions of Carboxylic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding acid-base reactions, esterification with alcohols, and reduction to alcohols.
example_tasks: Write the equation for ethanoic acid reacting with: (a) NaOH (neutralization), (b) Na₂CO₃ (producing CO₂), (c) ethanol (esterification)
Explain how esterification works: carboxylic acid + alcohol ⇌ ester + water (with conc. H₂SO₄ catalyst). Why is it reversible?
Write the equation for esterification of ethanoic acid with methanol to form methyl ethanoate

sub_topics.name: Reactions of Esters
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hydrolysis of esters in acid (producing alcohol and carboxylic acid) or base (saponification, producing alcohol and carboxylate salt).
example_tasks: Write the equation for acid hydrolysis of ethyl ethanoate: CH₃COOC₂H₅ + H₂O ⇌ CH₃COOH + C₂H₅OH
Write the equation for base hydrolysis (saponification) of ethyl ethanoate with NaOH. Why is this reaction irreversible?
Explain the saponification process for making soap from fats. What products are formed?

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Biological Molecules
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the structure and function of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids as essential biological polymers.

sub_topics.name: Carbohydrates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding monosaccharides (glucose, fructose), disaccharides (sucrose, maltose, lactose), and polysaccharides (starch, cellulose, glycogen).
example_tasks: Define carbohydrates and give their general formula: Cₙ(H₂O)ₙ. Classify glucose, sucrose, and starch as mono-, di-, or polysaccharides
Describe the structure and function of: (a) glucose (energy source), (b) starch (energy storage in plants), (c) cellulose (structural in plant cell walls)
Explain the difference between starch and cellulose. Why can humans digest starch but not cellulose?

sub_topics.name: Lipids (Fats and Oils)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding triglycerides as esters of glycerol and fatty acids, distinguishing saturated from unsaturated fats, and their roles in energy storage.
example_tasks: Define lipids and describe the structure of a triglyceride: glycerol + three fatty acid chains. Draw a general structure
Explain the difference between saturated and unsaturated fats. Which are typically solid at room temperature (fats) vs. liquid (oils)?
Describe hydrogenation of oils: adding H₂ to convert unsaturated fats to saturated fats, making margarine from vegetable oil

sub_topics.name: Proteins and Amino Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding amino acids as building blocks of proteins, connected by peptide bonds, with proteins having diverse structures and functions.
example_tasks: Draw the general structure of an amino acid: H₂N-CHR-COOH. What makes each amino acid different (the R group)?
Explain peptide bond formation (condensation reaction) between two amino acids, releasing water. Draw a dipeptide
List four functions of proteins: enzymes (catalysis), antibodies (immune response), hemoglobin (oxygen transport), structural proteins (collagen)

grade_11_12.name: Biochemistry
grade_11_12.short_description: Exploring the chemistry of life including detailed study of biomolecules, enzyme kinetics, metabolism, and energy transformations in living systems. Students learn about the molecular basis of biological processes and the chemistry underlying life.

sub_topics.name: Amino Acids and Proteins
sub_topics.short_description: Detailed study of amino acid structure, protein synthesis, protein structure levels, and protein function including enzymes.

sub_topics.name: Structure and Properties of Amino Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the 20 common amino acids, their classification by R-group properties (nonpolar, polar, acidic, basic), and their zwitterionic form.
example_tasks: Draw the general structure of an amino acid showing the amino group, carboxyl group, and variable R group. Label the alpha carbon
Explain what a zwitterion is. Draw the zwitterionic form of glycine at physiological pH (around pH 7)
Classify amino acids into categories: (a) nonpolar (e.g., alanine, valine), (b) polar uncharged (e.g., serine, cysteine), (c) acidic (e.g., aspartic acid), (d) basic (e.g., lysine)

sub_topics.name: Peptide Bonds and Polypeptides
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding peptide bond formation through condensation reactions and the primary structure of proteins as the amino acid sequence.
example_tasks: Draw the formation of a peptide bond between two amino acids (e.g., glycine and alanine), showing the condensation reaction that releases water
Define primary structure of a protein. Write the abbreviated structure of a tripeptide (e.g., Gly-Ala-Ser)
Explain why the peptide bond has partial double bond character, restricting rotation and creating a planar structure

sub_topics.name: Levels of Protein Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding primary (sequence), secondary (α-helix, β-sheet), tertiary (3D folding), and quaternary (multiple subunits) structure of proteins.
example_tasks: Define and distinguish the four levels of protein structure: primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary. Give an example of each
Describe two common secondary structures: α-helix (coiled spring) and β-pleated sheet. What bonds stabilize these structures?
Explain tertiary structure: 3D folding stabilized by disulfide bonds, hydrogen bonds, ionic interactions, and hydrophobic interactions. What determines the final shape?

sub_topics.name: Protein Denaturation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how proteins lose their structure and function when exposed to heat, pH changes, or chemicals that disrupt bonds.
example_tasks: Define denaturation. Explain what happens to protein structure (not primary sequence) during denaturation
Give three examples of denaturing agents: (a) heat (cooking an egg), (b) pH changes (acid in stomach), (c) organic solvents. How does each work?
Explain why denaturation is often irreversible. Can denatured proteins regain their function?

sub_topics.name: Enzymes and Biological Catalysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding enzymes as biological catalysts, enzyme-substrate specificity, factors affecting enzyme activity, and enzyme kinetics including the Michaelis-Menten model.

sub_topics.name: Enzyme Function and Specificity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how enzymes lower activation energy through formation of enzyme-substrate complexes at the active site, with high specificity.
example_tasks: Explain how enzymes catalyze reactions by lowering activation energy. Draw an energy diagram comparing catalyzed vs. uncatalyzed reactions
Describe the lock-and-key model and the induced-fit model of enzyme action. Which is more accurate and why?
Define active site and substrate specificity. Why can one enzyme only catalyze specific reactions?

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Enzyme Activity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how temperature, pH, substrate concentration, and inhibitors affect enzyme reaction rates.
example_tasks: Sketch a graph showing enzyme activity vs. temperature. Explain why activity increases then decreases, identifying the optimum temperature
Explain why enzymes have optimal pH values. What happens to enzyme structure at extreme pH values?
Describe the effect of substrate concentration on reaction rate. Why does the rate plateau at high [substrate]?

sub_topics.name: Enzyme Inhibition
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding competitive inhibition (inhibitor competes with substrate for active site) and non-competitive inhibition (inhibitor binds elsewhere, changing enzyme shape).
example_tasks: Define competitive inhibition. Draw a diagram showing how a competitive inhibitor blocks the active site. Can this be overcome by adding more substrate?
Define non-competitive inhibition. Explain how an inhibitor binding to an allosteric site changes enzyme activity
Give examples of enzyme inhibitors: (a) competitive (e.g., statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis), (b) non-competitive (e.g., heavy metals), (c) irreversible (e.g., penicillin)

sub_topics.name: Enzyme Kinetics and Michaelis-Menten Equation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the relationship between reaction velocity and substrate concentration, introducing Vmax and Km concepts.
example_tasks: Sketch a Michaelis-Menten curve showing reaction velocity (V) vs. substrate concentration [S]. Label Vmax and Km
Define Vmax (maximum velocity when enzyme is saturated) and Km (substrate concentration at half Vmax, indicating enzyme-substrate affinity)
Explain what a low Km value indicates about enzyme-substrate affinity. Which enzyme has higher affinity: Km = 0.001 M or Km = 0.1 M?

sub_topics.name: Carbohydrate Metabolism
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding glycolysis, cellular respiration, and fermentation as pathways for extracting energy from glucose.

sub_topics.name: Glycolysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the breakdown of glucose to pyruvate in the cytoplasm, producing ATP and NADH without requiring oxygen.
example_tasks: Summarize glycolysis: glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆) → 2 pyruvate (C₃H₄O₃) + 2 ATP + 2 NADH. Where does this occur?
Explain that glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and doesn't require oxygen (anaerobic). What is the net ATP gain?
Describe the two phases of glycolysis: (1) energy investment (ATP consumed), (2) energy payoff (ATP and NADH produced)

sub_topics.name: Cellular Respiration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding aerobic oxidation of pyruvate through the citric acid cycle and electron transport chain, producing CO₂, H₂O, and ATP.
example_tasks: Write the overall equation for cellular respiration: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ → 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + ATP. How much ATP is produced (approximately 30-32)?
Outline the three stages: (1) glycolysis, (2) citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle), (3) electron transport chain and oxidative phosphorylation
Explain where each stage occurs: glycolysis (cytoplasm), citric acid cycle (mitochondrial matrix), electron transport chain (inner mitochondrial membrane)

sub_topics.name: Fermentation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding anaerobic pathways that regenerate NAD⁺ when oxygen is absent, including lactic acid and alcoholic fermentation.
example_tasks: Compare lactic acid fermentation (in muscle cells): pyruvate → lactate, with alcoholic fermentation (in yeast): pyruvate → ethanol + CO₂
Explain why fermentation is necessary when oxygen is limited. What would happen to glycolysis without NAD⁺ regeneration?
Compare ATP yield: cellular respiration (~30-32 ATP per glucose) vs. fermentation (2 ATP per glucose). Why is aerobic respiration more efficient?

sub_topics.name: Lipids and Nucleic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the structure and function of lipids in membranes and energy storage, and nucleic acids in genetic information storage and transfer.

sub_topics.name: Lipid Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding phospholipids in cell membranes, steroids, and the role of lipids in energy storage and signaling.
example_tasks: Draw the structure of a phospholipid showing the hydrophilic head (phosphate group) and hydrophobic tails (fatty acid chains). Explain amphipathic nature
Describe the lipid bilayer structure of cell membranes. Why do phospholipids spontaneously form bilayers in water?
Give examples of important lipids: (a) triglycerides (energy storage), (b) phospholipids (membranes), (c) steroids (cholesterol, hormones)

sub_topics.name: Nucleotides and Nucleic Acids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the structure of DNA and RNA, including nucleotide composition, base pairing, and the double helix structure.
example_tasks: Draw the structure of a nucleotide showing: (1) phosphate group, (2) pentose sugar (ribose or deoxyribose), (3) nitrogenous base
List the four bases in DNA (A, T, G, C) and RNA (A, U, G, C). Explain complementary base pairing: A-T (or A-U) and G-C
Describe the DNA double helix: two antiparallel strands held together by hydrogen bonds between complementary bases. What bonds connect the sugar-phosphate backbone?

sub_topics.name: DNA Structure and Function
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding DNA as the molecule of heredity, with the sequence of bases encoding genetic information.
example_tasks: Explain the structure of DNA discovered by Watson and Crick: double helix with antiparallel strands and complementary base pairing
Given one DNA strand sequence (5'-ATCGTA-3'), write the complementary strand sequence. Remember antiparallel orientation
Explain why DNA is stable: multiple hydrogen bonds, base stacking interactions, and the sugar-phosphate backbone provide structural integrity

grade_11_12.name: Environmental Chemistry
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding the chemistry of Earth's atmosphere, water systems, and soil, including pollution, climate change, ozone depletion, and green chemistry principles. Students explore human impact on chemical cycles and sustainable solutions.

sub_topics.name: Atmospheric Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the composition of the atmosphere, photochemical reactions, air pollution, and the chemistry of climate change and ozone depletion.

sub_topics.name: Composition of the Atmosphere
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the layers of the atmosphere and the composition of gases including N₂ (78%), O₂ (21%), Ar, CO₂, and trace gases.
example_tasks: List the major components of Earth's atmosphere by percentage: N₂ (78%), O₂ (21%), Ar (0.9%), CO₂ (0.04%), and trace gases
Describe the layers of the atmosphere: troposphere (weather), stratosphere (ozone layer), mesosphere, thermosphere. Where do we live?
Explain why atmospheric composition is crucial for life. What roles do O₂ and CO₂ play?

sub_topics.name: Greenhouse Effect and Climate Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how greenhouse gases (CO₂, CH₄, H₂O, N₂O) trap heat through absorption of infrared radiation, and the chemistry of climate change.
example_tasks: Explain the greenhouse effect: greenhouse gases absorb IR radiation emitted by Earth, trapping heat in the atmosphere. Why is this process natural and necessary?
List major greenhouse gases and their sources: CO₂ (fossil fuel combustion), CH₄ (agriculture, livestock), N₂O (fertilizers), H₂O vapor
Explain the enhanced greenhouse effect: increased CO₂ from human activities intensifies heat trapping, causing global warming. What are the main sources of excess CO₂?

sub_topics.name: Ozone Layer and Ozone Depletion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the role of stratospheric ozone (O₃) in absorbing UV radiation and how CFCs catalytically destroy ozone.
example_tasks: Explain the formation of ozone in the stratosphere: O₂ + UV light → 2O; O + O₂ → O₃. Why is stratospheric ozone important?
Describe how CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons) destroy ozone: CFCl₃ + UV → CFCl₂ + Cl; Cl + O₃ → ClO + O₂; ClO + O → Cl + O₂ (Cl is regenerated as a catalyst)
Explain the Montreal Protocol (1987): international treaty banning CFCs to protect the ozone layer. Has it been successful?

sub_topics.name: Air Pollution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sources and effects of air pollutants including particulate matter, SO₂, NO₂, CO, and photochemical smog.
example_tasks: List major air pollutants: particulate matter (PM), SO₂ (sulfur dioxide), NOₓ (nitrogen oxides), CO (carbon monoxide), O₃ (ground-level ozone), VOCs
Explain the formation of acid rain: SO₂ + H₂O → H₂SO₃ (sulfurous acid) → H₂SO₄ (sulfuric acid); NO₂ + H₂O → HNO₃ (nitric acid). What are the effects?
Describe photochemical smog: NOₓ + VOCs + sunlight → O₃ + other pollutants. Why is it worse in sunny cities with heavy traffic?

sub_topics.name: Water Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding water as a solvent, water pollution sources and treatment, hard water, and the chemistry of aquatic systems.

sub_topics.name: Water as the Universal Solvent
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding water's unique properties as a polar solvent, including high specific heat, surface tension, and ability to dissolve ionic and polar substances.
example_tasks: Explain why water is called the 'universal solvent.' What types of substances dissolve in water and why?
Describe the properties of water that make it essential for life: high specific heat (temperature regulation), polarity (solvent), hydrogen bonding (structure)
Explain the hydration of ions: polar water molecules surround and stabilize dissolved ions like Na⁺ and Cl⁻

sub_topics.name: Water Pollution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding sources of water pollution including industrial discharge, agricultural runoff, sewage, and effects like eutrophication and bioaccumulation.
example_tasks: List major water pollutants: heavy metals (Pb, Hg), organic compounds (pesticides, PCBs), nutrients (N, P causing eutrophication), pathogens, thermal pollution
Explain eutrophication: excess nutrients (from fertilizers) → algal blooms → oxygen depletion → fish kills. What is the role of phosphates and nitrates?
Describe bioaccumulation and biomagnification: persistent pollutants (like mercury) concentrate in organisms and increase in concentration up the food chain

sub_topics.name: Water Treatment
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding municipal water treatment processes including coagulation, sedimentation, filtration, and disinfection to produce safe drinking water.
example_tasks: Describe the steps in water treatment: (1) coagulation/flocculation (removing particles), (2) sedimentation, (3) filtration, (4) disinfection (chlorination or UV)
Explain how chlorination disinfects water: Cl₂ + H₂O → HOCl + HCl; HOCl → H⁺ + OCl⁻. Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) kills bacteria
Describe wastewater treatment: primary (physical removal), secondary (biological decomposition), tertiary (chemical treatment). Why is each stage necessary?

sub_topics.name: Hard Water
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding hard water containing dissolved Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions, its effects, and softening methods including ion exchange.
example_tasks: Define hard water and explain its causes: water containing dissolved Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺ (from CaCO₃, MgCO₃ in rocks). What problems does it cause?
Explain how soap doesn't lather in hard water: Ca²⁺ + soap → calcium soap (precipitate). This wastes soap and creates scum
Describe water softening methods: (1) ion exchange (replacing Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺ with Na⁺), (2) adding washing soda (Na₂CO₃ precipitates Ca²⁺ as CaCO₃)

sub_topics.name: Green Chemistry Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the principles of sustainable chemistry including waste prevention, atom economy, safer solvents, and renewable feedstocks.

sub_topics.name: Twelve Principles of Green Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding key principles including preventing waste, designing safer chemicals, using renewable feedstocks, and maximizing atom economy.
example_tasks: List and explain five key principles of green chemistry: (1) prevent waste, (2) maximize atom economy, (3) use safer chemicals, (4) design for energy efficiency, (5) use renewable feedstocks
Define atom economy: (mass of desired product / total mass of products) × 100%. Calculate atom economy for: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O (forming water)
Give examples of green chemistry: (1) using water as a solvent instead of organic solvents, (2) using catalysts to increase efficiency, (3) designing biodegradable products

sub_topics.name: Sustainable Energy and Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding alternative energy sources including solar cells, fuel cells, biofuels, and hydrogen economy from a chemical perspective.
example_tasks: Describe how fuel cells work: H₂ + O₂ → H₂O + electrical energy. What are the advantages over combustion engines?
Explain biofuels: ethanol from fermentation of corn/sugarcane, biodiesel from vegetable oils. What are advantages and challenges?
Describe solar cells (photovoltaic cells): semiconductors convert light energy directly to electrical energy. Why is this considered green technology?

sub_topics.name: Recycling and Waste Reduction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the chemistry of recycling plastics, metals, and paper, and the importance of reducing chemical waste.
example_tasks: Explain the chemistry of plastic recycling: different types of plastics (PET, HDPE, PVC) require different recycling processes. Why is sorting important?
Describe metal recycling: aluminum is easily recycled by melting (saves 95% of energy compared to producing from ore). Why is recycling metals beneficial?
Explain the waste hierarchy: (1) reduce (best), (2) reuse, (3) recycle, (4) energy recovery, (5) disposal (worst). Apply this to a real scenario

sub_topics.name: The Carbon Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the natural and human-influenced carbon cycle including photosynthesis, respiration, decomposition, and fossil fuel combustion.

sub_topics.name: Natural Carbon Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding carbon reservoirs (atmosphere, oceans, soil, organisms) and processes that move carbon between them.
example_tasks: Describe the carbon cycle: CO₂ in atmosphere → photosynthesis (plants) → organic compounds → respiration/decomposition → CO₂. Draw a simple diagram
List major carbon reservoirs: atmosphere (as CO₂), oceans (dissolved CO₂, HCO₃⁻), plants and animals (organic compounds), soil (organic matter), fossil fuels
Explain the role of photosynthesis: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂. This removes CO₂ from the atmosphere and stores it as organic matter

sub_topics.name: Human Impact on the Carbon Cycle
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how fossil fuel combustion and deforestation increase atmospheric CO₂, disrupting the natural carbon balance.
example_tasks: Explain how burning fossil fuels disrupts the carbon cycle: releases carbon that was stored underground for millions of years into the atmosphere as CO₂
Describe the impact of deforestation: fewer trees to absorb CO₂ through photosynthesis, and burning/decomposition of trees releases stored carbon
Discuss carbon sinks and sources: oceans absorb CO₂ (sink), but warming oceans absorb less. Forests are sinks, but deforestation converts them to sources

grade_11_12.name: Analytical Chemistry
grade_11_12.short_description: Understanding methods for identifying and quantifying chemical substances including spectroscopy, chromatography, and electrochemical analysis. Students learn instrumental techniques used in research and industry.

sub_topics.name: Spectroscopy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how molecules interact with electromagnetic radiation, including UV-Vis, IR, and mass spectrometry for structure determination.

sub_topics.name: Electromagnetic Spectrum and Molecular Interactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different regions of the EM spectrum (UV, visible, IR, microwave, radio) and how molecules absorb energy causing electronic, vibrational, or rotational transitions.
example_tasks: Draw the electromagnetic spectrum showing regions from gamma rays to radio waves. Label UV, visible, and IR regions used in spectroscopy
Explain what happens when molecules absorb: UV-Vis light (electronic transitions), IR light (molecular vibrations), microwave (molecular rotations)
Relate energy to wavelength: E = hc/λ. Which has higher energy: UV light or IR light? Explain

sub_topics.name: UV-Visible Spectroscopy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how UV-Vis spectroscopy measures electronic transitions in molecules, particularly conjugated systems and colored compounds, using Beer's Law.
example_tasks: Explain the principle of UV-Vis spectroscopy: molecules with conjugated double bonds or aromatic systems absorb UV-Vis light, causing electrons to jump to higher energy levels
State Beer's Law: A = εbc, where A = absorbance, ε = molar absorptivity, b = path length, c = concentration. How is this used for quantitative analysis?
Explain why compounds with extended conjugation absorb at longer wavelengths (lower energy). Use the example of β-carotene (orange) vs. ethene (colorless)

sub_topics.name: Infrared (IR) Spectroscopy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how IR spectroscopy identifies functional groups by measuring molecular vibrations, with characteristic absorption peaks.
example_tasks: Explain IR spectroscopy: molecules absorb IR radiation at frequencies matching bond vibrations (stretching, bending). Different functional groups have characteristic absorptions
Identify functional groups from IR peaks: O-H (broad, 3200-3600 cm⁻¹), C=O (sharp, ~1700 cm⁻¹), C-H (2850-3000 cm⁻¹), N-H (3300-3500 cm⁻¹)
Given an IR spectrum showing a sharp peak at 1715 cm⁻¹ and broad peak at 2500-3300 cm⁻¹, identify the compound as a carboxylic acid (C=O and O-H stretches)

sub_topics.name: Mass Spectrometry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how mass spectrometry determines molecular mass and structure by ionizing molecules and measuring mass-to-charge ratios of fragments.
example_tasks: Explain the basic principle of mass spectrometry: molecules are ionized, fragmented, and separated by mass-to-charge ratio (m/z), producing a mass spectrum
Identify the molecular ion peak (M⁺) in a mass spectrum: the peak with highest m/z value represents the intact molecular ion, giving the molecular mass
Interpret fragmentation patterns: loss of 15 (CH₃ group), loss of 29 (CHO or C₂H₅), etc. Use fragments to deduce molecular structure

sub_topics.name: Chromatography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding separation techniques based on differential partitioning between mobile and stationary phases, including paper, thin-layer, gas, and liquid chromatography.

sub_topics.name: Principles of Chromatography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chromatography separates mixtures based on different rates of movement through a stationary phase while being carried by a mobile phase.
example_tasks: Define chromatography and explain the basic principle: components separate based on their different affinities for the stationary phase vs. mobile phase
Define retention factor (Rf): Rf = distance traveled by substance / distance traveled by solvent. What does a high Rf value indicate?
Explain why substances separate: more polar substances interact more strongly with polar stationary phases and move slower

sub_topics.name: Types of Chromatography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different chromatographic techniques: paper, thin-layer (TLC), gas (GC), and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC).
example_tasks: Compare paper chromatography (stationary phase: paper) with thin-layer chromatography (stationary phase: silica gel on glass/plastic). When is each used?
Describe gas chromatography (GC): volatile samples are vaporized and carried through a column by inert gas. Used for separating volatile mixtures. What is the mobile phase?
Explain HPLC (high-performance liquid chromatography): high pressure forces liquid mobile phase through packed column. Used for non-volatile compounds. What are applications?

sub_topics.name: Applications of Chromatography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding practical applications in drug testing, environmental analysis, forensics, and quality control.
example_tasks: Describe how chromatography is used in forensics: analyzing ink composition, drug testing, identifying explosives
Explain quality control in pharmaceuticals: HPLC verifies drug purity by separating and quantifying active ingredients and impurities
Describe environmental applications: GC-MS (gas chromatography-mass spectrometry) detects pollutants in water, air, and soil at trace levels

sub_topics.name: Quantitative Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding methods for determining the amount of substance present, including gravimetric and volumetric analysis.

sub_topics.name: Gravimetric Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Determining quantity by measuring mass of a pure compound formed through precipitation, usually expressed as percent composition.
example_tasks: Explain gravimetric analysis: analyte is precipitated, filtered, dried, and weighed. The mass is used to calculate the original amount of analyte
Calculate the percentage of chloride in a sample: 0.500 g sample produces 0.287 g AgCl precipitate. Use stoichiometry and molar masses
Describe key steps in gravimetric analysis: precipitation, digestion (allowing precipitate to form completely), filtration, washing, drying, weighing

sub_topics.name: Volumetric Analysis (Titrations)
sub_topics.short_description: Determining concentration by measuring volume of solution needed to react completely, including acid-base, redox, and complexometric titrations.
example_tasks: Review acid-base titrations: using a standard solution to determine the concentration of an unknown acid or base by measuring volume at equivalence point
Describe redox titrations: using KMnO₄ or I₂ as titrants to determine concentration of reducing or oxidizing agents. Example: determining Fe²⁺ concentration
Explain complexometric titrations: using EDTA to determine metal ion concentrations by forming stable complexes. Used in water hardness testing

grade_11_12.name: Advanced Topics and Applications
grade_11_12.short_description: Exploring cutting-edge areas of chemistry including materials science, polymers, nanochemistry, and industrial applications. Students connect chemistry principles to modern technology and innovation.

sub_topics.name: Polymers and Materials Science
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding synthetic and natural polymers, polymerization mechanisms, polymer properties, and applications in materials.

sub_topics.name: Types of Polymers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding addition polymers (formed by adding monomers) vs. condensation polymers (formed with elimination of small molecules like H₂O).
example_tasks: Define polymer, monomer, and repeating unit. Give examples: polyethylene (from ethene), nylon (from diamine and diacid), proteins (from amino acids)
Compare addition polymerization (no atoms lost, e.g., polyethylene) with condensation polymerization (small molecule eliminated, e.g., nylon formation)
Draw the structure of polyethylene showing at least 4 repeating units. How is it formed from ethene monomers?

sub_topics.name: Polymer Properties and Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how structure affects properties: crystallinity, flexibility, strength, and thermal properties determining applications.
example_tasks: Explain how polymer properties depend on structure: branching (decreases crystallinity), cross-linking (increases strength), molecular weight (affects melting point)
Compare thermoplastics (can be melted and reshaped, e.g., polyethylene) with thermosets (cannot be melted once formed, e.g., epoxy resins)
Describe applications based on properties: HDPE (high-density polyethylene) for bottles (rigid), LDPE (low-density polyethylene) for bags (flexible), Teflon for non-stick coatings

sub_topics.name: Biodegradable Polymers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding environmentally friendly polymers that can decompose naturally, including polylactic acid (PLA) and natural polymers like starch.
example_tasks: Explain why most synthetic polymers are not biodegradable: strong C-C bonds resistant to breakdown by microorganisms. What environmental problems does this cause?
Describe biodegradable polymers: PLA (polylactic acid) from corn starch, polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) from bacteria. What makes them biodegradable?
Discuss applications of biodegradable polymers: medical sutures, drug delivery, packaging. What are advantages over conventional plastics?

sub_topics.name: Nanochemistry and Nanotechnology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding chemistry at the nanoscale (1-100 nm), including unique properties of nanomaterials and applications in electronics, medicine, and catalysis.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Nanomaterials
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that materials at nanoscale exhibit unique properties different from bulk materials due to high surface area to volume ratio and quantum effects.
example_tasks: Explain why nanomaterials have unique properties: very high surface area to volume ratio makes surface atoms dominate, leading to different chemical and physical properties
Describe quantum dots: semiconductor nanoparticles that emit specific colors depending on size. Why does size affect color?
Give examples of nanomaterial properties: gold nanoparticles appear red/purple (not gold), carbon nanotubes have exceptional strength, nanoparticle catalysts are more efficient

sub_topics.name: Applications of Nanotechnology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding applications in medicine (drug delivery, imaging), electronics (transistors, displays), energy (solar cells, batteries), and environmental remediation.
example_tasks: Describe medical applications: nanoparticles for targeted drug delivery (deliver drugs directly to cancer cells), contrast agents for imaging, antibacterial nanosilver
Explain electronics applications: carbon nanotubes in transistors, quantum dots in displays, graphene in flexible electronics
Discuss environmental applications: nanoparticles for water purification (removing contaminants), photocatalysts for breaking down pollutants, more efficient solar cells

sub_topics.name: Industrial Chemistry
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding large-scale chemical processes including Haber process, Contact process, metallurgy, and petrochemicals.

sub_topics.name: Haber Process (Ammonia Production)
sub_topics.short_description: Comprehensive understanding of ammonia synthesis from N₂ and H₂, including equilibrium optimization, catalyst use, and importance for fertilizers.
example_tasks: Describe the Haber process: N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), ΔH = -92 kJ. What conditions are used: temperature (450°C), pressure (200 atm), catalyst (iron)?
Explain the compromise in conditions: high pressure favors products (fewer moles of gas) but is expensive; moderate temperature gives reasonable rate without shifting equilibrium too far left
Discuss the importance: ammonia is used to make fertilizers (feeding billions), explosives, and other chemicals. Why is this one of the most important industrial processes?

sub_topics.name: Contact Process (Sulfuric Acid Production)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the three-stage process for producing H₂SO₄, one of the most important industrial chemicals.
example_tasks: Describe the Contact process stages: (1) S + O₂ → SO₂, (2) 2SO₂ + O₂ ⇌ 2SO₃ (V₂O₅ catalyst), (3) SO₃ + H₂SO₄ → H₂S₂O₇; then H₂S₂O₇ + H₂O → 2H₂SO₄
Explain conditions for step 2: moderate temperature (450°C), high pressure, V₂O₅ catalyst. Why not use low temperature despite exothermic reaction?
Discuss uses of H₂SO₄: fertilizers, petroleum refining, chemical manufacturing, batteries. Why is H₂SO₄ production an indicator of industrial development?

sub_topics.name: Metallurgy and Metal Extraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding extraction of metals from ores using reduction (carbon, electrolysis) based on reactivity series.
example_tasks: Explain extraction of iron in a blast furnace: Fe₂O₃ + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO₂ (reduction with carbon/CO). What is the source of CO?
Describe electrolytic extraction of aluminum: Al₂O₃ dissolved in molten cryolite, electrolyzed to produce Al at cathode. Why is this necessary instead of using carbon?
Compare extraction methods based on reactivity: very reactive metals (Na, Al) require electrolysis; medium reactivity (Fe, Zn) use reduction with carbon; unreactive (Au, Ag) found native
